review_text:
This is a memoir in which the author, while in law school and while having very dark thoughts, decides to seek help in the form of a group therapy session. Initially, therapy seems to do a lot of good for Tate. She’s forced to start talking about her issues with eating and sex, and the therapist (Dr. Rosen) helps her give voice to issues long left unspoken.

But as we go along, the therapist’s instructions and his role in the author’s life grows, especially as he suggests that she join additional

“I was afraid of marrying my heart with the scoring that rose naturally between people, the inevitable bumping against other peoples desires, demands, pettiness, preferences, and all the quotidian Negotiations that made up a relationship. Scoring was required for attachment, and my heart leapt the grooves”.

“The deep secret that I carried was that I didn’t belong. Anywhere. I spent half my days obsessing about food and my body and the weird shit I did to control both, and the other half trying

Giveaway Win!

I want to start this review off by saying that I don't think traditional forms of therapy are for everyone. I've tried going to therapy and I've tried taking anxiety medication and neither were for me. That does not mean that those things won't work for someone else. Mental health treatment is not a one size fits all type of thing.

For me these are the things that work for ME (these are not recommendations for anyone else)

1) taking time away (a day or two)from everyone (total solit
I love reading about other people's therapy, so was fascinated by this account of unconventional group therapy and its life-changing consequences.

Just what the doctor ordered to forget about the pandemic and no electricity- what’s better than reading about someone else’s crazy messed up life! Lots of humor and misery kept me engaged until the very last page!
Group is an engaging and entertaining read. The author goes deep as she brings us with her to group therapy sessions and shows how the difficult process of revealing personal secrets allowed her to develop more intimate relationships.

In this memoir, Christie Tate, a lawyer with an eat

I can’t really in good faith recommend this book to folks (unless you’re simply looking for non-fic that can be taken with a hefty grain of salt).

This was salacious and entertaining and... honestly kind of iffy.

Tate is a crassly funny narrator, and this book presents a no-holds-barred account of her experience with group therapy and coming to terms with traumatic memories and eating disorder recovery. I liked the metaphor of the scored heart that she uses throughout the book. Just like how one

This is a complex review for me!

I got to read this book as an ARC and I was super excited about it since I am first-year therapy graduate student. I think that I was coming at this book from a different angle. The book is from the perspective of a client in therapy, specifically group therapy. Christie is a very successful law student and professional who finds herself in need of help.

My main critique of this book (it is a memoir) was that I really struggled with ethical issues throughout the

I love reading advice columns and shows about people in therapy. I find the way people see their own problems fascinating, and I find them even more fascinating when taken through another person who is there to consider and possibly disagree with the way a person sees their problems. I am frustrated that I can't read a million books about people sharing their experiences in therapy. But I get it. Sometimes when I watch/read/hear these stories I think, "Wow, how can anyone be okay sharing this mu

“My turn, your turn. Back and forth. So this was how it happened. This was how you built an intimate relationship. Word by word. Story by story. Revelation by revelation. Just like group.”

An intimate debut memoir centering on group therapy and how opening up to strangers saved a life.

I’ve often wondered how freeing it would be for a stranger or group of strangers to know my secrets. To have a group of people that did not hold back, judge or even tell you what to do. Simply a group of individuals
Thoughts soon.
Review to come but I definitely recommend this one.

This is difficult to rate because I didn't have any problems with the writing or how the author presented herself as a person, but the whole thing made my skin crawl. Everything Dr. Rosen did felt gross and unethical and over the line. There were so many times when Christie was about ready to quit going to group, and I was like "Good for you! Recognize that this isn't ok!" and then she always went back. I am glad that she ultimately got what she wanted and is in a good place. However, I don't th

I didn’t really ‘finish’ this book as such, I gave up sixty pages in. If this is an actual memoir and not simply a piece of fiction, then there is a psychiatrist out there in the world somewhere that seriously shouldn’t be practicing. I am a huge supporter of therapy, but this type of ‘therapy’ is unethical and just plain wrong. What a weird thing to decide to write about and share with others..

Oh wow. Five stars all the way around.

I know that several reviews I’ve read are stuck on the ethics of Dr. Rosen and the way he chooses to practice in his group therapy, but you know what? It didn’t bother me. I see the value in the way he makes everyone uncomfortable and let’s them feel things and get angry and work through it as a team. Having a support system is so important. Having a place to go every week at an exact time to keep the feeling of purpose alive in people who are struggling to

This book was really uncomfortable to read. At times I also found it horrifying and disturbing. I applaud the author's desire to seek help, but the group she attended came across as "cult-ish" and/or something that would be endorsed by Gywenth Paltrow (Goop). Any group that requires you to come to their organization 3 times a week for 90 minutes $800/month screams cult-ish. This kind of "therapy" is not realistic or sustainable for the average person. Most people cannot dedicate that much time t

user_name: PinkAmy loves books, cats and naps
review_text:
I listened to the Audible version of the book, read by the author.

Memoirs are difficult when the writer comes across as unlikable, more so when that writer narrates her story. I suppose a certain amount of self-importance is necessary to assume one’s life is worth a story, unless you’re someone famous like Michelle Obama or you’ve had an extraordinary life experience or deep insight, none of which applies to Christie Tate. She comes across as privileged and unlikable, but that wasn’t my biggest

Tate's evolution of self through totally honest, soul-baring & nontraditional-style group therapy will leave you feeling mentally taken apart & put back together. 'Group' is raw w/ insight & vulnerability & it was kind of therapeutic just reading it, as it creates a sense of hopefulness & positivity. Fantastic non-fic story!

As someone who has had therapy as a part of my life for as long as I can remember, I have always been fascinated by what it is like for other people. I am so grateful that especially during this last decade mental health and therapy have been normalized so much.

I started attending therapy when I was just a child during my parent's tumultuous and quite painful divorce. While it was something that was monumental in my ability to process many hard encounters and feelings, it was also a very isolati

****Now available!****

Thank you to Christie Tate and Simon & Schuster UK for a copy of the book in exchange for an honest review.

As I've said before: I LOVE a memoir. The more ordinary the person, the better! Me and nosey self just love a snoop into other peoples' lives and BOY did I get a snoop!

Christie is a law student battling with an eating disorder and intimacy issues and finally decides to take the plunge and start therapy. She is recommended Dr Rosen by one of her friends and she goes to
DNF at 22%. Just didn't care about all these different people in the group's complaints. Was grossed out by some of the therapist's the sexual comments.

Welp so, full transparency here, I have an eating disorder. I used to go to this awesome group a few years ago and now struggling to drag myself to this new group therapy. I tried reading this to find me some motivation to go, but it ended up being an upsetting read for me personally.

Dr. Rosen's therapies are strange and unorthodox and not alike anything you'd find normally. If you have questions about normal group therapy, ask google, your therapist, or myself. -- This book is not about anyone

This is quite a strange read and one that I alternately liked and didn't like.
It is extremely personal and I found the parts where there are lots of reference to sex a bit much.
I didn't particularly like the characters and found the whole American obsession with therapy hard to understand.
We basically join Christie on her journey, via group therapy with Dr Rosen, in her search for personal enlightenment and the opportunity to free herself from a lifetime of crushing self-doubt, self-harm and lac
I would go with 4.5. Refreshing and honest - and full of hope.

I usually do not read memoirs, but one of my friends is a librarian and had an advanced copy of this book. As a retired psychotherapist, I have to question some of Dr. Rosen's techniques and ethics. He could have directed the group to intervene more and could have helped the author better handle her emotional outbursts, which were over the top, creating havoc in her life, and really distressing to her. While I agree with his stance on not keeping secrets, I would hope readers understand that go

I have no idea who Christie Tate is but reading her memoir was perhaps one of the most intimate experiences I’ve ever felt reading about someone else’s life. Group is raw, powerful, funny, tear-jerking, and honest. I flew through the pages in a few short hours soaking it all in; every page left me wanting to know more, read further. I 100% recommend for a cathartic reading experience!

I'm no stranger to recovery memoirs or tales of therapy but I can honestly say I've never read a book like this before! Unpredictable, heartfelt and absorbing, I read this book and can't stop thinking about it.

Comments were deleted somehow.

Book was " off" for me. Something fishy about it.
Group was not a book for me. I just could not connect with the information or the author. The information felt too forced for my liking.

"I can be mad at you and still love you, you know"
No, actually, I didn't know that. I had no idea.

There are so many revelations like the one above in Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Saved My Life by Christie Tate that made me realize how much we assume how others feel.

The author, with unabashed honesty, takes us through her harrowing journey of grief, loneliness, depression, and self loathing until she joins Dr. Rosen's many group therapy sessions. She writes with such fearles

Group
280 pages
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Christie Tate had just been named the top student in her law school class and had her eating disorder under control at last. Why then was she driving through Chicago fantasizing her own death? Enter Dr. Jonathan Rosen, a therapist who calmly assured her that if she joins one of his psychotherapy groups, he can transform her life. All she has to do is show up and be honest. So begins her entry into the strange, terrifying and life-changing world of group therapy. ( trigge

I just loved this. It was so entertaining that I flew through it in one weekend. But I offer one caveat: this therapist seems certifiably nuts. While I’ve never been to therapy, some of his prescriptions and recommendations seem so far off. That said, everything seemed to work out for our memoirist here and I’m stunned that she chose to share these same (and embarrassing) stories with the world. Group seemed safe enough... at one point it seemed the entire city of Chicago would have known all he

Christie Tate has always been an overachiever. She buried herself in her textbooks and earned first place in her class at Loyola Law. She lands a plum job working for one of the nation’s leading law firms, but Christie wants more. All her life she has had trouble building and maintaining close relationships. She longs for a family and wishes for death. Told by her mother not to share her personal business, she nonetheless seeks help from Dr. Rosen who assigns her to one of his groups.
A raw, hone

I am found this memoir such an interesting read. I have never had therapy for myself so it’s an interesting look into a probably less conventional group. I’m not sure Group Therapy would be for me but I do like the idea of everyone working together.

Thank you Simon & Schuster Canada and Netgalley for my review copy.

Bravo! I’ve read and loved many memoirs but this one was hands-down my favorite. If I had to sum it up in one word I would call it CATHARTIC.

Dr. Rosen insists his clients tell all because anything less is more toxic than everyone knowing your business so Tate bears all to her quirky, Einstein-like therapist and six strangers - from bulimia to her childhood friend’s father drowning to finding a man who will love her. It’s raw. It

To start, this is intimidating to write a review that has the potential to be taken to group! I am sure Dr. Rosen would have something interesting to say about my fear.

That being said, this book was just this book for me. I neither liked nor disliked it. At times it made me uncomfortable, while at times I identified with it. The writing was uneven and at times confusing. It was also, strangely intriguing and relatable at times.

I am not sorry I finished it, but not sure I would ever read it again

Therapy is an essential part of getting to the core roots of your problems and essentially taking back your life. I personally have never done group therapy but Christine Tate has hit the nail on the head. Her experience with group therapy after overcoming anorexia is quite an achievement. Any one who has experienced depression and suicidal thought can relate to this book. I think the unconventional way that her therapist ran the group saved quite a few people. I give this amazing book five star

Thank you #Netgalley for the advanced copy.

Wow! I loved following the progression of Christie and really seeing therapy work for her. The concept of this group therapy seemed so unique! I applaude Christie and the others in the group share such personal things and to really make connections and force each other out of their comfort zone. So many things seemed so relatable about her thought process, but she trusted in the program and it ended up working for her.

I LOVED, loved, loved this book!

Thank you to Simon & Schuster for this advanced reading copy--I was SO excited to win it, as these types of books are my jam! (anything, pretty much, person growth oriented). Though one never knows if they will be any good.

To my utter surprise...wow, Ms. Tate can write. Much has and will be made of the content/material about which she writes. But writing-wise, she definitely is far more skilled than I expected from her being a hotshot lawyer (her career in this me

Group - How one therapist and a circle of strangers saved my life // by Christie Tate

Sometimes I come across titles or blurbs that leave me thinking "THIS WAS WRITTEN JUST FOR ME." Now, I'm not that delusional that I think that is literally true but I still wonder if someone, something, somewhere had me in mind when this book idea came into existence. For someone that was not even into memoirs until last year, I sure to race through them at full speed now, especially those related to mental heal

I've read three "therapy" books in the last 18 months. I think I'm hungry for stories of transformation, to be reminded that change is possible. Of these, "Maybe You Should Talk to Someone" is still my favorite, but I really enjoyed Group.

Unlike the other therapy books I've read, Group is written from the POV of a patient, not the therapist; it is the story of Christie, a high-achieving law student who is rated #1 in her class and secretly falling apart. When a friend recommends that she go to a

So I’ve been rolling this review around in my head since I finished the book, and to be honest I’m still not sure where I land. From a strictly entertainment standpoint, it was good. I listened to it and found myself really looking forward to the times when I could get back to the story. Christie is no holds barred- and from what she shares in the book we know that complete honestly was something she struggled with before therapy so for her openness, I applaud her. That said, I love to get deep

I am not quite sure what to make of this book, on the one hand it is honest, well written and ultimately uplifting, on the other hand it is a gross invasion of others’ privacy, disturbing to read and I could have done without the yucky intimate details of her sex life. I wonder if part of my distaste is that engaging with therapy appears to be mainstream in the USA whereas it is less common in the UK.
Certainly Christie suffered from post traumatic stress disorder after she witnessed a friend’s f

This book was right up my alley topic wise, and that aspect of it was fine. Nothing groundbreaking, the writing is okay, and the stories were also okay. There is a lot of emphasis on sex and intimacy which I wasn’t expecting, kudos to Tate for putting her bare life out there for everyone to read. It did get repetitive towards the end where the behaviours were repeating themselves just in different ways, but as is the nature of mental illness I guess.

BUT, my biggest concern with the book is Dr R

this book is fun to read because it's messy, but wow is the author a narcissist. I have seen people criticize the book because she mentioned group members stories, but honestly it's mainly about her and her boring life. Her life is not interesting, its the average mid 20 year old woman experience, she just breaks a few more plates. Her fellow peers sound way more complex and I was very worried while reading it about the ways the therapist could be taking advantage of their emotional state. That

Some of the stories and fears shared in this was great and it definitely had some LOL moments; however, there must be some kind of rules broken by the therapist who leads the group when she starts over sharing to the participants in group. If I was going to support, I would feel creeped out when the therapist is taking over and spilling her guts. Still a worthy read for people that find comfort for their issues in a setting like this but it may not be for all.

Goof writing and some stories but ta

"Group" is an intimate memoir exploring author Christie Tate's experience with mental ill health and an eating disorder, and the support she found in an unconventional group setting. Whilst therapist Dr Rosen's methods seem unorthodox, there is clearly validity in his approach. Tate really opens herself up, exposing her vulnerability in a warts and all manner. Yes, this makes for an uncomfortable read in places but I figure if Christie has taken the time to bare her soul, the least I can do as a

An engaging and entertaining memoir of one woman’s experiences with the healing power of group therapy. The author goes deep as she brings us with her to her sessions and shows how the difficult process of revealing her most personal secrets allowed her to develop more intimate relationships.

Read our full review here:
https://booktrib.com/2020/10/27/one-w...

Listened on audiobook. I enjoyed this book and had no trouble with the pace of the story, but unlike the book “Maybe You Should Talk to Someone” I didn’t put it down feeling like I had many, structured actionable lessons or takeaways from Christie’s story. There certainly are lessons but it didn’t feel like the story was written with those in mind.

The whole time I was reading this I was wondering - why am I so invested in the author’s relationship history? But I couldn’t put it down, and flew through it in just a couple sittings. Her story isn’t exactly remarkable, but it was told in such a way that kept me engaged and curious (and laughing), and hoping for her sake that her group therapy would finally “work.”

This book was a really honest and absorbing exploration of group therapy, and the impact it has on people. At times it was an uncomfortable read, and covered a lot of issues from eating disorders, to trauma, to sexuality and attachment issues in a lot of visceral detail. Overall the story was really interesting, and the personal development of the characters made me keep coming back for more. Not for the faint hearted! Overall I enjoyed this.

I received an pre-publication copy of this book throu

I read Group by Christie Tate via Pigeonhole, which released a stave a day for 10 days. I have never been in therapy and have no intentions of ever seeking help from a therapist. I found the book very frivolous and was bored by the end of the book. The book wasn’t for me and held little to interest me.

3.5⭐

I was fortunate to receive a copy of this ARC from Pigeonhole.

It feels wrong somehow to review an autobiographical book, because what right do I have to critique someone's life?!

However, I did find this a difficult read. The therapy setting in America is very different to my experiences in the UK, even group therapy, and some of the work done was quite shocking. It didn't always feel like Christie was receiving the right support and some of Dr Rosen's treatments seemed ethically and morally
Found the author to be self-centred, self-indulgent, attention seeking, over sharing and was uncomfortable reading this book.

This is different from any book I’ve ever read. I read it in a group, and have to admit to getting annoyed a few times with people judging the author and her therapist on his ways of dealing with the group he was leading. I admit it was a different way of handling his group as therapists usually go with secrecy. I am not going to say I enjoyed the book. But I can say it was well written and there was times I could put myself in Christie’s place. I gave it 3 stars. And I would recommend it.

I don't really know how to review this book. "Enjoy" seems the wrong word. It's a very honest memoir of a person's journey through therapy. Lots of the author's thoughts and feelings really resonated with me so it was sometimes a difficult read. Overall I'm glad I stuck with it.

The group therapy angle of this book had me hooked, especially this being a memoir. Christie made me laugh, cry, and feel. Read this book if you want to feel something.

Thanks to Netgalley, the author and Avid Reader Press for an ARC in exchange for an honest review.

Thanks to Net Galley and Simon and Schuster UK for an advance copy of this book.

Okay so let me start out by saying I did have high hopes for this book. I love self-improvement and I was hoping I could learn something. I was under the impression is was majority non-fiction and factual. After about the half way point I was confused.

I believe this book is a blend of memoir and fiction (I’m really not sure how it falls into non-fiction). It does explain the behaviour of a very strange therapist who
Really not for me, I didn’t feel right reading it. I felt as though I was intruding on confidential matters

3.75 rounded up - I love reading books about therapy and group therapy has always seemed so TV-esque to me. At times this story was too much for me - it was totally manic at many points, which is probably the point, and I could have done without graphic sexual details in favor of something a little more ~subtle~. But I applaud Christie for sharing arguably the most vulnerable, embarrassing, and emotional parts of her life! If I were in group therapy there’s no way I’d write a book about it.

Many

Group by Christie Tate is a free NetGalley ebook that I read in early October.

Overstressed suicidal author Tate goes to group therapy to sort things out. She's initially reluctant to share things, be asked questions, acknowledge a complicated relationship with food, then gradually sharing all her inner stressors, realizing her inner worth and reasons for living.

Christie Tate is at the top of her law school class, but unfortunately, she still just isn’t happy. When her friend tells her about her group therapy, Christie decides why not give this Dr. Rosen a chance. Now she is meeting with a group of 6 people every week and telling them everything about her and her life. Christie is put off by some of Dr. Rosen’s ideas at first, but over time she comes to love these people like family. Doesn’t mean she doesn’t hate them at some times too.

This one started

Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Saved My Life by Christie Tate was a really interesting exploration of the author's experience with group therapy. Going into this, I knew very little about what group therapy actually looked like. That said, this was also a very unique therapy experience, so the book is really about exploring the author's specific experiences versus a commentary on any type o

I've done a huge amount of therapy, both group and individual, in my life time. I enjoy learning about other's experiences and what they may have picked up during their time in therapy. Everyone has different needs for therapy and I appreciate the way people can learn from each other. The account just seems extreme and far fetched. I don't want to down play or criticize someone else's experience and I'm very glad this worked for the author. But my deeply personal opinion is that I would have lef

I really enjoyed this author's voice, but did not enjoy the read at all. Tate expressed herself well and I felt like she was the friend you talk about saying "She's such a great catch, why can't she find a man?" I wanted to relate to her, but as soon as life takes a turn she doesn't like, she is literally on the floor screaming like a toddler in the middle of her group therapy. I couldn't sympathize with her and I also couldn't get behind Dr. Rosen's method. It felt like she spent 5+ years being

Thank you to Avid Reader Press and Simon and Schuster for sending me this ARC to review.

I laughed, I cried, I got mad, and I cared a lot about the characters in reading this book. Christie Tate has really put her life out there in this memoir. The book starts with her fixation with wanting to die. This then leads to her sharing of her struggles with bulimia, anxiety, depression, social angst and lack of relationships (both friends and romance). The back drop for this book is mainly Dr. Rosen's

Group is an interesting memoir on the experience of group therapy.

Tate is a skillful autobiographical writer, approaching her subject with brutal honesty and striking just the right balance between humour and misery. Her story makes for a compulsive, engaging read.

The therapy itself made me a little uncomfortable at times, with Dr Rosen's unconventional approach and problematic line-crossing. In many ways it was a bit like reading about a cult.

But red flags aside, it was interesting to see the e

When I started reading Group I assumed it was fiction. Imagine my surprise and awe when 1/4 way in I realised it is a memoir. This is a layered account of Christie Tate's all out efforts to create meaningful relationships in her own life. She came to her first group, having made quite clear to the therapist that she wanted to end her life, and if group therapy didn't work within five years, she would do so. So she raged, loved and crumpled at rejection - all witnessed and supported by her group

Loved this memoir!! So brutally honest and refreshing. Also very funny! I laughed out loud in parts :) Group is all about the authors journey through years of group therapy with a bunch of very unique individuals and a quirky therapist. I just fell love with everyone by the end of the book and kind of wanted to go to Group myself :)

Personally I had a hard time finishing this book .I did not care for the way the the therapy Dr led this group or much of the advise given . I am thankful for the oppotunity I had to read this book, however this was a book I did not personally enjoy.
I received this book as a giveaway on Good Reads. I am glad the author received so meny 5 star reviews as it makes me know meny meny people loved and learned from the path this particular therapy group went through. Thank you .

This book is all kinds of ridiculous! I honestly don’t think I’d believe half the stuff Christie did or heard or saw in group therapy if I wasn’t in therapy myself.

Christie particular mental illnesses are addressed not just in the therapy setting but in flashbacks that add to the memoir quality of the book.

My only qualm was the what felt unnecessary obsession with everything sex. I feel like I get that enough on TV and movies and now books. It just felt like a lot, even though I know it was on

I received this book from the giveaway. This was an interesting ride. I enjoy memoirs and I enjoy books about therapy but this one wasn't my style. I'm not sure for whom this book was written. Christie Tate gets very real and honest and explicit about her past and relationships. I felt it was a little heavy on sex and, as almost everyone has mentioned, the therapist in this book raises some alarms. This is why I am only giving three stars: I doubt most people can relate to Christie's experience
Read July 2020
I won this book on Goodreads. Unfortunately I didn't like the style of writing and could not finish the book.

Mommy blogger Christie Tate (aka Outlaw Mama) recounts her earlier years in her debut memoir, GROUP.

On the day that she is named top of her class in law school, Christie wants to die. Thoughts of self-harm have been floating in her head for some time. She can’t form a lasting romantic relationship or any type of personal connection. She can talk about football and the weather with her family, but nothing more substantial. She fills this void in her life by immersing herself in her work. She also

I love books about psychology and memoirs, and this book combined that. I was really amazed that the author was so good-looking, because the way she described herself, I had the image of a really fat woman with enormous breasts. I guess that may say something about her self-image. I've never been a fan of group therapy, since it means that the therapist's attention is divided among all the members of the group, and in most groups you have ignorant or naive people spouting their opinions about ot

Purchased this book rather than wait for a library copy as I usually find Reese’s Book Club picks to be good and thought it might rank up there with Lori Gottlieb’s “Maybe You Should Talk to Someone”. I was thoroughly disappointed and rest assured “Group” doesn’t compare at all to Gottlieb’s masterpiece. Firstly, as a non-fiction memoir of sorts by author Christie Tate it frightens me terribly of how she has relied/ relies on her psychotherapist and the various ( and there are many ) therapy gro

This memoir is one working professionals account of her personal experience seeking help with intimacy, self-harm, and an eating disorder with group therapy in the early 2000s. If I had to give this a rating I would say 3 STARS out of 5.

I have extreme interest in the mental health field and thus based my decision to read this memoir on the fact it is author Christie Tates personal account of her many years in group therapy. Having earned my degree in psychological sciences I feel inclined to que

In this memoir we experience an unusual version of group therapy through the experiences of Christie.
Christie is suffering from passive suicidal ideation and has a history of eating disorders.
Her key issue seems to be “stuckness” an emotional inability to attach, or form an egalitarian relationship with a future male partner.
Her initial and ongoing wish when seeking therapy is to score her slippery heart, to be able to find love and be truly loved in return.
To find a love that sticks, and doesn

In this memoir we experience an unusual version of group therapy through the experiences of Christie.
Christie is suffering from passive suicidal ideation and has a history of eating disorders.
Her key issue seems to be “stuckness” an emotional inability to attach, or form an egalitarian relationship with a future male partner.
Her initial and ongoing wish when seeking therapy is to score her slippery heart, to be able to find love and be truly loved in return.
To find a love that sticks, and doesn

“If we can share our story with someone who responds with empathy and understanding, shame can’t survive.” Brené Brown

Many of us in our 40’s, myself and @christieotate, the author of Group, included, didn’t grown up with the resources of Brené Brown readily available. In an interview, I cringed when I heard someone ask Tate if she was ashamed that her secrets were out there for all to read. Those of us doing the work of therapy and trying to heal know that sharing our truth and surviving it isn’

I was so excited to read and love this book but am left feeling really disappointed and concerned.
If this was a piece of fiction then yes, it would be a good book. But as non fiction? No. Definitely not. The ‘therapy’ that took place in this book was not ethically sound, it was more like a cult than group therapy.
Dr Rosen, the therapist in this book, has a very questionable counselling practise which I feel is not ethical at all. It feels more like a power trip and throughout the book it seems

Christie Tate was a successful law school student and recovering bulimic who started attending therapy wanting to have more intimate connections, specifically a romantic relationship, in her life. My struggle at formulating that first sentence encapsulates my primary criticism of the book: it's not very clear what the problem was.

Her writing is so candid, and as she learns in group therapy to share everything because the holding of secrets is the carrying of shame, the reader gets to live insid

I love reading books about therapy. Maybe You Should Talk to Someone was one of my favorite books last year and I recently reviewed Good Morning, Monster which I also thought was riveting. Both of those were written by therapists about their experiences helping patients through various issues. Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Helped Save My Life by Christie Tate is a memoir about her years in group therapy and this new perspective sucked me right in.

Christie is at the top of he

I really enjoyed this book, but it may not be for everyone. Christie Tate wrote a memoir about her time as a law student/young lawyer in Chicago when she was having suicidal thoughts, recovering from bulimia, and struggling to build close relationships. She seeks treatment in group therapy, which is led by Dr. Rosen. During these group meetings members cannot hold anything back -- no secrets whatsoever -- and the groups function like small families where the members care about each other, but fr

(2.5 stars rounded up)

Christie Tate is a successful Chicago lawyer who has the brain and the skills to thrive in the professional world. Behind her professional persona is a side to her that is struggling immensely. Christie is a recovering bulimic, and after completing a 12-step program, she continues to be extremely unhappy. She is tired of feeling alone and miserable. A friend suggests group therapy, and though it is way out of her comfort zone, she's desperate to feel better. Group therapy pushes Christie to conf

We meet Christie as she aimlessly drives around in her car, wishing that she were dead. Christie is a promising law student turning lawyer. She is also in recovery from an eating disorder, insecure, anxiety ridden, lonely and a total mess. Her friend suggests that she embark on a journey of group therapy, and she does. This was so unexpected - I picked it up and ripped through it in two days, which I have not done to a book in ages.
Christie's story is relatable especially in light of the (enforced) isolation many of us have been in to one degree or another. On the the surface she is going brilliantly, top of her law school class with a promising career ahead of her. Inside she is feeling so disconnected from people and herself, she finds herself wishing someone would shoot her.

Enter Dr Rosen and his groups.

I enjoyed reading this book and learning about group therapy. As someone who has been in traditional individual therapy before, I have always been curious about group therapy and it was interesting to get a first hand perspective from someone who has now been in "group" for years. I can see both pros and cons to group therapy but it was clear to me that for some therapy patients it is a lifesaver.

This was a book that was terrifying and harrowing, and while I knew a fair amount about white supremacist movements online (as well as misogynistic movements like incels, though the overlap is definitely there), Lavin really peels back the nitty gritty of the awfulness. She has well researched information, as well as primary sources given that she basically went full on undercover to get close to these groups in their online forum

Lavin is every skinhead's worst nightmare: a loud and unapologetic Jewish woman, funny, smart, and profoundly anti-racist, with the journalistic chops to expose the tactics and landscape of online hatemongers.



Can't wait for this.

Sufferer of Trump derangement syndrome. Apparently there wasn’t enough information to write a book based solely on white supremacy so she had to expand the net to include four other groups. Blames far-right for hatred and violence while claiming anti fascists are completely innocent and victims (when they loot and burn buildings it is the store owners fault for having the store where they are rioting). The numbers she provides are intentionally exaggerated without explanation to use for fear mon

Quick, bold and somewhat terrifying! People who are Extremely Online might not be surprised by some of what thy read here (I think Gamergate left mental scars on us all), but Levin stares at the roiling nightmarish underside of the internet of white supremacy and exposes it for the bizarrely stupid and dangerous thing that it is. I laughed at some of these people while reading, but it was with a shiver down my spine -- the people that Levin learns about may be foolish and delusional but they are

Illuminating, sometimes amusing, and often disturbing – Lavin is a compelling narrator whose personal principles anchor the narrative even as it descends into some very dark places. Each case study of a different dark corner of the internet shines a light on extremism and provides critical context for anyone seeking to understand (and counter) contemporary white supremacist networks.

CULTURE WARLORDS: MY JOURNEY INTO THE DARK WEB OF WHITE SUPREMACY by Talia Lavin should win all the relevant awards. as an investigative journalist & writer, the author sacrificed her peace of mind & sense of security to infiltrate the alt-right spaces of the Internet. through her own experiences strengthened w/ additional research, she reveals that the alt-right monsters who plan violence & spew hatred are real people. although we might think that we know this already, we really learn who these

Outspoken Jewish female journalist Talia Lavin has endured widespread attacks from members of the alt-right and related supremacist movements, including rape threats and death threats, both for being who she is and for daring to report on their organizing. In this book, she goes even further, presenting what she has learned by entering their online networks under pseudonym and observing as they talk amongst themselves. To some extent, the result is a wry portrait of the author catfishing people

A VITAL book that everyone must read. Talia Lavin is an absolute superstar - both for her skill as a writer and for her fearlessness in gathering research for this book. I appreciate her skill for breaking difficult concepts down and putting everything neatly in context, starting with an intro to the history of hate and drawing a throughline to the current state of extremism. Racism, antisemitism, and misogyny are presented here as entwined issues that we must overcome together, not singular pro

This was the single most difficult book for me to finish this year. The author delves deep into the hate filled online world of white supremacy. She frequently brings up that she is Jewish and how people in these online groups are, directly or indirectly, threatening her, her family, and peoples she cares about. It isn't difficult to see my own family and the people I care about reflected there. I took this book maybe too personally.

The threat of violence from groups like these are very real, an

Talia Lavin is really a hero. Who else wants to enter the underworld of white supremacists and women haters to find out what makes them tick, who they are, where they are and what we can do about them? It isn’t easy and I give her a million kudos for even attempting it. She has brought serious attention on herself and as a Jew and a woman she is placing herself in harm’s way. So Talia be careful!!!! Talia is funny, self-deprecating and totally candid. Her personality shines through the book. Whi
I encourage people with any level of ambivalence towards "President" Trump and his ilk to read this and understand the evil they find unobjectionable.

Culture Warlords: My Journey Into the Dark Web of White Supremacy by Talia Lavin is a disturbing and eye-opening book that everyone needs to read. I don't care where you are on the political spectrum, you need to know what is bubbling under the surface and then make an informed decision about where you stand.

The majority of the book presents Lavin's research and interactions, undercover, on many of the sites where these people congregate to spew their filth. Early in the book you'll read about h

This was a complex read that often required me to put the book down and reflect on what I had just learned. This is, of course, the highest possible praise I can offer a non-fiction work that takes on the complicated world of organized hate. Even as someone who tries very hard to keep up on all the ways that misogyny, antisemitism, racism and white-supremacy have roots in American culture and politics, this was an eye-opener on many levels.

Levin blends important historical events and trends with

This book is essentially an ethnographic study of racial hate groups—anti-Semites, white supremacists, incels, and other assorted whack jobs. The author, a female Jewish journalist, infiltrates these groups by joining them online, disguising herself as one of them. What she finds is a barrage of hateful invectives, sharing of pictures with violent expressions such as lynchings, declarations of intent to commit violence, and dreams of world domination with the elimination or oppression of non-whi

Note Yeah Nah Pasaran! #040 w Talia Lavin on Culture Warlords : October 15, 2020

On Yeah Nah, we talk to Talia Lavin [Twitter]: writer, podcaster and author of Culture Warlords: My Journey Into the Dark Web of White Supremacy (Hachette, 2020):

Talia Lavin is every fascist’s worst nightmare: a loud and unapologetic young Jewish woman, with the online investigative know-how to expose the tactics and ideologies of online hatemongers. Outspoken and uncompromising, Lavin’s debut uncovers the hidden cor

Talia Lavin manages to make some of the most repugnant aspects of society absolutely fascinating to read about in Culture Warlords. This on its own is a major accomplishment, but when you combine it with all the historical and modern information about white supremacists, incels, and fascists, this book becomes a must read for everyone who wants to build a more just and equal world. After all, how can we improve things if we don’t have a good understanding of those who want to see the world burn?

Talia Lavin is a brave woman. She immerses herself in white supremacist discussion boards and blogs to reveal the white supremacist worldview in its natural habitat. As a leftist journalist who is an outspoken Jewish feminist, she knows going in this will be difficult; she's faced hostility and threats for years based on her reporting. The book is a mixture of historical diving into the mutations of anti-Semitism and white supremacy, and recounting of her experiences passing as a white supremaci

I went into this hoping to understand the white supremacist psyche, the detailed steps to radicalization that the web accelerates, snd the means with which organized hate turns opinion into violence, and finances violent campaigns. Generally a clearer view into the vulnerabilities that underly white supremacists. What I took from Talia’s work was, for lack of a better word, a rant of her experiences when infiltrating white supremacist channels, and surface level observations of their online acti

Culture Warlords is a highly uncomfortable - but necessary - read. Talia Lavin investigates the deplorable world of white supremacy via forums, chatrooms and dating sites in order to attempt to understand why these people behave they do, with the ultimate aim of exposing them.

As much as I was aware of these groups, I wasn't fully aware of the vulgarity of their beliefs and was appalled at the casual way such hatred and vitriol was discussed. Lavin explains the historical significance of these gr

There was a certain preparedness I thought I had before being shown the inner workings of these online white supremacist subcultures; that being said, the reveal is never without shock value, like upturning a rock you know will have grubs and centipedes underneath, but being wholly unable to contain a scream. Talia Levin’s infiltration of these taboo, yet disgustingly popular and interconnected spaces, left me wondering two things: how and why did this happen? I think Levin does a great job at o

Oh, boy. This book gives me some PTSD. As a former community manager in another life, I dealt with some of the elements that Talia mentions in this book on a daily basis.

In Talia's case, I can't imagine what it's like to have so much hate and harm wished upon you and kudos to her for wanting to expose members of these groups where possible. One passage she had at the beginning of the book highlighted why we need to shut down any talk of white supremacy, wherever it happens:

“But the effect of the

Forget other horror novels...this is the top pick for a terrifying Halloween 2020 read.

Culture Warlords is a deep dive into the world of white supremacy by self-described Jewish "loudmouth" Talia Lavin, who uses a variety of methods including catfishing and false histories to break into dark web forums and chatrooms in order to document and expose the fascist and racist world of the alt-right. Each chapter is separated into a different "theme" of alt-right hatred, such as antisemitism, antifemi

I found this book to be powerful and incredibly necessary. Grounded as it is in Talia’s own experiences as a Jewish woman, the book as a whole does an excellent job of deconstructing white supremacy and showcasing exactly who stands to be harmed by it. All in all, I would recommend the book.
Talia’s writing style is at its best halfway through. Chapters 1-3 felt so scholarly they were stifling. I would go so far as to call chapter 3 a true slog, but her writing picks up as she delves further into

This was my first time reading anything from Talia Lavin, and this was a really great book. As much as people like to talk about "snowflakes" and SJWs, the incel and white supremacy movement online is real, and it's scary stuff. Personally, I grew up online and as a gamer, and I've known many of these types of guys, and I don't know how many mass shootings we need to witness before people take this issue of domestic terrorism seriously. 

I recently started following Talia on Twitter, and although

This book is a fascinating and terrifying look into the world of white supremacists, incels, and other hate groups. The author, Talia Lavin, went underground to "catfish" some of these men in online forums where they espouse their racist, anti-Semitic, and misogynous views. She weaves in histories of right-wing hate groups and their leaders in the USA and around the world. It's chilling to read how a small but wide group of demented racists believe terrorists such as Dylan Roof and Brenton Tarra

Really well-written and passionate and full of really interesting firsthand accounts of undercover internet encounters and personal experience with being a Jewish woman online. It functions sort of like a modern primer for racist hate groups online and divides them into sub-categories, like incels, Proud Boys, Neo-Nazis, and extreme religious groups. I think the most effective portions were the direct reports of her undercover interactions online - she poses as a woman in white supremacist datin

Not for the faint of heart, this is the "Black Like Me" of the white supremacist world. Lavin traces the lineage back to Dark Ages European anti-Semitism, the hatred that seems never to die, though its American iteration includes many more groups than Jews. You realize that the topics of invented fears have hardly changed over the centuries, so we who have been waiting and waiting for all the fringe people to get on out of the White House and back under their rocks may be waiting all our lives.

Talia Lavin’s “Culture Warlords” is a peek at what’s been festering under the surface of Western politics for far too long, white supremacy. From a brief foundational history of white supremacist thought and violence, Lavin lights a path to the obscured online refuge of contemporary white supremacists. Relating stories from militant Telegram chats, antifascist catfishing, incel forums, and Pagan vs. Christian fundraiser rumbles “Culture Warlords” casts a wide net and reels in plenty to show for

It's not a book I enjoyed because its not a book to be enjoyed. Reading about neo-Nazis and the KKK and the alt-right is aggravating. Seeing the slurs of every racial and sexual component is unnerving.

Lavin goes into painstaking detail about the ins and outs of some of these messaging boards. Before reading this book i was not aware of her notoriety but her writing, with almost nonchalance, about the rape and death threats she gets is abhorrent.

On a personal note:

Reading this made me realized ho

3.5 Stars.

The topic of this book is timely and important. We should all be much more aware of what's happening in the darker corners of the internet and the impact hate has on our society and politics.

The book itself was certainly riveting—it was hard to stop reading because what Lavin documents is so horrifying. Lavin's writing style is engaging and entertaining. But it was hard not to feel like the book was missing something. The chapters bled together, and the ending, which is devoted to An

This is a hard book to review, especially at 11:00 on election night when I finished it. I think the press on it was misleading; while the author does detail some of her adventures undercover in contact with the alt right that does not really seem to be the thrust of the book. The narrative drifts, and if you are too online (like the reviewer) you probably know some, if not most of this. What this book is is an unsparing labor in the most essential way. It mercilessly catalogs who we are failing

While I can't say I was surprised by this book, I was definitely shocked and appalled. Not because of Talia Lavin's smart and thoughtful writing, but because of the behavior of the people and organizations she exposes here. This book overturns the rocks and logs of American (and world) society, finding the dirt of hate that lies beneath. Lavin posed as a Nazi sympathizer on several different social media sites, including a dating site specifically for people who espouse hate. She has endured cou

A short but good read/listen. The author gives an insight into online culture from white supremacy to incels and clearly shows how different forms of hate like racism and misogyny are often intertwined.

It loses steam towards the end, especially if you’re a very online™️ person who is already familiar with a lot of the antifa discourse on Twitter, but for the first 7 hours of listening I couldn’t put it down.

If you’re looking for a very “in-depth” book, this might not be for you. But if you wan

The rise of far right groups seemingly the world over is a highly troubling phenomenon so trying to understand them better is a worthwhile endeavor. Tanya Levin provides an often breezy (if that can be used on such a topic) journey through her dealings with some of these figures, almost solely online and in various layers of subterfuge. Often posing as a would-be paramour on far right dating sites (apparently these exist) she relays her experience with these fringe figures. After finishing the b

It feels wrong to be at all critical of a book about the history of white supremacy and exposing those who are rabidly anti-semitic/racist/homophobic/transphobic. The parts about Lavin infiltrating and gathering information behind web-based enemy lines were far more powerful to me than the rather dense and sometimes repetitive historical context, though I know that is important to understand. I’m grateful to her and not least because I can only imagine how horrific it was to read/see/hear and ab

With recounts and incidents that are still so fresh on the minds of most Americans this book helps to navigate the behind the scenes look at the Alt-right and Neo-fascist rhetoric that cause so much division on our social and political platforms. This gives context behind the brash behavior of alt-right online trolls and the political pundits on Fox news. From the moment I begin reading this book it was next to impossible to set it down. From first hand accounts to shocking stories of catfishing

Culture Warlords is a powerful and harrowing journey into the minds of those filled with hate. It's a unique perspective on their lives and how they function and thrive in our world. As unpleasant as it is, it's essential to recognize and oppose the white supremacy around us. Ms Lavin gives us all a starting point to understand who we are and what we're fighting against, and that our most powerful weapons are knowledge and love for our communities.

Language: Moderate (multiple racial, religious,

This book is brilliant & this book is horrifying. It is a scathing social commentary, that identifies the uncomfortable reality that Fascism is alive and well here.. but it’s also a darkly hilarious account of the author’s encounters with ridiculous humans, with frightening beliefs. Her narrative is also compassionate, and provides context & relevant sources. This was an outstanding work of creative, modern, brave journalism!

⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️

Thank you NetGalley & Hachette books for this e-ARC!

Gets a bit repetitive, but still a solid look at white supremacy and all the gross people involved.

Personally, I thought the first half of the “Operation Ashlynn” chapter was the best part of the book. Reading about a whites only dating site and the people who populate it was both hilarious and depressing.

Thank god for the humor in this book, because there is some heavy stuff in this. The incel chapter alone took me a while to get through because it was so dark, even though I know what incels a

I feel like it was a little bit too all over the place. Sometimes it felt like there was no direction? I think some who is more unaware of the extent of online extremism might gain more from the book than i did as someone who is Very Online. However I think I would recommend Antisocial by Andrew Marantz over this one to someone looking to learn more. I was really looking forward to this book so I’m a little sad I didn’t enjoy (well, as much as one can “enjoy” a book about political extremism) re

I follow the author on Twitter, so I was excited to recieve this as a giveaway.

In this book, Talia delves into the world of white supremecy, both openly (showing up at an alt-right youtube convention) and in secret (infiltrating various
hate group chat rooms).

Its informative and enjoyable (as much as a book about antisemitism/white supremecy can be) My only complaint is the flow of the book. Its slightly disjointed between chapters, but thats about it.

I definitely recommend it. To clear things up, however, I would say that the book is more of a contemporary history of the far right than what the media is advertising it as, as tales of catfishing fascists.

It misses the fifth star because I think it could have been tighter with some more editing and perhaps another chapter or two :/.

The chapter on Charlottesville made me nostalgic for my once upon a time home.

A generic enunciation of association, yes,
no matter, this is the way of robotic peacemakers,
Martin Luther King Jr. had, all kinds and ways,
a "turn the other cheek" Jesus Complex.

Me? I don't talk, I walk, I do:

If that Cross is lawn burning,
I put it out,
if that Klansman knifes me,
I pull it out,
if I'm that me,
I'm that forever.

Chris Roberts, Patron Saint to the Actionable Beings

This book promises to explore a topic of genuine concern in the USA right now and just simply fails to come even close. The first few pages of most of the chapters are interesting when the author actually writes about her personal experiences delving into various organizations ... but in EVERY case, she then rambles off on tangents that consist of nothing more than repeating news stories previously widely reported.

So much potential ...

Such a waste of time!!!

Recommended for all but especially women. The author goes underground to on the Dark Web to interact anonymously with White Supremacists. I had no idea how many White Supremacists group there are online and who they represent. Going underground as both a woman and a man using false identities. As a Jew I feel very frightening for the future and Americans because we choose to stay ignorant about the bottom up self destructive.

I received a copy of this book from Netgalley and Hachette Books.

Wow. This book is not for the faint of heart. It honestly took me forever to get through it because o lot of the things discussed are pretty revolting.

Talia takes us through the Disturbed world of white supremacy online. It's nasty stuff and I'm so grateful for Lavin for putting in the work.

Talia is an incredibly brave woman who also has a very, very enjoyable reading voice. I recommend the audible recording cause she does it herself! Some of this information wasn’t new (though it was a more in-depth dive into hate) but it absolutely nailed white supremacist strategy online and the men behind it (and the more quiet but no less vitriolic white supremacist women)

I'm fully aware of antisemitism, racism, and sexism in America and none of the people or groups Levin discussed were new to me (Soph, Proud Boys, incels, white nationalists/supremacists, Christian extremists, red pillers, etc.), but good God they are disgusting. This was a hard read, but also hard to put down and I wish I could certain people I know to read and digest it.

This book was an excellent, well-researched dive into the historical and current culture and making of white supremacist movements, both online and off. I deeply admire Talia's dedication to the work, oftentimes at great risk to personal wellbeing, and have come away from reading this with an even greater belief that those in power (elected and unelected) have a massive amount of reckoning to do.

Readable & compelling tale of infiltrating online white supremacist communities. I felt it was a bit surface level and read a bit like a bunch of blog posts stapled together, but an interesting read. Enjoyed the moments of dark humour especially. (Eg an adultery scandal in a neo nazi group being referred to as the Night of the Wrong Wives)

It was pretty interesting but the author repeated explanations of things as if she hadn't already defined them previously in the book. Also tbh I know she's an author who's written for magazines and other publications but I actually thought her writing was subpar. The subject was very interesting.

Cultural Warlords excels when Lavin's exploration into these dark enclaves of depravity is showcased. Her first hand accounts are spine-chilling. I was also pleasantly surprised on how optimistic the book ended. Definitely worth a read.

Pairs well with the No Compromise podcast from NPR. A look inside online hate communities, but also a discussion on the alt-right movement and how to defeat it. Really not looking forward to our post-election america.

Masterful

This is beautifully written book about the horrific but all too present realities of organized hate. I am in awe of the author, and hope that everyone that can read, reads this.

SUCH a good book. I've never read from the perspective of a modern-day leftist and hearing her explain the leftist/anti-fascist movement was fascinating and a really important thing to read. Even if you don't identify as liberal/left, this is still a really important book to read.

“[T]he best weapon against hate, they say, is love. Not the false love of airy social proclamations, or the acquisitive love of new desire, but a fierce, abiding love.”

ush se me hace un must-read para cualquiera que le preocupe esto.

It was alright. Sorta disjointed, and a bit repetitive at points. A decent primer for someone unfamiliar with this world I suppose, but there are better organized and more informative books out there on the general subject.

I essentially agree with everything the author writes, but the book was just meh. It didn't feel organized around anything in particular, was fairly repetitive, and never really built to a particular point. Wanted this to be more than it was!

I have such a deep respect for Lavin and the work she does. I loved whenever she wrote about her activist work. Sadly I didn't think the more general stuff was exceedingly well done (but that might be because I have read too much work about the new or alt-right already).

Worst book I read in a very long time. It seems like a fictional book sort of like a fantasy of what this author thinks or assumes white supremacists are. Even had it fact checked. Sadly almost no real facts.

This is an excellent historical review of the actual alt-right movement taking place all over the world, fueled by have and reminescent anti-semitism. Helps understanding a lot on the differents forms it takes.

Good overview of the current white supremacy movement. I enjoyed Lavin's writing but had to take breaks from reading about some of the hateful rhetoric of the people she profiles. I am amazed at the writers' strength in venturing into the online world (and in person world) of white supremacy.

Sorry but.... I didn’t like this book. It got better near the end, but didn’t give me a lot to work with. Sorry to this author because it seems like she really went through a lot to write it, but unfortunately I would recommend the NYT podcast Rabbit Hole over this book. 🙊🤷🏻‍♀️

Read this book now!

A well written, engaging peek behind the hate filled curtain of the alt-right and incel communities. I highly recommend it.
Every single person needs to read this. I want to start catfishing nazis right now.
this book is terrifying and everyone should read it

Depressing

A depressing look at how easily racism is cultivated online, and the brave people who fight it. Remember to vote.
Terrifying, concise and enlightening look at modern white supremacy on the internet. So good I'm listening to it twice in 24 hours. We are lucky to have writers as brave as Lavin.
Great book, well-written, informative.
Chilling.
This book when paired with Laura Bate’s book ‘Men who hate women’ gives a good overview of the extremist nature of online hate that is seeping into real life.

The content was very good, but I did not enjoy it as an audiobook.
A bit repetitive at time. Extremely instructive and quietly terrifying. Lavin's voice is awesome.

A line that stuck with me, among many:

I consider myself an antifascist because I’ve met antifascists, and I’ve met fascists, and I know which I prefer.
Very heavy, informative & the USA is full of creepy dudes.

Fine look at the white supremacists and their organized hate groups. The author isn't afraid to show her anger and disgust with these groups and refuses to take a middle path trying to find any good in a group of people who have devoted themselves to hating anyone different than themselves. Important reading especially in today's climate. This book was received as a Goodreads giveaway.

This was such a compelling and horrifying read. While I obviously knew that White Supremacy was a thing, I had no idea about the levels it goes to. White Supremacist dating sites?! Who knew?

I found parts of it quite difficult to read - the levels of hate that spill out from the boards Talia Lavin infiltrates is just awful. I honestly don't know how she managed to spend enough time reading them and participating in order to get enough material for this book.

user_name: Nenia ✨️ Socially Awkward Trash Panda ✨️ Campbell

review_text:
Wow. Am I ever thankful that I don't have vagina problems. I very much rather live with my few kill-me-now migraines a month, than the constant pain and torture that Parker lives with.
I can't express how impressed I am with Lara Parker and her willingness to put everything out there in the hopes of getting people to talk about topics that are still considered taboo by many. I can't believe how dismissive medical professionals were of her pain, but I can also totally believe that because I've als

When life for the entire universe and planet turns on its end and like everyone else you "have nothing to do" while your place of work is closed and you are in #COVID19 #socialisolation, superspeed readers like me can read 250+ pages/hour, so yes, I have read the book … and many more today. (I have played a zillion games of scrabble, done a zillion crosswords and I AM BORED!!!)

I requested and received a temporary digital Advance Reader Copy of this book from #NetGalley, the publisher and the aut

I received an eARC from Netgalley and St. Martin's Press in exchange for my honest review.

CW: all things medical, death of a friend

I laughed, I cried, I felt so incredibly seen. I would recommend this book to literally everyone because you either have a chronic illness and can relate to so much of Lara's words, or you don't but you should read this so you can be aware of what folks experience on a daily basis.

AVAILABLE NOW!!!

I have followed Lara Parker on Buzzfeed for awhile now. She was one of the only voices I was readily able to access when I received my very own Endometriosis diagnosis. I have so much respect for the way she showed up and offered her own life experience with vagina problems. I know I am not alone when I say that reading her articles made me feel less isolated in a time when isolation and I were very familiar with each other. At the time of my diagnosis, there were no other voices

When I saw this book on NetGally I got super excited! dealing with endo myself it's almost comforting to read that I'm not alone with my chronic pain.
Lara takes you on a journey of her struggles with Vagina Problems throughout her years, the endless amount of doctors appointments and days in bed. Finding a doctor to help with any sort of Vagina Problems is definitely a struggle, thinking you're going crazy while dealing with all the pain and stress is a true bummer. Vagina Problems is the real story of Lara Parker, a life that has been surrounded by pain and Doctors who kept telling her lies and misguided her on what to do or how to feel better if that's something that actually exists.

Vagina Problems, a very eye-opener book, not only do we see ourselves in every page and story Lara wrote about, but also we identify so much on how usually Doctors don't have any clue about our bodies, the female body, and how they usually throw diagnoses at us that are so wro

I absolutely love that Lara was willing to share her story in such intimate detail - for the sake of educating people about these diseases, and also to remind those 1 in 10 women dealing with endo that they aren't alone. It's so important to continue to rally for women's health reform. The lack of medical research specifically tailored for women's bodies is criminal. Her story perfectly details how the system let her down again and again - despite all the advantages she has with access to care,

An honest reflection on the author's journey through years of horrific pain, finally diagnosed, initial relief, and crashing reality as she grapples with several compounding "unfixable" chronic pain conditions. Her obsession with attempted prevention rang very true to my own after my initial Vagina Problem diagnosis. Parker weaves in hopeful and earnest prose without getting Pollyanna or despondent. Reading about her reworking of relationship and sexual expectations helped me release some unhelp

This is a book about pain—chronic, life-altering pain that affects 10 percent of all women. To be clear, this is not a medical study of endometriosis (or the myriad other diseases that affect women along with it), but is rather one woman’s experiences living with it. It’s both heart-breaking and inspiring. While I read this book because I wanted to know more about how endometriosis was affecting a friend of mine (chances are, if you don’t suffer from it, you know at least one person who does), I

There was so much that this book COULD have done to highlight the many issues that women face, especially when it comes to vagina problems. I was looking forward to this book as an informative non-fiction read that uses statistics and specific diagnoses that women receive. 

Rather than being informative though, this book read as a long complaint of chronic pain. I almost feel that a two-star rating is generous, but Lara Parker has obviously helped many people (women especially) by talking about t

As someone with a recent diagnosis of endometriosis, dysmenorrhea, pelvic floor dysfunction, and dyspareunia but a sufferer for 15 years, this book hit so close to home. I want everyone around me to have a copy so they can understand what it is I go through. I shared so many of the same struggles as Lara and like she said, this diagnosis can be so isolating. Lara is breaking down that “shh, you can’t talk about!” barrier and gosh, it felt good. I can’t recommend this book enough. Whether you’re

I really learned so much in this book. Basically this is a real education in endometriosis. First of all I thought I knew about it, well, I did not. This book at times can really be complaining from the author point of view in regards to how much pain she is in and the episodes that she goes through to truly find out what is wrong with her. However, I cannot begin to imagine truly what it felt like to be in her shoes. Was just thinking maybe some resources or something to help those that are goi

If you are a person with a vagina you should be reading this book. Modern medicine doesn’t include or treat women in a way that benefits our health. Being able to read an entire book dedicated to the vagina was truly an experience I deserved before I was 31 years old, but here we are. This book was well done and I highly recommend.
I was really looking forward to this, but it was incredibly repetitive and very 'woe is me.' Also strangely lacking in informative and statistical details?

Repetitive and not really all that informative🤔

I had hoped to learn something from Lara Parker's book that could help me understand how to handle some of the pain issues I've been facing for a few years. I did not find any answers here, and I found the narrative overly repetitive, depressing, and pretty well summed up in a few lines.

-Yes, she has pain that took a long time to diagnose and will not go away.
-No, she is not less worthy of love because of her pain.

As someone who has never shied away from calling it like it is—no matter what “it” is—Lara Parker’s Vagina Problems caught my attention instantly. It’s a catchy title, to be sure, but as I am someone with vagina problems, I wondered how Parker’s story and mine might be alike.
A blunt memoir of the harrowing journey to receive adequate medical care as well as an explanation for health issues spanning n

This isn't a book that only "people with vagina problems" should read—but everyone, especially men who oftentimes don't empathize with the pain women experience. Lara writes in a way that is conversational yet honest and vulnerable, as if you've sat down to have a chat with your very good friend. She speaks truthfully about her diagnosis and of the enormous flaws in the medical industry. Chronicling her experience with living with these conditions, Lara openly talks about her sex and dating life

So interesting...so informative...completely relatable.

Vagina Problems by Lara Parker brings light to SO MANY taboo topics having to do with women’s bodies, their vagina specifically. Society has decided for us that talking about sex and vaginas and the health of our vaginas is off the table. Parker touches on the problem with our healthcare system and how they've failed women's health. She discusses the nitty-gritty details about how vaginal pain causes both physical and mental discomfort for so man

I have Vagina Problems. Ever since my first period, I struggled with the unbearable pain associated with my period, missing school because of it. I went to various Gynaecologist with the belief that I could have endometriosis, many of these doctors brushed it off and put me on the pill. I struggled with my period for 9 more years before I met a gynecologist who listened and told me it was highly probable that I have endometriosis and that we should treat it as such.

Vagina Problems by Lara Parker - 4/5 stars

Trigger Warnings: Descriptions of pain, vomit, gaslighting (from doctors and personal relationships)

I received a free copy of this novel through NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

I have followed Lara Parker and her journey with her health and her life through social media for a couple of years now. Parker has always been inspiring and honest and watching her try her best always pushed me to do the same. When I found out that she had written a bo

Lara Parker's "Vagina Problems" is about the health problems she has suffered since first getting her period as a young woman. She discusses her struggles with endometriosis, vulvodynia, bladder pain, and more, as well as the devastating effects these conditions have on her mental health, sex life, relationships, career, and daily life. I hesitate to call this a memoir, since we learn only a handful of details about her family, upbringing, job, etc. Instead, each chapter explores different topic

I sincerely hope that anyone who ever experiences any sort of vagina problem finds this book, or at the very least, a standalone article by Lara Parker talking about her experiences with various vagina problem. This is such an important issue that effects SO MANY WOMEN, and we never really talk about it. As someone who is pretty sure they have an undiagnosed vagina problem, I'm so glad I found this book and have friends I can openly and honestly talk to.

In VAGINA PROBLEMS, the author very hones

The aptly titled Vagina Problems is Lara’s story of resiliency, self-advocacy and education for the masses. As readers we are given a front row seat to what felt like raw and traumatic experiences at the hands of doctors that weren’t willing or able (through their own fault) to help her and wrote her off as a “hypochondriac”. Lara has well... Vagina Problems as she refers to them but I’m sure the one your heard is endometriosis. One in ten women have this disease, thank you Lara for that statist

Vagina Problems chronicles one women's current (the trials are not over) life with chronic pain. If you don't have endometriosis, Parker gives you a look inside all the decisions one has to make as someone with an invisible chronic illness:

"Living with chronic pain feels like you're in a constant battle. You are never able to put down your weapons and just relax. You have to be persistently on alert. Every decision I make is somehow impacted by my illnesses." (74)

I haven't heard of the author before, so I wasn't familiar with her previous writing on the topic of her health. I was eager to read this book - planned to buy a copy, if I wasn't awarded an ARC of it - because there seem to be few books written for women's health issues that are up to date and actually talk about what it's like to experience "something wrong" but not be able t

I picked this up at the library (where I work :) ) hoping to connect to someone else who has vagina problems (I don't have endo, but I do have debilitating fibroids, painful sex, debilitating periods) but my pain is nowhere on the level that Lara's is, and my heart goes out to her, because I can't even imagine (just like no one knows the pain that I have - right?). But I was also turned off a bit reading this book because it was repetitive chapter-to-chapter, but I guess if it was a memoir she m

If you have endo or one of the other many issues Lara has you will probably like this book. If you don't I can see why you wouldn't enjoy it. Of course she could have mentioned a lot more about those specific diagnosis's but this is her 1st book. I personally found it extremely relatable and cried by pg 2. I have also been following her from Buzzfeed and her other social media platforms for awhile. So I'm a follower and maybe more used to her language. Sad that people found it "complaining". Sur

A missed opportunity.

As someone with “vagina problems”, I looked forward to hearing another woman’s story on coming to understand and treat endometriosis and similar pelvic pain disorders. At many points in the story, I found myself yelling, “YEP! Exactly!”

With that said, I feel like there was a lot of extraneous material (likely to hit the publisher’s page minimum), so I found myself skipping ahead. I believe this book would have benefited from being a collection of short stories from many wo

Certain topics don’t get enough air time because they’re considered taboo. How dare we speak of our ailments if they have anything to do with our reproductive organs and yet everyone feels the need have a say if given half the chance. We have to start discussing these issues in order to normalize them with the intention to get better care and more resources if we need them.
