I read this book because I have Vagina Problems.

As a person with endometriosis, adenomyosis, vulvodynia, and pelvic floor dysfunction: this book resonated profoundly.

The pain and suffering Lara has endured and shared with the world through this book sounds so much like my own pain. And for that, 5/5 stars. Sometimes suffering does need company... we need to remember that we aren’t alone. And this book did just that. This book held my hand and cried with me through every page. This book felt like

My opinion of this book was that it seemed like it was just one whining, annoying complaint. As a women some similar-ish issues, I can empathize but there really wasn't much humor in this until she shared some of the painful sex episodes. This was not what I expected when I requested a free read from Netgalley, and damn I am sure glad this was free because I would bring this back for refund if I had purchased it. JUST MY OPINION. Do not waste your time on this, surprised I finished this but I fo

4.5 stars

I expected this book to feel a lot more "taboo" than it actually did. Sure, it talks about sex sometimes, but really there are only a couple chapters devoted to the sex part of vagina problems. This book was really more about living with chronic pain. I didn't expect to identify with it as much as I did, but I've lived with terrible anxiety-induced stomachaches that hit 6 on the pain scale for about three years now, and some of these lines really hit home. It was a difficult read someti

As someone myself who suffers from the same illnesses or “vagina problems” she has, I don’t think I could’ve written a flare-up or unsolicited medical advice experience any clearer. The way she speaks about doctors not believing our pain and suggesting modalities that just serve as band aids and not permanent fixes is too accurate. I wish I could say that this was light reading, but i

Lara Parker basically said every thought that a woman with chronic illness feels on a regular basis. I have Endometriosis, Rheumatoid Arthritis, neuropathy, migraines and a few other issues and the pain can be unbelievable. Lara describes her vagina problems with unwavering realness. She divulged the many ways in which vagina problems interfere and consume her days and nights and all aspects of her life. Lara describes the struggle and fight that many chronic pain sufferers face with their docto

I read this book in disbelief. I had no idea a woman could be in such continuous pain from an early age. I had nothing but empathy for the author while reading. The amount of pain this poor woman has to endure is astonishing. She rattled off words I'd never heard of much less could pronounce. I was surprised endometriosis was so difficult to diagnose. One thing that crossed my mind was a hysterectomy. The author doesn't talk about that so I don't know if that's an option. She is a little reptiti

I really enjoyed Parker's voice, which is really consistent throughout. She combines humor, anger, and frankness to fully illustrate what it is like to have Vagina Problems, both dealing with the immense pain, expecting & fearing the pain, and having doctors not believe that pain. I do think this will be a balm for those with Vagina Problems, but also instructive for those who have someone in their life with Vagina Problems (or someone who just wants to learn and realize that 1 in 10 women have

I enjoyed reading Vagina Problems by Lara Parker because the book dispels the secrecy around endometriosis & shares what it’s been like for the author to struggle with it. Learning from the experience of others is an easy entry point to better understanding a problem and this book is an excellent primer what endometriosis is like. The author’s voice is clear & personable & it’s like she’s talking directly to you as a friend, so you learn all the ins & outs of what she’s going through. I apprecia

review_text:
This one took me a lot longer to get through than I anticipated. It's not because it was hard to read but mostly because it really hit me in the feels. I was really having a crappy few months of endometriosis flair ups while I was reading this and I cycled between- omg, she totally gets me. As well as - omg this endo life is the absolute worst thing ever!

The only big negative for this book is that it could be repetitive at times. In fact I almost DNFed it in the beginning because of repetition.

Thanks to NetGalley for allowing me to read this in exchange for an honest review.

The content in this book is so important and not talked about often enough. The writing was just okay; it did feel as though the author was repeating herself (even the same phrases) over and over - could definitely use another edit. But the subject matter was so important that I feel the need to still give it 4 stars. I don’t have the “vagina problems” that the author describes but know people who do. I can’t imagi

A great book about the realities of living with chronic pain, specifically what the author refers to as “vagina problems.” I have friends who have endometriosis and vaginismus, but still didn’t know how common they were before reading this. I know so many women whose pain has been ignored or minimized by doctors, and the gaslighting by doctors in this book filled me with rage. There was a lot that I loved about this book, and I appreciate anyone willing to share their stories about chronic pain,

Thank you to NetGalley, St. Martin's Griffin and the author for this free ARC. It's such an important topic and I think everyone on Earth needs to hear about it and read this book. It's complete BS how much funding and research has gone into men's health problems vs. women's. And the fact that endo and Vagina Problems are so misunderstood still in 2020 is ridiculous. I've had my own share of Vagina Problems that still have not been diagnosed, and the amount of gaslighting that happens with "wome

Having suffered from my own vagina problems, though not nearly on the same scale as the author, I am able to identify with her struggles and feel her frustration on a deep level. Many times throughout the course of reading this book I felt as if she was describing my own experiences with pain, with the healthcare system, and with well meaning people that just don't know the right thing to say. Until women's health is treated as if it were as important as men's and until the stigmas that surround

this book chronicles a worthy and underrepresented issue, women’s gynecological health. i felt torn, as i so badly wanted to love this book...while i think it’s a necessary publication for so many women who feel isolated, alone and confused (due to the dramatic lack of education all of us receive) by their chronic pain, i had to stop reading after about 75 pages.

parker is a talented writer, however, the book felt redundant and focused on her individual experience. i felt it missed the mark on b

A super well done book highlighting the struggle women go through when it goes to getting "womens problems" diagnosed. Many women struggle for years and years to get a proper diagnosis after being brushed off by doctors. I think it's so important to have books like this so women who are going through this can relate and know that they are not in this journey alone. Thank you to Lara Parker for putting this together and sharing her story.

Thank you to netgalley and the publishers for providing me

A book every girl should read!

Lara Parker takes a private subject and makes it approachable, relatable, and best of all - funny. As the title suggests, this book is about the female anatomy. But it is more than that.. it is about what we are afraid to talk about and what we are not sure about.

I really admire Parker for this book she wrote. She wrote this novel with confidence and zest.

A book for every woman.

I loved this book. As someone who suffers from some of the same illnesses as Lara, this book really resonated with me. I found myself crying at times and laughing at others as she recounts her experiences that are oh so familiar to me. This book made me feel seen and I hope it will do the same for many others experiencing similar issues. It’s refreshing to read from lived experiences rather than just medical facts. This book will help anyone with similar illnesses feel less alone.

Everyone should read it, the main reason why I do recommend it, it’s to understand what people might go through and the way we give feedback to them, it’s an education for everyone that bumps up with negative feedback and makes us feel like we don’t belong and make us feel like we should not have open up. But also it’s a topic that hardly ever it’s discusses! It was my first time hearing about endometriosis. Might sound maybe as ignorance but yes this was my first time hearing about it.

kindness thoughts to this author and others who suffer similar symptoms. feel the medical problem solvers should work to help solve those with this. did feel the book was repetitive in that it went over the same painful thoughts/episodes in all chapters. hopefully there will be some research work done in this area.

A wonderful book that was more autobiographical than I expected. I have many chronically ill friends, and now I think my understanding of what they go through in their day to day life has been deepened. And I'm always for a book that calls out the western medical industry on their bullsh!t. I received an ARC from a goodreads giveaway.

Disclaimer: I received this book from Netgally for review purposes.

Okay, this book was too good. I feel like she was speaking for me and telling stories of my own experiences. I'd never felt more seen, especially when she told all the stories about doctors not listening, not caring, and overall just giving us sad excuses and results. It hurts. When she talked about trying to date with her problems, or travel, or when she wondered what her life would be like when she wasn't sick - not to mention

4.5-stars!!

This giveaway was a dose of honesty that would be wonderful to see more people not turning away from but being open and unashamed to not only speak of but to listen to, to discuss. Ms. Parker provides great incite into a topic I not only wanted to learn more facts on but wanted to hear how such things personally effected another. Wonderful read.

I really needed to read this book. Lara’s story is heartbreaking and I could relate to her on so many levels.

I thought the writing was fantastic and full of great information. Her voice is strong and full of confidence.

I highly recommend this to any women, especially those that have had some type of problem with their vagina.

5 stars! This book made me feel so seen and valid. I feel so lucky to be a young woman at a time when books like these (and people like Lara Parker) are around. I hope medicine continues to advance to help with specifically female issues and that topics like these become more commonly talked about.

As a memoir, it's very good. It's not an easy topic to write about in such an open way but she does it so well.

But I feel like this could have had more science reporting - maybe about current studies into endometriosis, etc. (or lack thereof, because patriarchy) or some interviews with others who have had similar experiences. But like I said, it's a very good personal memoir.

I found this book to be so helpful and thoughtful to those of us who suffer (often silently) through these kinds of issues. I would recommend this book to anyone, even those who aren't suffering, but know others that are. Especially significant others.

I volunteered to read this book, through netgalley in exchange, for an honest review. This book is well written. It was my first time reading a book about Endometriosis. This book tells you how everyone who is experiencing Endometriosis is taking care of themselves day to day. I recommend reading this book to anyone and everyone. This book explains it well. This book will be in stores for $16.99 on October 6.

This is a super quick read and well worth it. Lara writes about her struggles with Vagina Problems in a raw fashion. If you struggle with your own Vagina Problems, you will feel like you are reading the story of your life.

This book is excellent for feeling someone can empathize with you if you also have vagina problems. It was eloquently written and felt very real and raw. I appreciate Lara sharing with us all of her pain so that those of us who share similar diagnoses as her can feel less alone.

The book was informative regarding vaginal problems that can exist BUT just how one can find enough to write about the subject in this book was individually repetitive, moanful and I repeat, repetitive to the point one could read 1/2 the book and know what to expect in symptoms. Notthe best author although I feel she has not been able to adjust well years ago
To get more out of daily life. Hopefully she will accepting of at least living with it.

A raw but funny look into the experience of having endometriosis from diagnosis to dating without sex, to work-life balance and other taboo topics. A first hand account as told by the Author in a relatable way & how it affected every aspect of her life.

I initially really liked this book but after a while it felt repetitive. Still worth reading if you have been diagnosed with any vagina problems or think you may have them. It can be nice to see your experience or even close to your experience in someone else's life.
An important book for any one that has medical problems and who is not being listened to by their doctor.
I won this book in the giveaway! Lara Parker has a keen insight of these taboo topics and did a wonderful job educating me and my other shy girlfriends! Great read for everyone!
I was drawn into the book for the first few chapters by how open and honest the author was. It started to get a bit repetitive after that. Thanks to NetGalley for the ARC.

Finally! Someone who can relate & straight up talk about these issues. I have never felt more understood & less alone. Just wish I had this book in my 20s!!!!

This book will be in stores for $16.99 on October 6.

This is a super quick read and well worth it. Lara writes about her struggles with Vagina Problems in a raw fashion. If you struggle with your own Vagina Problems, you will feel like you are reading the story of your life.

This book is excellent for feeling someone can empathize with you if you also have vagina problems. It was eloquently written and felt very real and raw. I appreciate Lara sharing with us all of her pain so that those of us who share similar diagnoses as her can feel less alone.

The book was informative regarding vaginal problems that can exist BUT just how one can find enough to write about the subject in this book was individually repetitive, moanful and I repeat, repetitive to the point one could read 1/2 the book and know what to expect in symptoms. Notthe best author although I feel she has not been able to adjust well years ago
To get more out of daily life. Hopefully she will accepting of at least living with it.

A raw but funny look into the experience of having endometriosis from diagnosis to dating without sex, to work-life balance and other taboo topics. A first hand account as told by the Author in a relatable way & how it affected every aspect of her life.

I initially really liked this book but after a while it felt repetitive. Still worth reading if you have been diagnosed with any vagina problems or think you may have them. It can be nice to see your experience or even close to your experience in someone else's life.
An important book for any one that has medical problems and who is not being listened to by their doctor.
I won this book in the giveaway! Lara Parker has a keen insight of these taboo topics and did a wonderful job educating me and my other shy girlfriends! Great read for everyone!
I was drawn into the book for the first few chapters by how open and honest the author was. It started to get a bit repetitive after that. Thanks to NetGalley for the ARC.
3.5 stars
This book was easy to read because I related to it so much but for that reason it was also very hard to read. It was weird to read my own thoughts almost word for word on the page.
I empathise with her but I wasn't even halfway and decided that I need to stop reading because it's just a story repeating itself over and over again
Thank you for sharing with us.
Finally! Someone who can relate & straight up talk about these issues. I have never felt more understood & less alone. Just wish I had this book in my 20s!!!!
Ok this was kinda hot ngl. Im gonna read it again
Self indulgent, repetitive and uninteresting. It would have been better as a long article in the New Yorker.
“I had been quite about my issues for so long that I no longer had the ability to keep my experiences inside. I started talking. And I told everyone”
Actually gave up. Repetitive drivel
5 stars for importance of subject matter, 3 stars for reading experience (mostly because it got pretty repetitive).

When I first found this book, I was so excited to read it. I have interstitial cystitis, also know one chronic pelvic pain which is a form of complex regional pain syndrome. In my case, my immune system attacks my bladder causing painful bleeding ulcers, sharp pain and urgency. I could personally relate to Lara on so many levels. I loved how she was so raw and open about her medical issues. It made me feel less alone. I found myself sharing excerpt with my friends and family because Lara was abl

Conversational, brutally honest, and delightfully clever, Lara Parker dives into all her vagina problems and the research that she's done to solve them. Parker offers up a safe space for discussion and commissary on topics such as PCOS, endometriosis, other chronic issues. For those who too suffer from pesky vagina problems, it's a must read!

Fascinating Text; Frustrating Lack of Illustrations

This book is loaded with odds and ends that run the gamut from well organized long form essays to factoids and bits of trivia. The structure is a touch idiosyncratic but makes reasonable sense overall. I guess that figures for a book drawn primarily from a popular podcast.

Here's the thing, though. No photos, no color, no detailed illustrations. Here and there is a bit of graphic doodling, or a little pen and ink sketch, or some clip art, and tha
I am already a plaque reader, but this book opened my eyes to the unseen wonders of the city.

This is an interesting book about city design that is mostly unknown, but the lack of photos is really frustrating. There are graphic illustrations at times, but as another reviewer mentioned, you really want to see pictures of the elements that are described. Also, I thought it would be more about secret elements of every city but many of them are specific to certain cities or to large urban areas in general (I live in a town of 800). It's still a fascinating read, especially for urban dwellers

I absolutely loved everything about this book - the illustrations, the subject, the style. It was so clearly written, yet well researched. My favorite chapter was the one on the raccoons and ths squirrels!
Great read about (mostly) unknown city design. The graphic illustrations are an interesting design choice, too!
As a Beautiful Nerd, I'm beyond excited to hold this wonderful book in my hands. 99 Percent Invisible is a treasure trove of design-based trivia, of which is both eye opening and endlessly amusing.

I really enjoyed this book. If you are inquisitive and like wandering around cities, noticing little details that seem to pop out at you-- sometimes strange or puzzling-- this book may take some of the mystery out of the equation. Other readers will find themselves searching for cryptic signs and details they'd never noticed before. I would have appreciated more visual documentation to go along with the narrative but overall I found this book fascinating.

I received a copy from the publisher thro

Design is one of those things that one struggles to define, even though its one of the most prominent things around us. I did an internship at a design museum a few years ago, and while I have a better grip on it than I did before, I came out of it still hardly knowing how to describe it to others. Everyday design is fascinating to me. Designs are good when you don't even recognise they are there, when they are doing the job they are meant to do without drawing any attention. One of the first th

I received a free digital copy of this book via NetGalley for an honest review.

99% Invisible is consistently one of my favorite podcasts. Even when episodes are focused on topics that I know something about, I always learn something new--and more frequently, the episodes highlight things I've never considered in any depth or even never noticed at all.

The 99% Invisible City is partially a book version of the podcast--that is not to say that the book can be read in lieu of listening to the podcas

The 99% Invisible City by Roman Mars is a free NetGalley ebook that I read in early October.

Chapters on city planning, utilities, signage, and public works & safety - there's a mix of graphics in the sense that there ink drawings and photo-realistic illustrations. The scope of the narration is vast and blissfully fluent, but takes the long scenic path to an otherwise basic phrase.

Don't confuse this book with Italo Calvino's Invisible Cities – they're really quite different things. This bumper pack of social history, engineering history and so on asks us to take a closer look at what makes a city, that we don't normally consider. Road layouts, and what gets put in the gap left behind once a railway line (or Berlin Wall) has been dug up, are here, as are so many amenities and parts of the infrastructure. That infrastructure has only grown and grown, from a gutter for the w

The 99% Invisible City: A Field Guide to the Hidden World of Everyday Design by Roman Mars and Kurt Kohlstedt is a fascinating collection of stories and descriptions that explain all sorts of things associated with city infrastructure. Many of these topics cover things that you’ve seen many times but may not have thought about or realized that there was an interesting backstory. The book is constructed in a way that you could read straight through in several sittings or you could pick up and rea

Pre-COVID days, I took public transport quite often. Unfortunately, I'm unable to read on the bus because I get travel sickness. I also can't do audiobooks for whatever reason. I'll sometimes listen to music, but… there's something about podcasts that make the bus ride so much more enjoyable. One of my favorite podcasts is 99% Invisible, which looks at the world through a different lens to focus on the little details that we, otherwise, don't think much of, or might not even know exists. They br

I discovered 99% Invisible's podcast in 2012 and they have been telling interesting design stories in new exciting ways. (I immediately digested their whole backcatalog) The 99% Invisible City is a wonderful revisiting and update of many topics, not a cut-and-paste of transcripts, and it shows. Handsomely crafted with distinctive illustrations and typography, it is meticulously organized into six distinct sections with a very in-depth Table of Contents and Index. There are many things that this
Amazing stories! Would benefit from some additional photos to accompany key visual stories (although the drawings included are fantastic)

"The 99% Invisible City" explains how different design features in cities have come about and why they are that way. These are short entries, only two or three pages long per topic. Rather than looking at the best design, we're often told about a poor design that doesn't work. Or we're told how someone was inspired to create something and how it works. The book covered things like what various sidewalk markings mean, how to spot fake façades and what they might cover up, how a city changes over
An interesting book that makes you understand and appreciate the things that make up cities and towns.

As a longtime listener to (who is still not yet caught up with) the podcast 99% Invisible I was excited for this book, perhaps because I didn't realize how much of it was just ... the podcast. I've listened to maybe half of the episodes, and every few pages I encountered some story that I'd already heard. The things that were new to me, I'm not sure if they're also episodes that I just haven't listened to yet. So that was a letdown. The other big disappointment was that they didn't take advantag

I feel like this book was intended as just a signal, “I’m so cool I own this book” and not actually to be read. The sections are so short as to barely convey any interesting information (the opposite of why the podcast is so good), and in dozens of places a picture or image of the thing they’re talking about would be enormously helpful but none are included (the art is fine but is rarely useful). Was really disappointed by this.

Potato-chip morsels of education and entertainment, and for some reason I kept hearing it in my head in Roman Mars's voice.

But it never quite satisfies. It doesn't have the depth of discovery from the podcast. These are articles with scope instead of sprawling interviews that occasionally surprised the journalists themselves in the midst of their topic.

If you like architecture and its quirks & features, you may want to read this book. I didn't know there is a podcast of 99% (not sure if I'm gonna listen) but if you regularly listen, not sure if there is something new for you (I found randomly an essay from book previously web-published).
For us others, it contained a lot of interesting quirks about city architecture (mostly USA). For example, did you know that there is a building in UK, nicknamed the Dalek? (and that it was making typhoon-like

A nicely illustrated overview of basic architectural and civil engineering objects and design in use in modern cities, this book offers short histories and vignettes about relay stations, urban reuse, warning symbols, manhole covers, and other things we encounter in daily city life. The histories are interesting enough, but rarely include the systemic issues that have contributed to the reasons for why many things as they are; a notable omission is the fact that overpasses across the Southern St
Pre-ordered from Porter Sq. Books, arrived Oct. 6, publication day. Can't wait for the publication night talk with Roman Mars & Kurt Kohlstedt. Challenge coin arrived last week.

Really enjoyed all of the urban fun facts that this book brought to the table. Sadly, it didn't live up to its potential because of the execution. To really appreciate much of this information included here, this should have been a book with lots of pictures - as the phrase 'field guide' also implies. Instead, I kept having to turn away from the text to look things up on the internet to fully understand, which took away from the experience. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes this sort of thing

I loved this book, then I hated it, then I started loving it again.

Listening to the eponymous podcast has been a huge source of joy in my life. I’m a supporter, I check out every side project they do, and of course I preordered the book as soon as it was announced. And I still love them with all my heart, but I have to admit that I wanted to throw this book out on the window 100 pages in.

On one hand, if you are a longtime listener, it offers much less: the best stories are all ones that you’ve

Those who listen to the podcast 99 Percent Invisible know the format -- 30-40 minute episodes, some history on the subject, interviews, nuanced takes. At first glance, such a listener might be bewildered by the format of 99 Percent Invisible, the book. How can they fit all the relevant information into just a couple pages per story? Well, Roman Mars and Kurt Kohlstedt do exactly that, and it's the most brilliant thing about the book. Each story is condensed into only the most relevant and necess

I thoroughly enjoyed this book about design. I’ve been a listener or 99 PI for at least year and it was interesting both to revisit stories that I remember listening to and reading stories that I missed from earlier episodes. Having a physical book allowed me time to rethink, explore and consider the small design choices that make up a city.

If I have one complaint, it was with the choice to go with line drawings to illustrate the book. In most cases, the line drawings work fine. In a few cases (

VERTICAL FOREST TOWER, MILAN
When tons of trees are put up on buildings, extra concrete and steel reinforcement are required to handle their added weight, irrigation systems are needed to water the plants, and additional wind load complexity has to be taken into account. Once installed on upper floors, trees are subject to high winds, though they often seem to remain improbably straight and tall in renderings. Wind can also interrupt photosynthetic processes, while heat and cold can wreak havoc o

I'm a long-time listener of the 99PI podcast, and to be completely honest, I was a little apprehensive about the book - what if it wasn't the same?!

Readers; I needn't have worried! True, it's not the same. There's no dulcet tones of Roman Mars or background music, but the written content is as clear and evocative as the podcast. And it has pictures! So many detailed illustrations! When I first heard that this book was going to include illustrations, not photographs, I was a little concerned. (Th

I'm a long-time listener of the 99PI podcast, and to be completely honest, I was a little apprehensive about the book - what if it wasn't the same?!

Readers; I needn't have worried! True, it's not the same. There's no dulcet tones of Roman Mars or background music, but the written content is as clear and evocative as the podcast. And it has pictures! So many detailed illustrations! When I first heard that this book was going to include illustrations, not photographs, I was a little concerned. (Th

As a longtime fan-girl of the 99 pi podcast, receiving an autographed copy of this book was a cool moment. This book is a must-read for "beautiful nerds" everywhere!

The line drawings (over real images) were a deliberate design choice by Roman and Kurt-- they explained it at an event organized by the JCCSF. They wanted to recreate the abstract nature of the 99 pi show, where Roman talks about visual objects like fonts and doors and colors, while his listeners imagine various versions of these ob

It’s 99% Invisible book. It’s exactly what you expect it will be. I learned a lot, but as with any book originating from another medium (here from podcast to book), some of it was rehash from old material, some of it is new.

As much as I understand the economics of a two colors book (instead of a full color book) and as I like the esthetic of this book, a "guide" centered mostly around the visual design of cities is a bit self defeated by it’s lack of pictures.

You’ll have a great time reading thi

Quite enjoyable, especially if one is a fan of the podcast. This was similar to reading a book of short stories, albeit non-fiction ones with an overarching theme. I often had the feeling that I had already heard a lot of these in podcast format with the most often feeling of “didn’t I hear this on 99% Invisible?” But Roman Mars said this wasn’t the case so I’m going to have to believe him on this. I think I am in the minority on this, but I would rather have seen photos in the book rather than

Picked this up in Type Books in Toronto on a whim, and boy am I glad I did! It was so incredibly interesting and I was hooked. If you are a nerd about the built environment, you will LOVE reading this.

Some have complained about the lack of photos, but I thought the sketches and illustrations were plentiful and sufficient. Of course, I’d have loved if there had been more, but that wouldn’t have been practical. The illustrations fit perfectly in with the design style of this book.

It is organized

If you like the show, or if you simply like cities, you'll really enjoy the book. It's a great source of small bits of knowledge which will let you see the world in a subtle, nerdy bit really compelling way. The illustrations are beautiful and there are dozens of little puns everywhere.

That said, I'm disappointed at how over-designed the book is, especially given its title. Too many heading styles, lines, flourish everywhere, to the point it distracts the reader away from the great text. You ca

What an amazing book! Being a fan of the podcast and used to the excellent quality of it, I had high expectations, and I was not disappointed!

The book is a delight to read and allows you to discover so many aspects of the world around you, in an accessible way. The illustrations were charming and fit perfectly in the flow of the book.At first I was confused by the lack of images, but as I progressed I fell in love with the illustrations and cannot imagine the book any other way, as they help wit

This is a great book, and would be a five star read if the original podcast 99% Invisible did not already exist - I would highly recommend giving the podcast a try - it is fun, educational, and at times really tense and exciting! I recommend starting with the episodes Structural Integrity and H Day, both of which are summarized in this book.

Destined to be a great book to read in the bathroom, but that is a good thing! I would keep your phone close by so you can Google some of the crazy things th

This is a great book, and pretty much exactly what I expected! It's full of a bunch of small, bite-sized chapters digging into various aspects of how a city works. This is a great installment in the genre of "under-appreciated things that are an important part of our life, but feel like background context"

Note: The physical copy was beautifully illustrated, but I found it fairly bulky and hard to read from

A fantastic book, but replicates a lot of what I've heard in the 99% Invisible episodes. I should have expected this, but it's a good way to "go back in time" and listen to each concept. They're also presented differently from the podcast, without interviews and with more analysis. Great book. I would recommend it to anyone.

As a longtime listener of the podcast I was excited to read this book. Lots of fun facts and descriptions of fascinating design aspects found in many cities. Certainly helps me appreciate the art and design we find all around if we just keep out eyes open.
Easy to pick up and read just a few chapters at a time or to devour all at once.

A spin-off from the podcast 99% invisible, this book looks at elements of city design, from traffic sign posts designed to fail gracefully if hit by a car, to the beveled city block corners in Barcelona to the intricate design of manhole covers in Tokyo.

Occasionally a bit shallow, the book tries to cover too many subjects, and can't dive very deeply into any specific subject.

DNF.

2 pages isn't enough space to get into these topics with enough depth to find much beyond what could be surmised by looking at these objects in the wild. Essentially a book full of anecdotes, another example of the podcast -> book conversion that didn't seem to effectively make the jump.

Wether you are a history buff, an architectural dilettante, art fascinado or just a curious soul and wonderlust, you will fall in love with this book. Poetic yet packed with science tidbit and history.

The audio book (I owned) narrated by the author himself is enjoyable as his podcast. Highly recommend.

While about half of the material seems to repeat from the podcasts, I still enjoyed it because that podcast content was framed in a different way or expanded into a different direction in the book. There is plenty of new content as well, and the book is organized in a very thoughtful and engaging manner

I'm a long time listener of the "99% Invisible" podcast and really expected to like this book. Unfortunately it felt overly overly broad. If they'd edited down the number of entries and included more on each topic it would have been so much better. As written it's a list of subjects you may want to look up in other places. I'm really disappointed.

An interesting book for those who are fascinated by trivia. This book gives snapshots of various topics within a city and also the history of various landmarks. There are six chapters overall chapters, each further divided, based on seen or unseen items, architecture, geography & human interaction.

Excellent book on every day designs you see in our urban and rural landscapes. Lots of interesting stories about how past designs and decisions can impact our current urban environment. Anyone interested in architecture, engineering, city planning, landscape architecture, this book is for you.

This was a most interesting book. It emphasized the mundane and mostly hidden design beauty that embellishes our cities. It was a nice introduction to observing the 'art' often found in simple, sometimes boring things. A good read.

A great field guide to any city. It's full of quick hits of information found in 99 Percent Invisible's podcast, condensed and light yet informative. Shout out to the local-to-me portions like Detroit's funky layout and Edward Hines contributions to developed roads.

Truly wonderful book about the very world we live in. Great book for all you design, planning, and just generally detail oriented people out there. Love the illustrations and stories about things we see every day!

This is a really fun book on design and the built environment. It's organized as a staccato series of short interesting pieces, grouped by topic. You can pick it up and read for a few minutes, or for a few hours. Lots of useful trivia for your next walk around town with curious people.

A set of very interesting story 99pi style. A lot of the thing that is common in the book, doesn't exist in my place. It feels weird for me born and living in Malaysia, needing me to looking up on it.

It is still an interesting story written in a short format, still will recommend it.
Like the podcast, it's a well-researched and interesting look at parts of cities that tend to be taken for granted or ignored.
Interesting but of course very US centric because it's written in the US
This is an excellent look at all the things that we overlook
This is not a book, it's a long and tedious list of random stuff loosely organized into chapters. It's the most bored I've ever been reading something fascinating.
Love the podcast, and really enjoyed the book.
As a huge fan of the podcast, reading this book was like finding a hundred unheard episodes. Some are familiar stories, but most are new. I appreciate the detail put into organizing the book.
All these puns! And Roman’s voice in my head when I was reading each and every word!
Fascinating.
I could certainly hear Roman's voice when reading the book. Great book read cover to cover!
I've had a blast reading this book. The sections tell enough about a thing to be satisfying and are short enough to fit in so many topics in the book without it becoming an overencumbering time.
Enjoyed the dozens of short stories about the small things you don’t normally notice in cities. A great addition to the podcast.

You beautiful nerds:
There are stories everywhere.
Thank you, Roman Mars.

I was in the communications field for years, so most of this information was already known. However for the average citizen around the world, it's an interesting and fun read. Suggest you pick up a copy from your local library and learn about the hidden (and not so hidden) things all around you! This is an excellent read.
I picked and chose and enjoyed. Will share around.
LA behind LA. Sounds like a fascinating examination of 'beyond the obvious' design of the city.
So much fun to read! Will be going back to this book often when I come across a new urban design element in the "wild."
A book for all the plaque-readers, slow-walkers, and wandering minds of the city.
Great book, highly recommending it.
At times it feels like recycled material from the podcast, but giving it 4 stars as it's still an interesting and entertaining read.
Love the content, but if you listen to the podcast there's nothing new here.
If you like the podcast (and if you don’t you have no soul) a lot of this book will feel familiar. This book is an apt extension of the podcast, entertaining, informative, thoughtful, and human.
So much fun! Tons of cool information about design details around our cities. I'll definitely be on the lookout this stuff as I make my way around my own city!
I love this podcast, so the book is an extra special treat
Fascinating.
I could certainly hear Roman's voice when reading the book. Great book read cover to cover!

Just published my October Book Vlog and whew! It was a lot of reading but so worth it!
The Written Review

Full Review to Come

Cait is a hiker and a blogger who has "opted out" of society's expectations and carved out her own life, on her own terms. This book is her "field guide to leading an intentional life."
But for something claiming to be intentional, this book doesn't seem to know what it wants to be. Instead of inspiring it's all so.....banal....and bland.

I was SO looking forward to reading this book because I loved Flanders' previous book, Year of Less. This one was disappointing. The premise sounded great - "opt out" of the expected paths and find your own way/adventures. She writes the book with "opting out" being an analogy to hiking. But, like many reviews said (and I didn't want to believe) it was VERY repetitive and used the same few examples over and over and over. And most of the examples were pretty vague, so it didn't have much impact.

Thank you to the publisher for providing me with an eARC of this novel via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

My honest to god gut reaction while reading this was: Cait...girl...please tell me something I don't know.

I appreciate the message that Adventures in Opting Out is trying to deliver. I fully ascribe to the belief that we should live our own lives fearlessly the way we want, not how other people want us to live them. Make messes, go on big or little adventures, find your niche com

I was so looking forward to Cait’s second book but it feels bland, repetitive, and overly simplistic. It’s actually painful to write this because I so enjoyed her first book and also her Instagram posts.
Please no more self help books based on a hiking analogy.

I read and enjoyed the author's first book. This one didn't hit home with me quite as much. There are some good bits about opting out from "regular" life and following the life path that suits you best. Flanders tried to parallel opting out with hiking terminology and it sometimes works, but at other times just feel a little gimmicky. From reading the book, I know the author was trying to make the information here more generalized rather than sharing more of her own story but I think this book w
Meh. I didn’t like the first book so don’t know why I thought this would be any different. It’s not that it was a bad book - I just didn’t get the content I was hoping for.

Dang. I really did like The Year of Less and I like Cait's voice, but I just did not feel a connection with Adventures in Opting out. Small sections of the book landed solidly, but overall I didn't feel like it had much value for me. Too bad.

I really like the message of this book, listening to your gut, managing the pushback you might get from opting out, keeping important people in your life even if they might not understand… I think the tone and writing style just didn’t work for me. All of the analogies were cute but didn’t always make sense, and it veered more into self-help and giving directions rather than telling the story of how she spent a year traveling from place to place. I think these days I prefer my “self-help” more i

I had low expectations after reading the other reviews, but I was pleasantly surprised by this book! Cait’s wide network of friends/bloggers allows her to share experiences and anecdotes that have something for everyone. I found myself particularly drawn to her story about her friend Nicole. Her personal experiences, while still central, take a backseat to the overarching plot of the novel, which allows the reader to become the focus. While reading this book, I spent a good deal of time looking

I was a longtime reader of Cait’s blog, and loved her work. It was a grounded voice that resonated with me, and was a refreshing change from the rest of the Canadian personal finance blogosphere.

I read her first book and didn’t enjoy it - perhaps it was better for readers who were new to her as an author, but it was more or less a reprint of her blog.

When this book came out, I gave it a try. She’s written how this book feels a lot different than her last one.

This book fell flat for me pretty muc

This book had me with this....

"We all follow our own path in life. At least, that's what we're told. In reality, many of us either do what is expected of us, or take the invisible, but well-worn paths that lead to what is culturally acceptable. For some, those paths are fine-even great. But they leave several of us feeling disconnected from ourselves and what we really want to do. When that discomfort finally outweighs the fear of trying something new, we're ready to opt out."

Loved this book. G

This book is hard to categorize its part self help, part memoir part travelogue. The author focuses on the idea of it being okay to "opt out", choose to live some aspect of your life in a way that's different than others expectations, if it doesn't hurt you or other people. She talks some about her own opt out of having a permanent residence and deciding to travel around Europe for a time but also interviews others who have had their own opt out. She uses a hiking analagy throughout.

I overall l

I’m disappointed to write this review, as a great fan of Cait’s blogging, social media, and first book. I feel this book missed the mark. I was looking forward to reading about the experiences of other people and their opt-outs as advertised but I felt she barely scratched the surface either any of them. She indicated in the book that she didn’t think she could finish writing the book due to personal challenges, but hunkered down and did, and it’s shows. The only lesson I really took away was th

I was really excited to dig into this book after loving Cait's first book, The Year of Less. The tagline says it's a field guide and that's exactly how it feels when you're reading. While none of the advice is groundbreaking per se, it does give helpful reminders and encouragement from a friend who feels like a fellow trailblazer. I especially connected with the section titled The Viewpoint and the Seventh Sense chapter. It was nice to read other people's stories in opting out rather than just t

I adored Year of Less and preordered the audio of this one because I was so excited. But. I get what she was trying to do with the hiking analogy format but it didn’t work at ALL for me. I so wanted this to be a memoir and not a how-to guide - she even admitted at the end that all of this big stuff had happened to her during the time period in which the book is set but didn’t discuss it in the book because it didn’t fit the format. I wish an editor had realized how much powerful it could have be

I loved Cait’s first book and I love this one as well, though they are very different. This one is for all those who are drawn to the path less travelled. Follow along as Cait shares some of the paths and experiences she intentionally chose to leave behind, and what she was able to find as a result. A timely reminder that we only get one chance at life and the book provides a guide of sorts for how to navigate leaving the “norm” behind and finding your own way. Highly recommend!

Absolutely loved this book. It doesn't feel like a self help book, but it really makes you feel good about making choices that are right for you even if they aren't mainstream or they seem daunting. The writing feels like a friend chatting and it's relatable.

Flanders uses an extended metaphor to compare making different life choices to the elements of a hike. I really liked her first book, which felt personal, compelling and left me ruminating for quite a while. Sorry to say that this one feels distant, bland and highly repetitive. She works very hard to break down the hiking metaphor into infinitesimal pieces to keep the theme going. I know she was trying to come up with a “guide” that would ostensibly help anyone on any life journey that goes agai
Nothing too profound here, but made me think that I can still opt out on a smaller scale ( given my age) and realized that my ex had opted out a long time ago & I did not realize it!

I love this book. It's full of nuance and real stories, not platitudes or sweeping "advice" like so many other books in this category. This is one where, if you go through it too quickly, you could miss the real magic. Cait is a joy to read; it's like catching up with an old friend. And I loved reading her travel reflections and stories throughout!
I’m a big fan of Cait Flanders, but this felt like it fell short. There is good content, but the story isn’t captivating. 2.5 stars.

I'm very conflicted in this review as I love Cait Flanders and really enjoyed her debut The Year of Less. This follow up somewhat missed the mark for me. I kept waiting for her to dive into her life abroad but it was so piecemeal that I never felt I was getting into a flow. The book is organized into elements of a hike which is personally where I feel this book is flawed as there is. lot of style of substance. Nothing is bad in here--it just feels like a lot of very basic advice when I would hav

Thank you to NetGalley for getting to read this book early. I received a free copy in exchange for my honest review.

I read Cait Flanders's first book, The Year of Less, three times... well, read it twice and listened to it once. It certainly is the book that planted the seed of minimalism into my brain. I'm FAR from a minimalist in my home yet... I have YEARS of stuff to get rid of first - not only my own stuff but multiple family members' stuff that got foisted upon me from their estates. I co

A while back, I did a year-long project called "A Simple Year." Cait Flanders was one of the facilitators, and I have followed her work since then. Her recent book, "Adventures in Opting Out: A Field Guide to Leading an Intentional Life," draws on hiking metaphors to reveal truths she has learned from years of opting out of debt, consumerism, drugs, drinking, and some societal expectations. In 2019 she opted out from her "normal life" to spend a year trying to live traveling and working abroad a

I read Cait Flanders's first book, The Year of Less, when i was starting my own journey to minimalism and had opted out of the material world. I gained much insight from her first book and at that time she was blogging which was a wealth of information on doing without materialism , opting out of "expectations" of others and being true to yourself. I admire independence so I have followed her journey and always admired how she creates and re creates her life to suit herself which is what we shou

Adventures in Opting Out by Cait Flanders is a non-fiction book written to share the experience of the author and other individuals who "opt out" of what others and society tell them to do. It also helps the reader to use those stories to reflect upon their own lives and identify any areas where they can intentionally opt-out of the things they don't actually enjoy. I think this is an important topic, especially in the midst of COVID which is forcing people to reflect upon their values and what

I received a copy of this book from NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

I really liked the tone of this book! I wasn't familiar with Flanders work before I dove into this story.

Flanders shares advice from her life of travel and her pursuit of things that made her feel happy. I like the metaphor of climbing the mountain and each step being a phase along the hike to get to the summit. I like that the author acknowledges that it's hard and sometimes you lose friends and you change and that's

I met Cait online in 2015/16 when she was a personal finance blogger. She was the only blogger that replied to her followers by email. I was pleasantly surprised. Hers became the only blog I've ever followed because I loved her writing and it spoke to me at the time.

I also had credit card debt I needed to get rid of and the concept of her shopping ban helped me do that! Then it started a Journey of Less for me. I bought her first book and enjoyed it. But not as much as this book. I've never rea

First off, thank you to the publishers and NetGalley for this ARC; I read Cait’s first novel last year and fell in love with her knowledge and way of articulating her words and “Adventures in opting out” is another brilliant piece. While the majority of the novel is travel/hiking based; you don’t have to be either of those things to enjoy it. Opting out is a personal journey, one that takes you on a adventure(much like travel and hiking) with peaks and valleys, learning that even though that fir

Overall, I enjoyed some of the ideas in Cait Flanders' Adventures in Opting Out. She details some of her experiences and those of her friends as they have "opted out" and gone done an unexpected path. She is balanced in terms of not just focusing on the fun and glory of choosing a different route, but also focusing on certain trials and tribulations that may arise.

Unfortunately, I did not love the structure that she used for the book. She used hiker's analogies as a scaffolding for the book and

Having read Cait’s first book I couldn’t wait to dive into this one and it did not disappoint! She has such an easy writing style that every time you sit down to read this book you’ll feel like your just chatting with an old friend. Whether you’re considering a life change, big or small, or in the middle of an opt out like I am, Cait walks you through what to expect and how to stay in a positive mindset when things get hard, because she reminds you that it will get hard. I loved that this book w

Adventures in Opting Out is an interesting read and parallels the author's journey via the idea of hiking/mountain climbing. Each chapter develops starting from the bottom of a mountain until one reaches the summit. The author faced many challenges along the way, both in her personal life as well as on actual hikes and a trip to Europe. She gives up her home to travel for a year, only to have difficulties along the way. I really enjoy Flander's writing style but did enjoy her first book a bit mo

As a fellow hiker the analogy of hikes resonates with me. I enjoy her writing and the gentle guidance to take things into your own hands. In the Introduction she says ‘...if you’re already happy with the path your on, you probably don’t need to read further.’ I disagree. While I may be on the right main path for me it is far to easy to take a side trail that leads you away from what you really meant to do. There are many lessons here that apply whether you need to change direction completely or

Cait Flanders is one of those writers where I feel like we're friends even though the closest we've ever come to talking was when she commented on one of my Instagram posts one time (which made my day). She's written another encouraging, compassionate, comforting read on living life on your own terms, perhaps especially necessary in these times. If you're reevaluating the way you've been living in light of what's happening in the world, this book is like a thermos full of tea or soup and a suppo

I felt this book lacked focus. It kept shifting from being a book about a year of travel to how to hike to analogies of hiking and opting out of something your life. Towards the end of the book she talks about how when she got her self out of debt she “bought” herself a coffee and went down to the beach to celebrate. I found it odd that she wouldn’t have just taken a coffee from home to the beach. In the introduction of the book she states that if you’re already happy with the path you are on yo

If you need inspiration or support during a time in your life when you want to change your path, this might give you that helping hand. As someone who plans every trip, every adventure and wants to know what I’ll do along the way, this book helped me see the joy of giving a new path a try without having to know all the answers before I start. Cait says, “You can’t know what’s going to happen or how you’re going to feel about it until you start going down the new path. Instead, you have to work p

I read the kindle version. This book just comes at a perfect point for me, as I am about to navigate some drastic and intentional life changes. The purpose is really to help the reader navigate their opting-outs, with a special focus on the emotional aspects. Really recommend it as a practical guide to anyone looking to change any aspect of their life, and being at a counter current of folks close to them. It's tough and Cait offers a helping hand

I generally don't love books that have an "instruction manual" style/vibe so I knew going in that this might not be my favourite, but I've enjoyed Cait's other work and was glad to see that the style, personality, and warmth present in her newsletters carried over here. It was a lovely read and I came away with a few ideas to chew on/some much needed reminders, which is exactly what I'd hoped for.

Not exactly what I was expecting. I was thinking it was a book about living off grid. It's not. Disappointed, but the book was interesting, in it's own way. I could relate to it, a bit. In my own way, I opt out ocassionally, too. This will appeal to some young person, life's a journey; don't waste it. You should go out on limb and try new stuff, explore while you have the chance. Time enough to maybe pick another route. You have time and it all works out!

Cait Flanders spoke to my heart in this beautiful, affirming book about choosing the path less travelled. As a childfree, self-employed, serial renter, I have consciously left many of society’s expectations unmet; but that doesn’t make the road any easier to walk. Cait normalises every rollercoaster emotion whilst reminding me of the true importance of living in a way that is consistent with my values. I feel refreshed to keep striving forth with courage and ‘hike my own hike’.

The underlying premise of the book has a lot of promise but the execution just wasn't there. I liked the analogy threaded through the book of hiking and making choices to 'opt out in life.' However Caits examples were not that inspiring or great. One that came up a few times was Cait living in another country but not being able to find accomodations that meet her budget in a few weeks. Would not recommend.

This book was such a wonderful read! Cait has carved a unique and intentional life for herself, and her honesty and candid writing are refreshing. Even as someone who lives a fairly normal, unadventurous life, this book challenged me to look for ways the status quo isn't working for me and to examine them. What a wonderful second book from Cait Flanders!

A refreshingly honest and thoughtful reflection on taking the road less traveled. Heartwarming and encouraging and exactly the kind of book I needed during a year where everything we were told about how to live has come into question -- the best and most beautiful adventures come from "hiking your own hike," not anyone else's. Highly recommend!

I like Cait’s writing in general, and I liked this book, but I’m not sure I loved it. I think I wanted more of her story during this particular opt out. There were absolutely good reminders and lines I’ll think about and write down, but I’ll have to see if I think about these analogies through my own future adventures.

I think this book would be really helpful for me if I hadn’t already gotten over the hump of needing other people to agree with or understand my life choices. If you’re looking to change something (especially something dramatic), she gives you a roadmap for trusting yourself to know what’s best for you.

I cannot praise Cait’s first book enough so I did what I never do and bought a copy of this book when I found out my library didn’t carry it. I enjoyed the read and continue to learn so much from her life experiences. I will say that I didn’t totally love the flow and found the anecdotes repetitive. Overall, I admire the author and will continue to support her work and message.

I followed Cait's blog for many many years and I enjoy her outlook on life. Unfortunately I felt like this book didn't have enough substance. Cait uses a hike as a metaphor for following your own path in life. That's basically the book in one sentence. It would have been more impactful as a number of blog posts or newsletters.

Author Flanders wants to give a path to executing a live of value. But there is an attempt to become beyond the usual stuff. She says we need to get “opt out” as a way of doing something new and important. The best of the book comes in the last quarter of the book when she uses gives us a new way to see what is necessary to make a difference in one’s life.

I liked the overall read about how to improve one's life as an analogy of climbing a mountain. I would have preferred to read more personal impacts/stories of how the author achieved this instead of just talking about the steps. Overall it was a quick read - would give 3/5 stars.

I liked the overall read about how to improve one's life as an analogy of climbing a mountain. I would have preferred to read more personal impacts/stories of how the author achieved this instead of just talking about the steps. Overall it was a quick read - would give 3/5 stars.

Amazing

I read caits first book and it became my favorite book , now her second book here is my new favorite. She's an in credible writer and speaks from the heart. Life changing words that came at my own stage of life of choosing multiple opt outs.

I loved Cait's first book. But this one didn't have much of a take away for me. I found it repetitive and vague. It's too bad because Cait has had such an interesting life. I wish she had've shared more about herself in this book.

So many tidbit of wisdom about the paths in life we've taken and yet to have taken. It's an inspiratonal account of how one might broach the topic of changing one's own life, someone one step at a time, other times with a leap.
Review to follow...
Loved it !
This is a book for those who are intrigued by living life a bit differently. “Whenever you dare to go on an adventure, you will always come home a little more like yourself.”
This book was like a warm hug. I loved how Cait presented the novel as a hike. Her words touched my heart and came at the perfect time in my life.
It was. That’s kind of it. I enjoyed it for the easy read and permission to do the alternative, but it was the mostttttt compelling book out there.
Loved the comparisons between opting out and hiking. The story did not go where I thought it would and I liked the honesty in that.

Inspiring

Flanders takes us under her wing and shows us all how to opt out and find our true path in life. She is an inspiration and a joy to read.
This is just not the book for me. If I was 30 years younger, this book would be great. I think others would enjoy this book.

This is a wonderful self-help book that discusses how to opt-out of the big things in life to keep you on your path to the life you want to live. I loved how the author used the analogy of hiking a mountain and how it relates to making big changes in your life. The advice she gives to achieve a goal is spot on; for example, do your research before making a big decision, have a cheerleader to support you in your choice, take your time to accomplish your goal, be flexible with the change, and take

I am not a nature person, but I have deeply enjoyed everything Flanders has put on the internet and wanted to read her newest book anyway. This is not nature writing, it is a memoir which is set mostly while traveling and hiking. Flanders carries the journey of a hike to frame the arc of the book, a very effective literary tool. I have no grand dreams of nomadic life, but found it affirming nonetheless for the many other ways I am opting out of expectations. This book helped me learn to listen a

I devoured her first book "The Year of Less" and very much enjoyed the feeling that it was more like sitting down with a friend over coffee and having a conversation. Adventures in Opting Out very much has the same feel. Your friend has returned and has all sorts of information that she wants to share with you about her travels and to give a fresh perspective on how to possibly look at life.
I very much enjoyed Cait's book and more to the point I love her style of writing.

Adventures in Opting Out very much has the same feel. Your friend has returned and has all sorts of information that she wants to share with you about her travels and to give a fresh perspective on how to possibly look at life.
