The Dead Are Arising is the collaborative effort of Les Payne and his daughter Tamara. For the heralded columnist this is his opus, a thirty year labor of love. For Tamara Payne it is a testament to her father as much as it is to Malcolm.

This past Friday I had the pleasure of seeing Tamara Payne interviewed on Politics and Prose. In discussing the direction of The Dead Are Arising she explained how our love for the man clouds our vision of him. That we tend to see him in a vacuum. He is this myt

This is great companion reading to the Autobiography of Malcolm X. It parses through Malcolm's life using interviews with his siblings as well as many people who knew him personally in order to flesh out a full version of his life. It gives you a better idea of who Malcolm was in all of the major phases of his life. Of course, there are some things that seem consequential in his autobiography which barely get a mention here, but that most likely has to do with being able to corroborate the stori
Ohhh maaan! Riveting! May very well be the best book ever written about Malcolm x. Mor to come.

The first chapter of this book begins with two gripping, life-and-death stories. The first is the story of Louise Little standing on the porch of her Omaha home, confronting the Klansmen who came to threaten, if not murder, her husband — who was in Milwaukee at the time. Surrounded by her three children, the eight-months pregnant Louise faced down the Klansmen. A month later, she gave birth to her fourth child: Malcolm.

The second is the story of the 1919 Omaha race murders, in which a screaming,

The takeaway: I have not finished this book yet but in my opinion, it has not been very well-researched. I ultimately couldn't bring myself to purchase it due to the poor scholarship. Manning Marable's A Life of Reinvention remains the essential biography of Malcolm X.

Good: I will say that the authors have done a great job in finding primary sources who knew Malcolm and his family and are willing to share their recollections. There were a lot of interesting anecdotes regarding Malcolm X and his

Detailed Exploration of Malcolm X's Life and Death

Very informative, deep dive into the live of the compelling Malcolm X. I appreciated how this book really expands on The Autobiography of Malcolm X and how it differentiates the incidents and people in Autobiography from the more detailed reality of what actually happened. For example, Autobiography uses composites from real people and events in Malcolm D's life to tell his story. However, The Dead Are Arising goes further and really names the tr

What a fascinating and powerful individual, filled w/ contradictions, and in the end, great promise. Years ago, I read the Autobiography. I really liked how the Paynes have skillfully researched his family, provided greater context about the Nation of Islam and Malcolm's background, and illustrated his foibles, as well as his potential. A worthy biography about an amazing American.
My 4th X bio. This and the marable could not be more different, but both are necessary.

In any history of the previous century and its racial unrest, Malcolm X must play a prominent role. From a hustler to a prophet, from a spokesman to an apostate, from a victim to a martyr, Malcolm embodied so many contradictory roles and phases that it's sobering to realize that he died on the cusp of his fortieth year (much like his contemporary and supposed rival for the hearts and minds of Black people, Martin Luther King, Jr.). That he left behind a testament to his transformation and eventu

I just finished this book and the first thing I want to tell you is to go and buy it as fast as you can. Then read it. ‘The Dead Are Arising: The Life of Malcolm X’ was started by Les Payne, an award-winning journalist, and completed, after his unfortunate death, by his daughter, Tamara Payne.

If you don’t know who Malcolm X is, this book is a capable, captivating, compelling illustration of the arc of his tremendous life. If you do know who Malcolm X is, you’ll know why you’ll want to read ever

I first read “The Autobiography Of Malcolm X” 38 years ago, in 1982. I have read the book more than 5 additional times, each time offering new insights. The book was so inspiring that I have been obsessed with knowing more about him. I have reviewed a wide scope of works in reference to Malcolm, so it is easy for me to become complacent and to think that there is very little that is ever going to be presented that is new. This new book by Les Payne proves me wrong. I purchased Payne's book on th

As I mentioned in one of my status updates while reading, Les Payne throughly summarizes Malcolm X's childhood in the Midwest and then speeds through his young adulthood in Boston and New York until Malcolm converts in prison and joins the Nation of Islam. That is mostly the reason why I subtracted a star from my rating.

However, The Dead Are Arising provides information that even Manning Marable couldn't unearth before the publication of A Life of Reinvention and his death: the names of Malcolm'

A very even handed look at a very intersting life. I was 13 when Malcom X died and he was a figure that was difficult for white Americans to understand and certain difficuot to embrace. This terrific biography explains how he arrived at being a black activist after a very difficuot childhood laced with discrimination and violence. This was a complicated man, not all good, and certainly not all bad.
His leadership qualities were amazing. His downfall was seperating from the Nation of Islam's forma

The premier and seminal biography of American hero Malcolm X. This biography has the depth, breadth, and sensitivity of a classic. Finally, a biography that contextualizes events of Malcolm's life, 'connects the dots' for nonhistorian readers, and examines the personality of Malcolm without sweeping his faith under the rug. Throw out all your other biographies of Malcolm.

i only read through when he went on the hajj as I just cant bear what leads up to the assassination. The biography very much fills in a lot of questions I had about his early life and 'awakening' so to say and doesnt diminish the autobiography at all (which I think is a masterpiece of the genre). His assassination is so depressing to me

Terrific, insightful book. Especially strong on his family, the death of his father, and early years in Boston. The chapters on his meeting with the Klan, at Elijah Mohammed's behest, and his execution were excellent. A balanced, informed, and interesting read. The focus on his youth and early criminal years is especially welcome as new material is uncovered and investigated in some detail.

Enjoyed Marable's biography more but the details given about Malcom X's early life and his assassination are unparalleled and obvious that this is the most thorough recounting of both ends of his life.
SM
Several years ago I realized I knew very little about Malcolm X - this well written, well researched biography proved to be an excellent introduction. Highly recommend.
Astonishing!! Many new findings
MALCOLM X WHAT AWESOME MAN LOVE YOU MY KING.
A remarkable biography, beautifully written and based on exciting new source material.
After reading this book, it feels like in some ways, I know less about Malcolm X than when I started.

This lovely book tells the story of Audrey Hepburn from the point of view of Audrey as a child. We learn about her early days, the time she moved to Netherlands and the difficult days of "the Occupation" when she and her family, as well as so many people, had to struggle to live with little food, and how they had to hide in their cellars meanwhile the planes were dropping bombs. Little Audrey starts to daydream of the things she'd like to do, such as becoming a prima ballerina, singing and actin

This is a charming little book about the life of Audrey Hepburn written by one of her sons. I loved the illustrations and the message it conveys about girls being able to be anything they want when they grow up. I recommend it to anyone who wants to learn more about Audrey Hepburn in a simplified way, or to anyone who wants to share their love for Audrey with children. Thank you to Princeton Architectural Press and NetGalley for providing me with an advance copy in exchange for a review.

A pretty pleasant – and certainly pretty – look at Audrey Hepburn. With the structure of this book we see her wartime childhood, from when she was born in Belgium to the Nazi Occupation of Holland. We also see a life of instant fame with the movie Roman Holiday, and all the rest, and a great maternal spirit, and work in war-hit countries around the world – but the change in font, and the title of the piece, show this might not be the reality we know her to have had. The lesson, then, that dreams

Little Audrey's Day


Dream by Sean & Karin Hepburn Ferrer is a children's book absolutely tender.

Published by Princeton Architectural Press this children's book tell the story of one of most legendaries Hollywood's actresses: Audrey Hepburn, but...The story of this actress being told in a very delicate way, for being understood by children, at the end will be something else: the totality of her existence hasn't been after all fame and glory, received because she was immensely talented, but her ow

'Little Audrey's Daydream' by Sean and Karin Hepburn Ferrer with illustrations by Dominique Corbasson and Francois Avril is a picture book about a seemingly storybook life.

Told in the first person, this is the story of Audrey Hepburn, born in Brussels, Belgium in 1929. She lived through World War II, and even worked as a spy. She became a famous actress, and then a humanitarian.

It's such a beautiful story. I could hear Audrey Hepburn's voice reading it in my head. The illustrations are exquisite

Lovely illustrations, and the author did a great job of condensing Audrey Hepburn's life. I don't know if it was because I was reading an ARC and the formatting was slightly off on my Kindle, but I felt the book needed better transitions. There were times I was not sure if events were her "daydreams" or supposed to be happening in real time.

I definitely teared up a little with this one! Such a beautiful retelling of Audrey's life, in a way that even a child can understand. I loved reading this to my nieces and then introducing them to one of my favorite actresses. A timeless beauty that has done so much good in the world, I love that this was created so we can share it with future generations.

What a great story . I think it will inspire young girls to follow there dreams. Whether to be a mom, an actress, humanitarian. I love that such a historic women is portrayed as strong, We often remember Audrey for he simple beauty and style but she was so much more. I would defiantly recommend this book for elementary aged girls. It's really a lovely memoir, #LittleAudreysDaydream #NetGalley

Thank you to the publisher and netgalley for the opportunity to read and review this book. I honestly did not know much about Audrey Hepburn before this book. Even though it is a children's book I learned quite a bit. The illustrations were just gorgeous! Definitely recommend.

Darling pictures, short summary of Audrey's biography by her first son.
Touches on war, hunger, etc. without getting too dark for kids.

A well presented book, I knew a bit about Chicago’s great fire from documentaries and self learning, but this book really did teach me a lot I didn’t know, it was well written, it really did keep you interested and included maps and great photographs, cuttings that make the book even more interesting, a fantastic historical guide

Thanks to netgalley and the publisher for a free copy for an honest opinion

Having parents born in Chicago with many family members and friends still there, I had to request to read this. I knew a little bit about the devastating fire but it was nice to learn more in depth what happened. I ,made many highlights for future reading pertaining to the fire including newspaper articles and scholarly documents, all these were appreciated. I am definitely looking forward to continued reading about this event in Chicago's history.

The book itself? It is all about the details and
Another great Chicago book about the Great Fire! But, it isn't just another book- this one stands head and shoulders above the other half dozen or so that I've read. Well, worth my time!

Carl Smith has written a very extensive history of the fire that destroyed a large part of Chicago back in 1871. He wrote about the origin of the fire and how many escaped the conflagration, which made this story come alive even more. And the story didn't end there.
Mr. Smith writes about the relief efforts and the generosity of the many people, US cities and countries that raised money and donations of food and clothing for the people of Chicago who lost their homes, belongings and their liveli

I love historical non-fiction books and this was an enjoyable read! It is very thorough and well researched and will leave you not simply thinking of Mrs. O'Leary's cow and the unproven belief that this was the source of the fire but also the hysteria immediately after, of the recovery, its' role in fire codes, the profiteers who sought to benefit, and of course the inevitable politics that brought grandstanding.

While not told in a narrative style as some of my favorite historical non-fiction b

Carl Smith has done extensive research to get to know Chicago at the time before/during/after the Great Fire. He even knows the details of where the O'Leary's children were baptized and attended school! Research like this allows me to just read how ALL the facts intermingle at this devastating time in Chicago's history, and not worry if I'm missing facts. If you want the insight on all things Chicago Fire, you have it in this one location.

Smith's writing is clear and concise. He has no ax to gri

My great-great grandparents lived in Chicago in the 1870s in the area where the fire started and I've always been interested in its history. This book is fascinating and very informative. It's more than just a recounting of the fire itself. The author explains the political and social attitudes of the city at the time. This gives you a feel for the era and the circumstances that contributed to the fire.

He also covers the period after the fire which brought aid from around the world along with p

Having family ties to Chicago I grew up with the usual story about Mrs. O'Leary's cow. What I never knew beyond that has been remedied by this fascinating book. Now I know the kind of life Kate and Patrick O'Leary lived, how their neighbors lived and how the way Chicago was constructed led to it's destruction. This is the way to learn history - from a historian who can write in such a way that the facts come alive. I wish more history came in this form. Looking ahead at my list of birthday and C

A huge thank you to NetGalley and Atlantic Monthly Press for the Advanced Release Copy in exchange for my honest review.

I am a sucker for non-fiction historical books. I especially have a propensity for books about tragedies and disasters as sad as that is. The research that Carl Smith put into this was extensive.

You receive a great history of the city itself, its socioeconomic history, as well as, an interesting history of Firefighting in America. It also tells the story of the city's resilien

Enjoyable, informative book

I enjoyed this book. I wasn’t familiar with Chicago when I started the book and I was concerned that I would be spending a lot of time looking things up. I was wrong. There are several maps in the book that helped me along. Along with the maps, were some amazing photographs. In addition, I liked Carl Smith’s conversational writing style, all of which helped make the book a thoroughly enjoyable and informative read. I recommend it for anyone interested in Chicago and/or

A historical gem told with Frank honesty that puts you right into that incredible moment of Chicago history. Here is a story that has never been told so completely and with so much detail. The writing itself is engaging and stays that way, so you don't for one minute think you are reading a boring historical tome. It will keep you turning the pages and caring about the people who went through the tremendous ordeal of The Great Chicago Fire. You need to read this one.

Well done historical piece with many photographs culled from numerous historical societies and museums. It is also a social history detailing the many immigrants and the why and origins deciding where they would settle. the history of firefighting in America was more than interesting with all the numbers provided. It is a celebration of a city that literally rose from it's own ashes.
I requested and received a free ebook copy from Grove Atlantic via NetGalley. Thank you!

The most recent serious study of this catastrophic event is well-written and in time for the sesquicentennial of the Great Chicago Fire in 2021. Smith manages to bring a fresh perspective to this well-told story, has done a thorough job of combing through the eye witness accounts, and debunks long-held myths and tales about this seminal occurrence. Anyone with an interest in Chicago history will want to read this.

A very well presented book, I knew very little about Chicago’s great fire, This book really did teach me a lot, it was well written, it really did keep you interested and included maps and great photographs that make the book even more interesting, a fantastic historical guide. For those who are interested in history it is a very enjoyable read.

I am from Chicago, so I was excited to read this book. I am glad I did, too. It was a fabulous accounting of the Great Fire. It is such a detailed writing of this huge event in the history of Chicago. The pictures, along with the maps, are fantastic. It helps to see how huge this was in Chicago. It was very well written and really kept my attention. I loved it. I highly recommend this book!

Amazing to see how little people have changed in 150 years.

Recommend
Great for those who want to know more, like Chicago and/or its history. From where it started and how it spread, to who possibly started it. A good look at that day and the days following.

Lincoln’s Lie is a thrilling dive into the little-known, darker side of a revered president’s history: It untangles the threads behind a mysterious 1864 newspaper article to reveal how Lincoln manipulated the media during the Civil War. This book speaks powerfully to our current political crises: fake news, profiteering, Constitutional conflict, and a president at war with the press.

Lincoln's Lie is a terrific voyage into a distant time, bizarrely parallel to today. Lincoln had more dramatic conflicts than merely fighting the confederates. His character is revealed in both tender and harsh ways. Constitution be damned! I had no idea that Wall Street malfeasance was so central to the evolution of the Civil War. Telegraph and the press were the media of the time, steering events with the smell of self-interest, even potentially dooming the north. Dishonest behavior, who cares
Absolutely great! New perspective!

Thank you to NetGalley and Counterpoint Press for an Advanced Readers Copy in exchange for an honest review.

This book gave a great retelling of Lincoln and his relationship with the press. It read like a novel, so it would be good for even a casual reader of history to pick up. This isn't a story that's often told, so history buffs would love it too. Even though these events happened 150 years ago, Mitchell's writing makes this seem timely and relevant. I would recommend it to anyone who asks.

Lincoln's Lie is a story I had never heard of before and was a picture of Lincoln that had never been presented. In May 1864 a hoax was played on some newspapers in New York. Late a night after the last of the news stories had come in and the papers were going to print a proclamation from Lincoln arrived at several newsrooms. Once of the newsrooms printed it. Lincoln was requesting an extra 400K men or a draft would be called. The Battle of the Wilderness had just been fought and this proclamati
Hysterical. Sad. Poignant. Worth the wait.

I really don't understand why people are getting upset about the publish date. I consider her first book one that changed my life. It made me laugh, cry and gave me a better understanding of myself dealing with depression and anxiety. I am just so thankful that she has another one in the works and would happily wait years to experience another one of her pieces. Be patient my friends. I have no doubt that it will be worth the wait.

How am I just hearing about this?

Not until next year...

I'm leaving this unrated (for now) because I feel conflicted. As you may or may not know, I leave books unrated when I feel that no rating properly reflects my feelings.

This book started out amazingly. I was so, so excited to read more of Allie Brosh's work as Hyperbole and a Half is one of my all time favorite books and I have reread it so many times. My body was literally quivering with excitement and joy.

The first couple stories were hilarious as in made me literally laugh out loud hilarious

--She has redirected her efforts into public speaking and abandoned her blog.

So...DANG.

Maybe. Sorry Allie Brosh. But at the very bare minimum I can't be forced in any way to un-read this book.

When considering what to write in this review, I had a lot of thoughts floating around in my head akin to, “a book doesn’t HAVE to funny to be good, you just made a pre-assumption the author is funny,” “it’s not up to you to decide how someone gets to describe their experiences,” etc. Which are both true. But they also obscured the fact that, at the end of the day, I didn’t enjoy Solutions and Other Problems very much.

I wanted to. Oh, how I wanted to. Like every other person and their mother on

I had this long conversation with a friend of mine today about the need we all seem to have for answers. We call it different things but it all sort of boils down to this weird, innate need to understand what in the hell we're meant to be doing here. We, as a species, really can't seem to bear the idea that there isn't some grand plan in place that would explain the casual suffering, the loneliness, the soul destroying pain we all suffer through. We do not under any circumstances want to confron

This is finally ACTUALLY happening. I've been waiting so damn long for this and I'm so emotional right now. Allie Brosh is literally a huge part of why I'm still on this planet today. If you'll all excuse me, I'm going to go sob for a while. 😭💖

I hope you will allow me to tell a little story here. Some years back, I was going through a bad time with my mental health. It’s been, what feels like a lifelong struggle, but this was a particularly rough period. I had been in the hospital and was then moved to a sort of group home to recover more. One of the counselors there had two stories by Allie Brosh printed out and we read them as part of a group activity. They were about depression and were real and sad and funny.

I felt seen. Like som

I really hate to say this (and I see I'm going to be in the overwhelming minority here) but I didn't care for this book nearly as much as the first one. I got halfway through before realizing most of the stories felt "meh". Made it 3/4ths of the way through before putting it down yesterday. And I honestly had no interest in finishing it but did for the sake of review.

Every. Single. Story in the first book is either hilarious or sad & hilarious. Most of the stories in this one are "okay" and for
I want this ALOT.

This book arrived at my doorstep and I almost couldn’t believe it. It’s real? Like, for real real? Because, like other lovers of the hilarious graphic memoir “Hyperbole and a Half,” I had abandoned any hope of a sophmore book years ago. But then I discovered “Solutions and Other Problems” the day before publication and 24 hours later was chuckling along once again with Allie Brosh, in awe that this moment had come. I’d forgotten how much I’d missed her work.

I don’t think this book was as good as

I hope it doesn't take another seven years before we see her next book, but I can wait. She's not only a little bit insane, she's also brilliant.

I read Hyperbole and a Half at a time when I didn’t know I was depressed, but I found the comics ~relatable~ and funny. Now, I am fully aware, and Allie Brosh has crushed my heart to pieces again.

Solutions and Other Problems is so potent. It is, at times, the view inside my own brain. But also not. Brosh had a lot of terrible life experiences in the years between her first book and this one, out in September. She lays it all bare, alongside some fun comics about being a weird kid and having

I've been waiting for this book for so long, and I don't think it could have come at a more perfect (or needed) time. Allie Brosh opened my eyes with Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened so many years ago, and while this tome is definitely tinged with more darkness, it a worthy successor.

Now that I'm a mother to two of my own impetuous children who, while not probably quite on the "Richard" level of creepy, definitely give

I think it's safe to say a lot has happened to Allie Brosh in the seven years everyone I know spent going, "Man, I just hope Allie Brosh is doing well, wherever she is." And this book really peels back the layers on that -- there are funny chapters and heartrending chapters and chapters that talk about truly awful things in small, simple sentences that sit there in your head like a rock.

Basically, this book is a testament to the power of keeping on, even when things are awful, and also on being

Absolutely worth the wait, and everyone's going to connect with a different story here. Favorites of mine that had me cackling included "Cat," "Richard," "Bananas," and "Loving Kindness." There is, in the middle of the book, the big "what happened to Allie in the last 7 years," which some of us who are periodic Googlers of her to make sure she's been okay know, but for many others, it'll be clear why she completely disappeared.

I loved this and I loved laughing, but I will say the unpopular thing

I feel bad giving this graphic novel such a low rating, especially when considering all the author went through since she published her first book, some of the traumatic events detailed in this one. I liked her first book very much as it achieved a fine balance between sadness and lightheartedness that seems to be lacking in this current book. For the most part, this book was a downer, even when the author was relating stories that were supposed to be funny. Not much of it was humorous to me, an

The long-awaited follow up to "Hyperbole and a Half" is at times funny, at times heartbreaking, and at times muddled. I think if you are looking for a "spiritual sequel" to Hyperbole and a Half or a book with the same well-cultivated, insightful humor and insight on childhood, adulthood and even serious topics like depression, you may be disappointed.

Considering the events in the author's private life which occurred in between the book's initial conception and the final release date, it is not s

I suspect many people will say this book isn't coherent or that it's a little bit all over the place, and that may be true but it is also exactly what the book intends to be. The whole point here is for Brosh to throw some not-entirely-coherent feelings at us and she makes that quite clear up front. Wanting something focused and clear isn't really in keeping with a book that is about how everything is actually terrible and random and now what do we do once we realize that?

If you have wondering w

Five years ago, I was given a pre-order of this for my birthday, because of course I was looking forward to another Brosh book like anything. I am sorry that life got so very much in the author's way, although I think we're all painfully aware of how that can happen. If just about the only good thing to come out of 2020 is the new releases, still that's a lot of good.
I am eager to dive in, but I am waiting until Saturday morning when I can look forward to lots of reading time unimpeded by work

After a seven year absence, Allie Brosh returns with a whopping 500 pages of illustrated essays that range from hysterical to heartbreaking.

Brosh made a name for herself with Hyperbole and a Half, her website-turned-book of autobiographical essays/comics. Not only were the essays funny and occasionally poignant, but their MSPaint illustrations added a layer of fun to them.

Solutions and Other Problems is the follow-up fans have been waiting for. None of the humor has been lost(her pets are still

I read Hyperbole and a Half when it was a blog and bought the first book gleefully when it came out. I reread several stories so many times (The Year Kenny Loggins Ruined Christmas and The Scariest Story were my favorites) for various reasons related to my own childhood, I guess. I didn't preorder this one when it was first announced, but I do remember seeing the release date stretch on and on, and I remember how sad I was. I googled "what happened to allie brosh" more than once since she disapp

Looks like I'm the dissenter on this one.

Hyperbole and a Half was, by turns, poignant, clever, insightful, and gut-bustingly funny. Some of the best sections involved the author discussing her battle with depression. While painful to read, there was a stunning clarity to the work. Through anecdotes and analogies, Brosh painted a comprehensible picture of a land which, thank God, I've never had to visit.

It's fairly clear, from the content of Solutions and Other Problems, that Brosh's life has tak

I tried I tried I tried to pace out the reading of this, to savor it, but two days was the best I could do.

However, that's okay. There's so much here that I know I will be revisiting. Some chapters are so funny I was nearly crying. Others are so sad that I'm still sitting with the weight of them. Brosh writes about death, isolation, loneliness, pointlessness. This is, somehow, a very 2020 book, despite being seven years in the making.

I said in my review for a 2019 reread of Hyperbole and a Half
*pterodactyl screeching*

30% the funniest things I have read in years, 70% absolutely devastating emotional stuff, I feel like I’ve been blended.

Note that it goes pretty hard into grief (death of a sibling), nihilism, references to divorce and serious chronic illness. The author is very clearly writing out of being super depressed and having some seriously bad things happen, and while I found most of that extremely relatable it might be more depressing for you.

Pictures definitely worth a thousand words and there are 1

Just like Hyperbole and a Half, this collection is full of stories that had me laughing out loud only to be suddenly hit over the head with emotion and gut wrenching feelings of identification. She has a way of describing feelings in a way that drill right to the heart. I told myself I would read a chapter or two a day to savor this, but I think I secretly knew I would read it all in o

3.5 stars

Who has not seen the comics/stories by Allie Brosh? Case in point:

I was a follower of her blog, which is also the title of her first book (Hyperbole and a Half) and loved her work. But then she practically disappeared right when her book became a best seller. It was strange and worrying. This second book explains a lot about why she seemingly fell off the face of the earth for years, and well, it's not a humorous story unfortunately for her. And it's also a little unfortunate for the re
Her last book was one one my absolute favorites. Can't wait for this one.
I finished and immediately wanted to read it again. I probably will. I don’t know how to put into words how this made me feel. But I do know that I loved it.
I MISSED ALLIE SO MUCH. I’m so glad she’s okay.

Back in 2013, Allie Brosh published Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened named after the blog she kept (and has finally updated with a new post!). I pre-ordered the last book and bought it as a Christmas present for pretty much every single person my husband and I knew that year (now our own copy seems to have mysteriously gone missing - which distresses me). Allie's blog (we are clearly on first-name basis, and would be g

As a huge fan of Hyperbole and a Half, I had to read this and love it. I just love Brosh’s unassuming sense of humor and hilarious drawings. The reflection of her weird labyrinthine mind on the pages, her fun childhood memories, unique visualization skills and imagination create yet another fascinating book. However, if I hadn’t read the previous book and thought of this as a standalone, maybe I would have liked it better but I know the author’s potential and what she’s capable of and that’s why

I loved Hyperbole and a Half, but this follow-up stumbled too much for me.

I enjoyed the first 150 pages pretty well despite a long and useless (day)dream sequence, but then the blocks of teeny-tiny typeset text started multiplying in frequency and size during a nothing story about cross-country skiing and arguments. More and more little words saying nothing much of anything. And then I started gritting my teeth every time those blocks came back throughout the rest of the books.

After the touching

I kept trying to walk away from this book because I wanted it to last.

I want(ed) more of a 514 page book.

You know the Leonard Cohen quote about a crack in everything?

This book is the crack in 2020 that will have lifted me enough to keep me going.

That is all.
weird, wholesome, and SO funny. allie brosh is doin it like no one else.
Allie Brosh's brain is fascinating. (Also, it really sounds like she's had a shitty past few years.) I'm going to be thinking about the Bananas chapter for a very long time.

Solutions and Other Problems by Allie Brosh is so terrific! I loved the first book and this one is just as good! Laugh out loud funny in spots to deep heart warming in others. Loved the clever and hilarious cartoons graphics! The cartoons alone are quite a hoot!

Solutions and Other Problems, Allie Brosh’s follow-up to her critically acclaimed first book, Hyperbole and a Half, had a lot to live up to.  Like many people, I’ve been waiting for this book for years.  The book had been plagued with delays leaving her readers believing that the book may never actually see the light of day.

Then, out of nowhere, the book was scheduled for release in September of 2020.  Finally!  Something good in this horror show of a year.  However, as the content of the book s

This book is for the goofy blob people we were ten years ago who are now facing or have already faced really hard things.

I think many longtime fans of Brosh knew that the reasons for the book's delay and anticipated some of its content being different as a result, and like many, I'm just so grateful that it exists, and that Allie exists with us still. This book is different from the first -- less "adulting! i am the god of cake!" and more "mortality and loss and complex human loneliness o no" --

I laughed, I cried, and I felt very seen by this book. At the end of the day, Brosh is a master at communicating the sheer absurdity of life. She captures the way things can feel pointless, meaningless, and unfair even as we have to continue moving forward.

ebook

Harder to love than the first one. An intimate look at a gal who has had more than her share of trouble coping with the way her brain works. In some ways, I'm sure we can all relate, and in other ways, I'm sure we all say "thank goodness I'm not that confused/ disturbed/ ill."

But it's not exploitive or anything, not a daytime talk show confessional. It's glorious, heartbreaking, gorgeous, funny, and incredibly illuminating.

I feel as if I know myself and my loved ones better now, even those

I have never laughed so hard while being told repeatedly that life is meaningless and terrifying. Allie Brosh is a treasure and I hope she gets everything she wants. I'm not sure if I'm supposed to identify with Squirrel, the cat in an obsessive relationship with a mouse friend who is actually made of cloth, but I did. Hard. Also, it turns out if you are extraordinarily imaginative and perhaps prone to obsessive thoughts, as Brosh may be, a simple lovingkindness meditation can really spiral out

One of my favorite reads of 2020. Poignant, hilarious, tragic, and above all, extremely brave. Brosh gives you glimpses into her life since she all but disappeared years ago. She tells some, giving stunning glimpses, but she holds so much back. And that's a wonder. You can feel like you are inside her mind, but her privacy and reclusive nature keep you at arm's length. It's intimate and mysterious. But most of the chapters made me laugh out loud at least once, while one story had me laughing so

This book while not as tremendously funny as Hyperbole and a Half, it was excellent.

There's a lot of feeling in this book, I laughed and cried. I can't imagine living through everything she lived through, and still come out on the other side.

I would still highly recommend this book to people who enjoyed her first book.
Hilarious in spots, but mostly heartbreaking all the way through.

Allie Brosh is one of the only people who can write a book and make me laugh out loud. I’m so glad that she was able to finish this despite going through the worst period of her life. It's full of both sad and hilarious stories, but my favorites were the hangry banana fight and pile dog.

I got this in the mail when I was about 15 pages from finishing another 400 page book. I decided I’d just take a peek and I read almost half of this in one sitting. I highly recommend picking this up if you’re go

I have waited so long for new content from Allie Brosh and I am most happy that she is still here and still writing. However, I felt a lot of these stories felt like they would just stop at the end of a chapter right when I was getting fully invested in where that tale was going. But I definitely laughed and got choked up while reading and so it was still time well spent. Poop Mystery alone!
I read this in one sitting. It’s fantastic.
So funny it had me laughing out loud and also so, so dark, this is a weird little book and I would expect nothing less from Allie Brosh.
YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS

Allie Brosh makes me feel seen. Her work is definitely something that anyone can appreciate and enjoy, but she writes about depression and anxiety (without always naming them as such) in a way that feels like home. Someone else out there gets how it's both simple and complex, crushing and absurd. Also, "The Poop Mystery" is the funniest thing I've read in a long time.

I’m so glad another Allie Brosh book is in the world! I laughed so hard I cried at many of these stories, and I forced my coworkers to read or listen to me read them. She’s at her funniest when she’s writing about her childhood or writing about animals. I love the kooky sentence structure she uses as she imagines what they’re thinking.

There’s been a lot of sadness in Brosh’s life in the years since her last book came out. She writes about that too, so not all the chapters are a laugh riot. The

It's a semi long story, but I got up at 4am to get this book and read it before it's actual release. I'm dog tired (whatever that means) and it was worth every moment of sleep deprivation.

Allie (much like Tina Belcher) is my spirit animal. We speak the same language. The language of, lets discuss this deep topic and also farts. I read her first book during a bout (if you call roughly 2 years a 'bout') of depression and it brought me joy. I read her words now, at my most joyous and it still does

This is much more melancholy than the first book (for very understandable reasons), which means that it wasn't quite as funny. (Although I did laugh out loud in many places.) Mostly I'm giving this a four rather than a five because a lot of the chapters end very abruptly, almost as if they've cut off rather than come to a natural ending point. That did grate on me after a (very short) while, and ultimately curtailed my enjoyment of the book.

No real surprise that this was exactly the hilarious, heartwarming, relatable, and emotional storytelling style that is uniquely Allie Brosh.

I'd first like to express my infinite gratitude to meera for informing me that this book was going to be released, thus giving me the biggest boost of serotonin I've had in over six months. I think allie brosh is a genius and it's very comforting to know that we're both little absurdist creatures experiencing life and fucking shit up. I haven't read a book book in months. Not all summer. Yes, I've been reading a bunch of graphic novels/manga (I have a huge backlog of titles to log here—and the longer I put them off, the worse it gets), but nothing that's, like, a novel or anything.

All that changed late last week when a friend shared a link to Allie Brosh's blog (hyperboleandahalf, of course) where there was an update about a new book. I started crying.

It's a complicated set of emotions. On the one hand, I don't know author Al

I excitedly pre-ordered this the second I saw a September 2020 release date. I've always loved the Hyperbole and a Half blog, and seeing that this was able to come together after all of this time made me so happy (and hopeful that the author was doing better).

There are very few books that are actual "laugh out loud" types, but this is one of them. My boyfriend was on the other side of the room trying to concentrate on some particularly challenging Magic the Gathering games, and I was shaking wi

Gosh, I adore Allie Brosh.

I have loved her ever since 2010, when I stumbled across her Hyperbole and a Half blog and proceeded to laugh so hard I sounded like I was sobbing over something heartbreaking. Her words brought so many giggles into my world when I was most in need of them, and when she disappeared for several years, I thought of her every so often and hoped she was happy.

Solutions and Other Problems shows us that Allie has had a rough seven years, and my heart goes out to her - and al

I liked a lot of Solutions and Other Problems. Looking back at my review of Hyperbole and a Half, I see that I really didn't enjoy that one. Not sure if it was my head space a year ago when I read that or if this book is that much better but Brosh is a great storyteller and while the style is a bit unexpected compared to the typical graphic novel (large blocks of text!), everything works together somehow. The crude drawings compliment the text really well and make for a quick read and enjoyable

OMG, could it be that 2020 will finally offer something good? That there will be one small ray of hope, one little piece of enjoyment this year? AND, just in time for the inevitable dumpster fire that will be the election? Will I really have something meaningful, poignant, and hilariously touching in my hands to help me get through that?

Well, apparently so. And I guess that all I have to say is this: whatever workings in the universe delayed this book so long, that's ok, I'm not mad at all, bec

Here are the major themes of this book:

-There’s no underlying purpose to the things that happen to us
-We are powerless, though we trick ourselves into thinking we have some level of control in our lives
-MORTALITY!!!!
-Life is unfair, and that’s just the way it is

All this nihilism is colored by Brosh’s trademark wit and humor, but there’s no denying that this book is significantly darker than her first. And who can blame her? She doesn’t talk about her trials in huge amounts of depth, but Brosh

Brosh has famously been absent from the internet (at least publicly) since 2013. Solutions and Other Problems chronicles the whys and hows of that, without feeling as though we’ve been given too much access. We do get a view into her life, and more specifically her worldview, and all that’s changed and evolved since last we saw her. In some ways reading this felt like sitting down with a friend I hadn’t seen in a long time and just having an in-depth rambly conversation for a few hours to get ca

The existence of this book makes me so happy. The existence of Allie, too.

There are funny chapters, sad chapters, weird chapters, weird funny sad chapters. There's an explanation why Allie disappeared for so long and my immense happiness at her return. So much has happened, decades ago and months ago. It feels like being reunited with your best friend in the world ever (the final chapter talks about Allie's best friend in the world ever), demanding a COMPLETE update on everything, and getting it

The book is like asking a friend how they're doing and they tell you, and it's not good, and you feel so bad for them, but you were really hoping they were doing better and that they'd cheer YOU up, and you realize no, you need to be there for THEM.

If you want to know how Allie Brosh has been doing, this book will tell you. It won't make you laugh much, but it'll make you think, and probably worry.

I have such mixed feelings that I can't rate it. Am I glad I read it? Yes, because I loved "Hyper

Is it totally worth it to wait so long for more from Allie, known for her Hyperbole and a Half?

It certainly is just as batsh*t crazy, if not more so, then her first book.

In this one, she deals with being alone, and I’m sure that is why it took so long to pull this book out of her. Humor as sort of therapy. Humor in sadness. Even though her drug trip in the countryside is funny, it is also sad. Even though her thoughts about having to make friends with herself, since she was all alone are quite

(c/p from my review on TheStoryGraph) Oh my gosh y'all. I know we've been waiting for this book for a very long time and I know saying "It was worth the wait" is cliché as all hell but! I am just so happy this book exists in the world. At once both so funny I almost dropped the book a few times and so deep and sad that I cried into its pages. There is so much hope and humor inside these pages. It feels like talking to a friend you haven't seen in awhile but still 100% gets you and you get them.

It's here!

Fans of Hyperbole and a Half have been waiting too long for the newest book, and it was worth the wait. This book is filled with ridiculous tales of Allie Brosh's life, like how she got stuck in a bucket and how she stole her neighbor's cat, all hilariously and horribly illustrated in Paint (which adds to the comedy).

She again deals with more serious subjects throughout, which help explain her long absence from the internet and the delay of this book, like her divorce and loss of her s

I can pretty much copy my review of Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened verbatim: "Uneven, but generally amusing and sometimes laugh-out-loud funny." I'm giving this one fewer star due to fewer laugh-out-loud moments and a couple sections that were legitimately disturbing. Still recommended for all fans of the first book.

Hyperbole and a Half is one of my all-time favorite books and for years I've waited for Allie Brosh to write/draw another book, as she went through some very difficult times in her personal life. This is it - hilarious because it's all so true; just as off-kilter as the first; with illustrations that make me howl.

I love Allie Brosh and her humor and her art. I love her fearlessness and willingness to talk about the hard stuff. I wanted Solutions and Other Problems to be as funny as Hyperbole and a Half, but at the end of the day I guess this book is more about what Brosh needed to get on paper.

It would probably have been 5 stars except I couldn’t handle the format. A hardback? With a real spine? Printed on heavy-ass paper because it’s an art book? It makes zero sense. I wanted to crack the spine to be a

Hyperbole and a Half is one of my favorite books of all time. I followed the blog before the book came out, and I reread both the blog and the book whenever I need a laugh. Solutions and Other Problems has been on my Goodreads shelves since 2016, and since then, I've checked the blog every couple of months to see if there were any updates.

As many stars as she wants!It was well worth the wait.There is a very helpful q and a on the back page which clarifies everything in the book.All authors should be forced to do the same.She has overcome her depression by giving herself prestigious awards such as...(see back book flap).The introduction was as original as any I have read.So was the entire book.I even enjoyed the acknowledgements.Which rarely happens.I will now wait patiently for her next book.Hurry Allie.

4,5*

No one can do funny & depressing like Allie Brosh. Hyperbole and a Half is one of my favourite books ever and Solutions and Other Problems is another masterpiece. This book feels a bit more grown up and cohesive than Hyperbole, although nothing can top that one for me. I wish nothing but the best for you, Allie!

*Disclaimer* I received this book through a GoodReads giveaway. It's only the second giveaway I have won, but I am certain it will be the best.

I don't have a rating just yet, because I'm only halfway done. I read the first half in a couple of hours, but I have to step away for a bit. Having a dead sister myself, the Dead Sister chapter has destroyed me. I'm going to take several days of deep breaths then pick it back up.

——-

Ok, it’s been 6 days and I've finished. Allie has always been very open a

I was cracking up during the first half of this book, and really saw more of Allie's struggle through the second half. Working through the death of a loved one is extremely hard, and the struggle with fear really resonated with me. Same with dealing with being alone.

Allie can really cut to the core of weird thoughts and ideas and I think a lot of people can benefit from seeing that on a page.

The only review I can think of is just a series of emojis that are like sobbing, cry-laughing, laughing, heartbroken, heart, hug. I'm not entirely sure I can put into words how this book made me feel. Amused, sad, shocked, confused, bewildered, rolling on the floor laughing, deep introspection - sometimes all at the same moment.

This book really drives home the point that life is absurd. Sometimes it is absurdly silly. Sometimes it is absurdly sad. Always though, it is absurd.

This is a brilliant follow to her first book, and is something I think everyone should read.

4.5? 5 stars?

I laughed so hard I was wheezing for air at some points, at another I was crying into my scrambled eggs. I had what the absolute heck moments and moments of thank goodness someone else thinks these things too.

My husband keeps asking me why I’m laughing. I show him a picture and he’s like “what?” I just say “it’s hard to explain”. And continue laughing out loud.

I’m glad I’m not the only one laughing as the weird thing is this book is sad. The honesty is what makes me smile. Thank you, Allie

Okay, the first half of the book wasn’t as good as Hyperbole and a Half but at least I had a few good laughs and some explanations about the 7 years delay of the new book which is something.

This is one of the few good things to come out of 2020. I needed this.

I love (and really respect) Allie Brosh. I want to give Allie a big hug and then take her on a picnic. Some of the chapters were absolutely heartbreaking, some were hilarious, but all were heartfelt and honest.

Charming and weird

While not as entertaining as her first book, this was still a solid go. Her artwork amuses. Her topics delightfully random. But I could put the book down easily. That's a 4 star for me.
I had been waiting a long time for this to be published and it was well worth the wait, equal parts heartbreaking and hilarious.
I laughed and I cried and I was very sad when it was over.

Take every single expectation you've built up for this 'Hyperbole and a Half' follow up over the past seven years and forget all of them. The pile dog was a silly-looking animal. We had to cut eyeholes in her fur so she could see. It made her look way creepier than would be ideal, but you can’t let your dog be blind just because it looks creepy when you can see its eyes.

This appeared on my Kindle at midnight and I had forgotten about it but then I obviously had to stay up ridiculously late reading the whole thing from front to back. Arthur also had to stay up ridiculously late because I could not. Stop. Laughing.

Oof.

Allie chooses to utilize her impressive artistic talents by drawing in a crude (yet surprisingly effective) style best described as “MS Paint,” which fools the reader into expecting content reflective the lighthearted style. It’s a bit of an emotional hammer, in between stories about goofy dogs and the weird kid next door.

I devoured this memoir by Chef David Chang. I have enough of a background in the culinary world to know how hard it is, how few people succeed, how easy it is to completely burn out. It can be such hard work when you're only responsible for yourself; taking on the risks of managing and opening a restaurant are unfathomable to me.

Every once in a while you find someone who despite those same struggles pulls off something amazing and changes the landscape forever, and that is this story. Even if yo

This is a fantastic memoir that is primarily about the creative spirit. David Chang is definitely an artist. I did not know much about him personally when I picked up this book, but I knew about and had been to his restaurant sensation Momofuku and was interested to learn about the man behind it. I got much more than I expected in this memoir which is honest and real and insightful into the human condition as well as food.

Just as the chef is known for his innovative and creative approaches towar

David Chang is the uber-successful head chef of many restaurants, including Momofuku, Ko, and Milk Bar. You’ve probably seen him on Netflix’s Ugly Delicious and Bravo’s Top Chef. Honestly, he’s everywhere—opening a restaurant or publishing a new cookbook like every other year. He’s a machine.

I was so excited to read his memoir, Eat a Peach. He strikes me as an intense, quiet, and interesting guy, so I was curious to know more of his story. This book isn’t what I expected it to be. In fact, it to

This is a really good celeb memoir and an excellent chef memoir. Chang does a good job with talking food insight and giving us a glimpse at his approach and thinking. He calls out his own short comings on #metoo and talks about racism in food. Overall very good. He does shy away from getting too deep on some topics though.

Disclaimer: I won a free ARC of this book in a Goodreads giveaway.

Love a good food memoir. Chang is such a fascinating figure in food and has so many relevant things to say. This didn't disappoint.
