I really don't read "celebrity" type memoirs as a rule, but I've been a fan of David Chang since my first issue of Lucky Peach arrived in 2011. It wasn't just the recipes that caught my attention (his tonkatsu-style ramen has been my go-to recipe for ten years now), but also his writing in the magazine left me entertained and informed. I wasn't "entertained" with this book (although I did laugh here and there), but most certainly informed.

(Review copy, courtesy of my very dope job)
It's unclear why, but I was expecting this to be more amusing, and honestly, more anecdotal. It felt more like a screed on how success is complicated. Which...ok?

David Chang is well known for his restaurants and his Netflix show, Ugly Delicious, and he shares his journey to his success in his book EAT A PEACH. The main focus is on his life as an adult but readers do get glimpses into his childhood as well. He comes across as open and honest in his book because he tells of his failures as well as his successes. He’s also up front about his battle with bipolar disorder. I enjoyed my time listening to the audio version (narrated by the author) and would lik

An intense and raw memoir about the journey of creating a meaningful restaurant empire against all odds. I like Dave Chang, I really enjoyed his Netflix series Ugly Delicious and it was interesting learning about Momofuku from the ground up. I wasn’t here for the name drops, they went way over my head. I was here for Dave talking openly about his serious mental health issues, getting a better perspective about how to improve his leadership within his business, becoming a husband and dad, and alw

Brutally honest and powerful. As much a memoir as it is a philosophical exploration of human frailty, mental health, obsessiveness, racism, friendship, love, and of course, food. Though I started off with the e-book, I cannot recommend the audiobook enough. I highly recommend letting David Chang read it out to you, in his no bullshit style - after all, these are his lived experiences. Wonderful!

Celebrity chef David Chang's memoir. His publisher wanted a memoir. He wanted to write a How-to-succeed-like-I-did. I'm not sure either of them won that argument. Though I do like reading books and watching shows about cooking, Chang has never been on my radar. I don't know, just didn't grab me.

I wasn't in love with this book, but the chapter entitled "33 Rules for Becoming a Chef" should be required reading for every high school and college student. It applies broadly to anyone embarking on an education or a career.

It is a memoir. Let’s get that out of the way first. But if you’re at all familiar with David Chang, this book is what you’d both expect and were hoping for: 300 pages of Chang’s quirky conversational style that simplifies complex cuisine, tying it to pop culture, food you’re familiar with and makes you want to grab a beer with the guy, even if you don’t get samples of pork belly-infused pintxo out of the deal.

Chang has established himself as a worthy successor to Tony Bourdain: if Bourdain is

Q: What's the last book that made you laugh out loud?
A: Eat a Peach by David Chang

Q: What's the last book that made you cry?
A: Eat a Peach by David Chang

I loved this book. I expected it to be good, and it far exceeded my expectations.

Chang writes with humor, pathos, and honesty. He philosophizes. He tackles mental health, racism and xenophobia (that which he has internalized and that which he has observed), familial and romantic relationships, friendship, mentorship (both being a mentor and bein

“It’s harder to unfuck yourself than it is to fuck yourself.” [from Chapter 17, 'Hyung']

The first time I heard/seen DC on the telly was almost a decade ago when 'The Mind of a Chef' was first aired. I was so intrigued by DC's eccentricities and was also quickly spellbound by most of the chefs that were introduced in the program.

I had a very high expectation of the book but I was still blown away by it. I've written lots of notes in the two days I've spent reading it because I love it so much an
Seemed more like ranting then writing. He seems utterly amazed he founded a successful restaurant because of pure luck.

This book is in the vein of ‘everyone feels they have to write a book’. It also reads rather impersonally and makes David Chang seem like a jerk. I think it’s written to temper his image of being a jerk however it doesn’t really achieve that aim. He refers to his staff almost like property and has a superior tone throughout the book. It was interesting to read some of the stories about the restaurant but I don’t think the book had to be written. The writing was dull and I think mostly written by

If you’ve never heard of David Chang or his accomplishments, it’s fine. He will fill you in on everything. Then keep telling more and more. This book seemed to me that he is trying to define his brand (Momofuku) by who he knows and other famous places where he worked or has eaten. So much name dropping and stories about “celebrity chefs” or highly rated restaurants that didn’t accumulate the accolades his restaurants did. Despite his multiple statements that his restaurants are uniquely Korean a

Vulnerable, yes. In depth, maybe not. Chang tells us, but doesn't show us, what his flaws are.
Some call Chang a bro chef, and with all the white male chefs that he name drops, the book only reinforces this. Just because later on in the book, he mentions how he wants to do better, doesn't mean much.
The footnotes seem very gimmicky, along with the chapter that he wishes he could rewrite.

I will say, it was a smooth read, probably because I just wanted to know everything that happened next.

First I would like to state that I have received this book through goodreads giveaway in exchange for an honest review. I would like to thank the author for giving me this opportunity and honor in being able to read this book. When I received this book I began reading it at once. This book was a very interesting read. It pulls you in and keeps you wanting more. I would recommend this book to others. It is a very good read

It's funny how celebrity memoirs are usually fluffy cotton candy bites of anecdotes, while Celebrity Chef memoirs are a litany of traumas. This is no exception, right out the gate we open with stories of what is now somewhat stereotyped Asian parental abuse, followed by mental illness. This felt like one of the more comprehensive memoirs I've read, talking quickly through childhood, youth sports, university then diving right into all the nitty gritty of failing/hating jobs that led him to culina

4.5 stars. I really like David Chang. That feeling has only intensified since reading this book.

I was first introduced to David Chang through his Netflix show, Ugly Delicious. I watch a lot of food programming and am picky about what I like. Chang won me over through his discussions about authenticity in ethnic food and who gets to be the authority on what is authentic. Chang's career has been subtly dedicated to subverting the norm and playing up the unexpected. He is a Korean American who make

[4,5/5 stars]

EAT A PEACH by David Chang is an honest and insightful memoir about food and Chang's life.
Starting with his childhood, Chang gives us a glimpse about his struggles regarding otherness and religion, plus his early talent with golf.
From cooking school to complex culinary dishes, there was plenty of immense effort and detailed preparations meticulously described that drew me in. We feel the tenuous balance between real world and kitchen, as it also happens in other areas of life.

I so

Reading experts on food talk about food sort of feels like listening to a really nice song in a different language. It is so pleasant!! My favorite things about it were the emphasis of his writing on process instead of outcome and the credit he gives to his community.

I never knew the descriptions associated with Michelin stars; 'a one-star restaurant as “high quality cooking, worth a stop.” Two stars is “excellent cooking, worth a detour.” And three is “exceptional cooking, worth a special jour

Coronavirus (update: Coronavirus + Rebellion 2020) book review #47 – 3.75 stars

Eat a Peach is one man’s battle with depression and anger whose workaholic tendencies to escape himself made him a superstar chef at a fairly young age. That man is David Chang, head of the Momofuku empire, and I want to eat all his food.

Kudos to David for being self-reflective on how harsh he’s treated himself and the people who have worked with him throughout his rise to stardom and yet, he’s one of those people wh

Honest and enlightening. David Chang not only deserves our respect, but also our support. He recognizes his past as imperfect, he looks back with a critical eye. How he has moved forward and fallen into the lovely life he has now is nothing short of a miracle to him. The future is bleary and certainly filled with more hurtles, challenges, and self-bettering. This is book that not only shows you the road up to now, but also let’s you gaze into the horizon with hope. That’s how it left me feeling,

I expected this book to be a fun, semi-arrogant recap of David Chang’s adventures with cooking and famous people. This book (and the chef) are so much more complex than that though — he talks in detail about his own mental health, his challenging relationship with his father, the biases he has experienced as an Asian American and how he used all that to fuel his restaurants. Parts read like a cheat code for understanding his restaurants, which is cool to get inside his mind. He’s also super hone

I’m already a big Dave Chang fan, and have always been interested in the way his brain works, and the questions he brings up. This book was right in line with what I expected, very genuine to him. The way it talks about depression and mental health is truly stunning. It made me miss the experience of eating in restaurants BAD haha. Such an interesting look at paradox, success and making your mark BECAUSE OF your pain (not in spite of it) was something I’ve heard described like this only once or
Brutally honest, deep and thought provoking. I'd probably rate it a 4.5 if I could, was great to have the audiobook narrated by David Chang as well.

I like it when an author reads his own memoir, good or bad, it's his voice. That said, I found this memoir sometimes interesting, sometimes not. I worked in the restaurant industry as a young'un when dinosaurs roamed the earth, and have read several memoirs in this vein (Kitchen Confidential, Service Included, BloodBonesButter). I've never eaten at one of David Chang's restaurants, but have seen him on my teevee and he seemed an interesting personality. I'll bet his food is spectacular. Aaannnyw

A good read for anyone who is interested in the restaurant industry and how the concept of dining out has changed in America over the past ~20yrs. Also a thoughtful discourse on mental health and obsessive compulsive disorder as it pertains to one’s career
Three Michelin stars.

I picked this up because I enjoyed Chang's philosophy about food. I kept reading because of his unflinching discussion of mental illness. Accessible and easy to read, EAT A PEACH is about running a business, building a team, and being honest to who you are.

notes compiled from a whatsapp convo (hi julia):
- david chang has a lot of personal issues (mental health, anger, etc) which he is working through and extensively references throughout the book. he also talks about his journey of reflection and self improvement. however, it didn't feel like a new perspective on any of these topics for me, because i don't think he went deep enough into his own experience. he would use the labels and mention what he was doing or what he was told he was doing, but

Book Review: Eat A Peach: A Memoir
Author: David Chang; Gabe Ulla
Publisher: Crown Publishing/Clarkson Potter
Publication Date: September 14, 2020
Review Date: April 14, 2020

I received a free copy of this book in exchange for a honest review.

From the blurb:
“From the chef behind Momofuku and star of Netflix’s Ugly Delicious—an intimate account of the making of a chef, the story of the modern restaurant world that he helped shape, and how he discovered that success can be much harder to understand t

David Chang's much-anticipated memoir was pretty good, but not great. I'll preface by saying that I don't know a lot about David Chang. I've seen a few episodes of one of his shows, Ugly Delicious, and I know of his famous noodle bar Momofuku. So I'm definitely not the target audience to read this memoir - it's written with the idea that readers will be familiar with Chang, his multitude of restaurants, his magazine, his attitudes in the kitchen, etc. I had very little prior knowledge of these t

I won an ARC in a Goodreads giveaway; this did not influence my review.

I've been familiar with David Chang for several years, and though I did not know a lot of details about him or his life, I did have a few perceptions of him - particularly as an eminently confident chef and TV personality. The reality, as Eat a Peach shows, is much more complicated. This is not your typical foodie memoir that recounts tales of learning to cook from a mother or grandmother as a small child on the perch of a st

Eat a Peach is an autobiography of David Chang and written with Gabe Ulla. It is the debut memoir from the star chef and restaurateur.

Chang, Momofuku restaurateur and star of Netflix's Ugly Delicious, starts this self-effacing, heart-on-sleeve memoir with a disclaimer about not understanding his appeal. Chang writes about being a hard-driving Korean-American kid with an anger problem who channeled his frustrations into an eagerness to test limits.

He left a soul-sucking post-college finance job a

3.5 stars, rounded up. This was much more self-aware than I would have expected from a “celebrity” memoir (although to be fair I haven’t read too much in that genre), and quite dark.

Chang’s candidness in talking about his struggles with mental illness was an unexpected highlight of the book for me. Any sense of a triumphant arc in his career is tempered by discussion of where his head was at in the given moment, and the impact of his single-mindedness on those around him. It’s not a feel-good bo

This is more than the memoir of David Chang, chef and founder of the Momofuku restaurants. Written in a very readable, honest, darkly humorous, manner, DC lays bare his mistakes, his battles with mental illness, and his struggles with his success. I also really appreciated the separate list of "33 rules for Becoming a Chef" which also contains many life lessons for us all:

"I've found that the cooks with the brightest prospects are the ones who are hardest on themselves. The trick is to direct th

I first became obsessed with the Momofuku story through milk bar, because who doesn't love birthday cake truffles. Since then I've come to be a big fan of Chang (and Tosi), and was blown away by his vulnerability and transparency in his podcast. (The episode that stands out is the conversation with Steven Yeun on being Asian American...but I digress)

Still a fan of the podcast, I first listened to the episode about the writing of this memoir, where he talks about the writing process, questions wh

This was a solid audiobook. A look into the restaurant industry and excellent for fans of Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly. One thing that stood out to me was that David Chang does a really good job of not glossing over his shortcomings as a leader, his intense mental illness, Imposter Syndrome, and anger issues. He is wonderfully candid and is very upfront about all the mistakes he has made and continues to make.

There was a brief nod to restaurant roles in #MeToo and

This is a book that I was really looking forward to reading and it did not disappoint me. I know Chef Dave Chang from watching him on the Netflix show, Ugly Delicious as well as his appearances on other food and cooking programs. This book reveals a lot about his life and about the inner workings of a startup restaurant in New York City. From this book I started listening to his podcast, The Dave Chang Show, which is also very eclectic and enlightening on a variety of topics relating to family,

I read this book so quickly. Chang writes about the Asian American, Korean American experience. He is also a celebrity chef. He is a father. He is, in his own way, an intellectual. He is an entertainer with a tv show and a podcast. He is famous. There is no other voice like his and it gives me such joy to read his book, and relate so deeply to parts of it - to relate to parts about being a child of immigrant Asian parents to being a workaholic who identifies too greatly with the act of working.

Excellent! Eat A Peach by David Chang is everything you want in a memoir. It is honest. It is insightful. It is told with humility and humor. Readers looking for a bragfest or gossipy tell-all will not find it here. Instead, readers are given an enthralling and unflinching account of Mr. Chang's struggles with mental illness, what has shaped him, and what drives him to this day. Mr. Chang also includes advice and thirty-three rules to follow if you aspire to become a chef. However, these rules c

If you've heard of David Chang, you probably remember him as the angry, screaming bro chef from his early Momofuku days. But he has really tried to transform himself and he describes his journey in this compelling memoir. He has told some of these stories and discussed his philosophies in his podcast, but this book has so much more. I particularly appreciate how he emphasizes honoring where a particular food or dish comes from culturally. I find Dave to be honest and sincere about his struggles

Four stars might be a little high, but it's a good read by a fascinating guy, looking at how his vision for food became an empire. There's very little gossip and if you're expecting a lot of insight into the food at Momofuku (and elsewhere), there's surprisingly little of that as well. This really is a memoir, a look more at Chang's struggles with depression, anger, working too much, etc. than anything else (although the tips for aspiring chefs afterword should discourage anyone from ever pursui

I’ve always loved David Chang as a food personality and public figure, even though my knowledge of cooking is primordial. Upon reading this memoir, I was skeptical as to whether or not Chang—someone with a restaurant empire and so many accolades under his belt—could write a book that was both humble and accessible to readers outside of the cooking world. The best memoirists reveal the universal through what is unknowable to readers, and that is exactly what Chang has done here. In the course of

I would say that I’ve watched all of the Netflix content with David Chang so I expected a funny, light-weight book. I am so glad it’s so much more than that!

As previous reviewers mention, Chang dives deep into his own demons and talks in-depth about his struggles with mental health. I appreciate that he neither tries to sugar-coat his thoughts nor make excuses or try to gain sympathy from the reader. A lot of his stories hit a personal note with me.

Favorite quote: “My answer is no, I don’t think

I loved this book. It's an easy, well written read by a very interesting person. It's packed with behind the scenes details and drama about the food, the shows, his famous chef friends and his family. He's very honest about his struggles with serious mental illness and how that both drove him to succeed while at the same time being responsible for much of the interpersonal conflicts that marks all areas of his life. His instant success and likability as a celebrity chef in contrast to his strugg

To me David Chang presented as such a grounded man with a million cool stories to tell. Underneath, he's a boiling inferno of anger trying to outrun imposter syndrome and mental illness.

I loved Momofoku. I never did get into the original restaurant, though did get to Milk Bar. It was one of those books that give me inspiration to cook. This book, not so much. And I'm not sure what I'm supposed to take away from this book. Maybe more sad that a man who achieved such heights into the culinary wor

This is the most honest memoir I have ever read. The candid nature with which he looks back on his past simply blew me away.

I found myself dog earring pages, and pulling the book out to quote particularly well written parts to my friends. To be clear, I finished this 2 days ago and I've been finding ways to work it into conversations since.

And the last line of the 33 things to be a chef (effectively the last thing written in the book) is simply flawless.

I don't generally like memoirs, which is

I like Dave Chang so was predisposed to be a sympathetic reader but Eat a Peach exceeded my expectations.

Finding redemption for past personal failures requires a clear reckoning and Chang airs his shortcomings without flinching or ignoring the harm to others. He provides a lucid and honest description of his own mental health challenges in a way that hopefully continues the effort to destigmatize them.

Chang also wrestles with the implications of success for someone who has always conceived of

3.5 stars. I really didn't know anything about Chang and I've never eaten at a Momofuku restaurant (though I totally would; now I'm curious). On one hand, Chang sounds like a *raging a-hole*. But he also is someone who has done a lot of therapy and is aware of it and trying to do better. Being a celebrity chef is a totally bonkers life. I thought the most interesting parts of the book (scattered throughout) were about racism, and how it plays into cooking/restaurants/dining. I appreciated his ca

(I received a free copy from Clarkson Potter in exchange for a free and unbiased review!). David Chang's memoir is pretty fascinating- hearing the creative processes behind the creation of the numerous restaurants and concepts under the Momofuku umbrella is pretty wild. Chang is honest about the things that failed and why as well as his successes. It's also honest about his mental health and the role that's played in his career. I didn't realize how far this brand had spread until reading this.

4.5 ⭐️ I love a good memoir. I’m not sure what made me choose this one since I don’t follow the author and knew little about him prior to reading it, but something about him being at the top of his career game and still struggling with mental health intrigued me. This book was amazing. I love the “afterword” and the possible scenarios as a result of Covid-19. Glad I rolled the dice with this book.

Not the usual chef autobiography. Though Chang describes a few mouth-watering dishes and describes the trajectory of his culinary career, the bulk of this story is about his life-long struggles with manic-depression. His writing style is conversational and easy to read, but the subject matter is heavy, so I did not want to read this book in one sitting. I appreciated Chang's candor about his angry outbursts and bouts of depression and the effect that his manic depression had on his colleagues, c

To me, a good memoir feels like an in-depth conversation with a friend - the highs, the lows, the faults and the triumphs. David Chang's memoir is successful in all this - it's funny, self-deprecating, proud, shameful and kindhearted. I was only marginally aware of his personality, having only been a fan of cake truffles from Milk Bar and possessing of the Lucky Peach cookbook, but I enjoy his philosophy in the kitchen and look forward to seeing what he comes up with next.

This is slightly different from many of the chef memoirs I have previously read. Along with Chang's perspective of how he got to where he is today, he touches on many social and mental health issues (sometimes, successfully; sometimes, with the truths of being {like us all} a flawed human). The closing with the worst case / best case scenarios for what the world of food (and beyond) will be in 2035 is really an artful summation of it all.

I think I enjoyed this book primarily for the fact that I have worked in commercial kitchens for several years. I appreciate how truthful the experience of working in one (noisy, cruel/abusive staff and managers, internal politics, evolving to stay alive, etc). It is not a profession to make a living on, and he is overt and explicit at every turn in this book. What also makes this good is the fact that it is a different memoir from others in that it reads like an anti-memoir. His brashness throu

I loved every page of this book. His personal life, career, leadership, mental health journey, leadership methods and and approach to cooking are all explored in this book which, unsurprisingly from Chang, makes this book difficult to categorize. I'm sure it's been through 1000 edits but it reads like journal/stream of consciousness. His voice challenges the status-quo and I hope more books like this come from Chang down the road.

This ended up better than I thought it would be. Perhaps because I also suffer from the twin maladies of mental health issues and restaurant ownership. Chang is extremely honest and sincere throughout. He could have gone more into depth, but I think this provides good insight into a complicated man while also being a cautionary tale to anyone foolish enough to want a culinary career.

If for nothing else, this book is worth it for Chang’s openness and transparency around his mental health and journey with therapy and meds. This was an illuminating look into his mind. I’m Gen X, and Kitchen Confidential was the chef memoir of my generation. I suspect Chang’s book is going to be the touchstone for Millennials and Gen Z. It’s a great fucking book.

Not only is this book an interesting read from a business and entrepreneurial stand point, but it is an honest account of facing your demons and being honest with yourself. It touches on racism and sexism in business in a way that I found insightful and useful as a man in the US business world.

Definitely worth your time.

I love memoirs, and this is definitely a good one. It takes so much bravery to speak on personal struggles with mental illness, and I admire David so much for talking so deeply about it. I also have increased respect for all kinds of chefs and everyone in the restaurant industry. I've never read a memoir even similar to this, and enjoyed it tons.

Recommended by Jean. Read her review on the Cook Memorial Public Library blog, Shelf Life: https://shelflife.cooklib.org/2020/10...

(#goodreadsgiveaway, though my review is in no shape a reflection of that)

My knowledge of Chang was entirely based on Ugly Delicious and Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner and probably some other food shows. From this perspective, he just seemed like an interesting and smart person who thought about food in a cool way. I feel the same way even more so after reading this. It's honestly pretty ridiculous that I haven't eat at any of his restaurants (gonna say that Milk Bar doesn't count) and it's something

Despite the fact that I kept wanting to read, this book was hard to get through. Lots of name dropping and food details I’m less interested in. I definitely got a view of the stressful restaurant industry but it doesn’t make me feel good that he’s a self admitting raging jerk. Mental health definitely plays into this, but still didn’t make me admire him or his success.

5 Stars

A wonderful autobiography that you won't want to put down. The style of the book is an easy read-as if you are sitting down with David Chang ; learning who David Chang is, his personal growth, as well as the thinking behind his successful restaurants.

Yowzah! The author gives a truly honest portrayal of himself. He's a bit scary, I wouldn't have wanted to work for him, that's for sure. It was a good read although went off into details about the financial and logistical problems of restaurants that kind of bored me. I preferred the parts where he wrote about his personal life. Next time I'm in NYC (if that day ever comes again), I want to try one of his restaurants!

Possibly the best book I read so far this year. I’ve never visited Chang’s restaurants but Eat A Peach was such a raw, honest homage to food, Asian American heritage, and loneliness. I don’t usually read food books but I believe that Eat A Peach is truly one of a kind.

Reading this definitely felt like watching a person in the midst of making sense of himself, coming to terms with himself. I am not overly interested in the restaurant business but appreciate the insight his story gave to me, especially as context and illustration for his struggle. That said, his passion is what speaks loudest. You can feel the teeth-gritting, the dust-wiping after repeat falls. So it was kind of a rough read, which i guess is unavoidable given that DC really seemed intent on ba

Chang tells quite the story of working as a chef and opening his own restaurants. I have only been to Milk Bar and I love it! And I have read Lucky Peach a few times. If you like cooking, food, and the life behind the scenes this is a good book!

This was less a great literary work and more a fascinating journey along with someone as they both mature and tackle their own demons. Is it beautiful prose? No but I found it a fabulous memoir and a great ride for anyone who was swept up in in the 2005-2010 food scene. It was also a mini tribute to Anthony Bourdain and a reminder to invest in therapy.

This was a great read. It was nice to see the story of the man behind momofuku. He didn't hold back, he admits to all of his shortcomings, and that fact he can be a complete asshole.

I would never want to work for him, but I do know people that do

It was a good memoir and I hope his restaurants continue to do well. I've never had a bad meal at any of his establishment.
Super good. really enjoyed this one
Love him as a person & as a chef!
Brutally honest, he's openly talking about mental health, racism, about his restaurant business and his relationships with his employees/partners throughout his career.
Memoirs are one of my favorite genres to read. This was a delight and I always enjoy reading about the restaurant industry. Chang is dark, sensitive, and introspective.
3.5 stars
A hauntingly honest read.
I freaking love David Chang and after I read this I have decided to pivot from teaching to becoming a chef.

A brutal and surprisingly relatable memoir. The best sections of this book are gold, although not every section is.

Recommended for folks who love reading about delicious things and also mental illness.
A really honest memoir from David Chang, touching on some tough topics and points in his life. This was a great book and a really excellent audiobook.

I'm not a foodie but I'm surrounded by them and this was the pick for my book club this month. Despite not being a foodie (I'm probably almost at the other end of the spectrum) and being a vegetarian, I find food writing really interesting. I've read a couple of chef memoirs and will probably read more in the future.

This book was a wild ride. It was an eye-opening peek into the world of restaurants in NYC - I should clarify: the bro-ey world of restaurants and chefs. I don't think I quite like D

I give four stars mostly because it is profoundly satisfying to read a good memoir written by someone you really like.

As he preaches in his book, Chang is intent on always molting like a lobster, shedding his skin, changing, and growing. He does this in food, but in this memoir he applies the same approach to his life.

This was exactly what I wanted: not so much a chronicle of his life’s work with Momofuku — though it is that, and it is good — but an analysis of Chang’s driving ethos, his intro

David Chang makes great food. But he sounds like a very challenging boss- and for reasons I can identify with. The part of this book i enjoyed the most was not the description of the food - which is great- but the honest and frank discussion around his mental illness. It is an eye opening read about the challenges with balancing leadership and creativity and meant so health.

I also appreciate the fact that Chang seems to a air ownership of his mistakes and his part in creating a boys club in the

I've enjoyed Ugly Delicious and follow David Chang on Instagram, and I'm glad I checked out this audiobook to get to know more about both his personal and career story. The only part that didn't keep me engaged was in the middle, some of the nitty gritty details of the restaurant biz and some stories involving others in the culinary world (which hey it's his memoir, he's allowed to get into as much detail as he wants...). He's very candid about the personal challenges he has faced along the way

I read Kitchen Confidential when it came out in 2007 and was surprised by the gorilla warfare chefs engage in in the name of fine dining. I became a Bourdain fan and from there a Top Chef fan, which is ironic since I don't cook. I loved everything about Chang's book, especially his honesty as he battled addiction on two fronts, as an addict and a workaholic. I've attended many AA meetings with my recovering husband and know that recovery is a difficult and often unsuccessful journey. And anyone

What is it like to walk a line as thin as a knife's edge between success and failure? David Chang is an internationally recognized, adored, hated, and envied chef - but he is foremost a quirky Korean American trying to make it in the world outside of stereotypes and without math skills.

I don't often read memoirs but when I do, the perspective in question balances on the spectrum of anti-hero, and served with a huge side of underdog success. David Chang grew up with the unique stresses of Asian i
Dude tries to convince you he doesn’t take himself too seriously for 300 pages; proceeds to take himself too seriously for 294 pages.

I enjoyed reading this immensely. It took me 3 days to finish. Could not put it down. I'll start by saying that I've always admired David. Ben Macintyre has done it again; produced a jaw-dropping book about 20th-century espionage. Sonya, born Ursula Kuczynski, lived a long life in service to the causes of anti-fascism and communism, starting 10 years before the Russian Revolution and extending decades after the fall of the Berlin Wall and the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. This is the 3rd book by Ben Macintyre that I have read, and I consider all three of those as exceptional works of non-fiction.

If you are interested in real-life spies and their spycraft, you can't go wrong with Ben Macintyre.

In this age of demagogy and liberal use of truth, it is easy to forget that not very long ago, people actually carried beliefs in various political ideologies, and some politicians made decisions according to ideology rather than according to what's in their best interests. In view of the current political climate, this may seem like a positive thing, but the story of the 20th century proves it wrong. Taken to the extreme, ideologies are no less dangerous than political opportunism.

Ben Macintyre writes the best spy biographies! Ben MacIntyre is one of the most prolific producers of nonfiction books about espionage in the English language. Of the thirteen books he’s written to date, nearly all are about spies, saboteurs, and partisans, and five of those books have been made into documentaries by the BBC. In his latest venture, MacIntyre tells the tale of an extraordinary Soviet spy in World War II, a German-Jewish Communist named Ursula Kuczynski (1907-2000). A Master at his Best, 2020 Edition, Part II. Unequivocally Macintyre’s best yet. This is a richly-rendered, romantically-grand, globe-spanning story of love, loss, intrigue, treachery, and decades of world military conflict. Truly an epic in its own right.

Yes! This is the kind of book that grabs me by the eyeballs and flings me through every page. I love historical fiction, but historical non-fiction that reads like a novel hooks me every single time. FINALLY, we are learning more and more about women’s activities during military conflicts. I have been reading about women who spied for Britain and who led the French resistance, but this is a completely new spy story and one I could not put down.

I loved the technical and family details. I look fo

A good generalised summary of Sonya's career as a soviet spy,working for the GRU.
However,a major failure is that Mcintryre doesnt evaluate who the prominent GRU spy 'Elli'-who Sonya ran-was.Most commentators think it was either Roger Hollis or Graham Mitchell.
This book doesn't consider Mitchell as a fit for 'Elli', and is rather superficially dismissive in its rejection of Hollis,in spite of the overwhelming evidence that Hollis was indeed 'Elli'-the evidence of Miksen in "An Estonian Saga" prov
Ben Macintyre writes spy histories that read like spy novels. Amazing stories.
Probably my least favorite Ben McIntyre book, and I’d still recommend it to anybody. His books are just so fun to read.

Thanks to Netgalley and Crown Publishing for the advanced digital copy of this book.

After being introduced to Ben Macintyre's work through the fantastic Spy and The Traitor, I was extremely excited to read Agent Sonya. Unfortunately despite how well researched and detailed it is, this one doesn't live up to Macintyre's lofty standards. The parts following Agent Sonya and her career as a soviet spy are interesting however the book gets bogged down by all the secondary characters who aren't as in

Agent Sonya: Moscow's Most Daring Wartime Spy is a biography of Ursula Kuczynski, a German communist spy. Ben Macintyre is a British author, historian, reviewer, and columnist for The Times newspaper, who wrote this biography.

Ursula Kuczynski was a German Communist activist who worked for the Soviet Union in the 1930s and 1940s as a spy, most famously as the handler of nuclear scientist Klaus Fuchs. She moved to East Germany in 1950 when Fuchs was unmasked, and published a series of books relate

Get ready for a bumpy ride!

"Agent Sonya" has nearly everything you want in a spy story, whether it is fact or fiction.

This true account of Ursula Kuczynski, a German Jew born in 1907, follows her from her early pro-Communist years in her homeland right through her experience as a Russian spy in China and Europe. While I expected the story to mostly be about World War II, I was very intrigued by her experiences in China in 1931 just prior to the invasion of Japan and the rise of Nazism in Germa

Agent Sonyais a true-life story about a woman code named “Sonya”. For decades, she was in the service of the Soviet regime, an evil regime but a regime the US and its allies needed during World War II to beat the Nazis. We can sympathize with her as an anti-Nazi spy but she was a contributor to espionage provided in support of Stalinism.

Sonya, born as Ursula Kuczinsky, a German Jew aligned herself with Russian Communists to fight fascism. Her spying took her to Shanghai, Mukden, Moscow, Switzerl

Ben Macintyre has done it again--another mesmerizing portrait of a master spy, nonfiction which reads like a novel. His subject this time is Ursula Kuczynski, a Jewish German communist who became one of the most celebrated Soviet spies of the WWII era. Radicalized during the Weimar Republic, Ursula was fortunate to leave Germany in the early '30s, right before the rise of the Nazi party. She landed in Shanghai with her architect first husband, Rudi, and was soon recruited into the local Soviet s

I listened to this non-fiction book (read by the author) and it was brilliant. It is a biography of one of the most successful Soviet spies of the WWII era Ursula Burton nee Kuczynski, or as she was known in Moscow: Agent Sonya. Ursula was born in a family of Jewish intellectuals in pre-war Germany. In her teens, she became interested in communist ideas and remained a staunch Marxist her entire long life. In the 1920s and 30s, even before Germany fell to the rule of fascists, Ursula considered t

Once again Ben MacIntyre delivers a compelling account of the life of a mid century spy. In this case the spotlight is on German born, Ursula Kucsynski who from an early age deplored injustice and mistreatment. Her life was comfortable given her upper middle class status, but she saw others' miserable lives and experienced the force of raw power herself when protesting as a teen.
Before WWII she aligned herself with the Communist cause which seemed a promising alternative to the ris

I still have them - my fifty cent Signet paperback editions of all the James Bond books - which I over indulged in during my 60’s high school study halls. And thus began my almost 60 year infatuation with espionage novels. It was just now as I was finishing Ben Macintyres thoroughly engrossing #AgentSonya that it dawned on me that I have done very little, if any, reading non-fiction spy narratives. #AgentSonya is the true account of the life of Ursula Kuczynski, a German Jew, who, in the 20’s at

Ben Macintyre has written a fascinating narrative about a woman who served as a spy for various Communist organizations from the 1930's to the Cold War era, managing to escape detection until Klaus Fuchs was uncovered in the atomic bomb investigations. As a daughter of a prominent Jewish family in Weimar Germany, she was a dedicated anti-fascist, and her lifelong commitment to Communism was a result of her antipathy to fascist regimes such as Nazi Germany. This led her to serve mainly as an info

Thank you to NetGalley and Crown Publishing for the eARC of this incredible real-life thriller. Ranging from the Weimar Republic to New York to Shanghai in the early ‘30s to Moscow, to Czechoslovakia, Montreaux, Oxfordshire, and finally, East Berlin, Ben McIntyre’s Agent Sonya covers an amazing amount of territory and world history in an extremely fast-paced 400 pages.
Growing up as a wealthy German Jew in the Weimar Republic, 16-year old Ursula Kuczynski was beaten by a policeman while taking p

A German Jewish woman, a mother of three, an anti-Nazi commie spy, and a fiction book writer. An engrossing detailed biography of Ursula Kuczynski who became a Communist in Weimar Germany, an anti-Nazi after that. She served the commies through Stalin's purges and the Nazi pact with the Soviets. Escaping Europe during WWII, she landed in Britain with her children, and continued her spying work, eventually becoming the handler of the atomic spy Claus Fuchs. In the 1950s, she escaped Britain and e

Epitome of non-fiction reading like fiction. Agent Sonya delves fully into the spy-life of Ursula Kuczynski Burton, a seemingly inucuous housewife in the Cotswolds. A Jewish-German refuge and member of the Communist Party, she spent 20 years providing information to The Centre, the Russian/Soviet hub of international spy operations. Recruited while in China, her escapades took her throughout the world, and she recruited spies in various countries. Her handling of Fuchs, a German exile who worked

Not a spy fiction fan, so that might influence my rating. The stars are a recognition that it is thoroughly researched and well-written. However, Ursula's life is quite repetitive for a spy and much more routine than expected. Here life was a series of 1. Move where you’re told to and 2. do as you’re told. As she progresses up the spy hierarchy it is
1. go where you’re told,
2. do what you’re told,
3. set up a network of subordinates and gain their fealty,
4. almost get caught,
5. move on to the

Ursula Burton, AKA Agent Sonya, lived several lifetimes compared to most and this is told quite competently in here. Living in Weimar Germany, Shanghai, Poland, Switzerland, and then in the UK during WWII, and early on spying for the Soviets while in Germany, she definitely had a full life. It’s difficult to judge someone who was willing to divulge such sensitive information to the Soviets regarding the nuclear bomb project; likely without her there would have been a different conduit, or in the

While engaging and enjoyable, this story of a Soviet spy is not as engaging as Macintyre's previous books. This is due to the fact that the subject is not as sympathetic as most of his previous subjects. While the agent codenamed Sonya was brave and her life was of cliff-hanging events, her inability to see the scurrilous nature of the regime she is supporting, even as it brutalizes members of her own family and circle of agents, makes the reader wonder when she is going to wake up.

Given that,

Excellent! John le Carre meets the The Americans. Ursula Kuczynski came of age in Germany during the 1920's, from a Jewish intellectual family. This biography follows the rise of fascism and Nazism in the early 1920s, her time in China in the mid-1920s, recruited as a spy, training in Moscow, then off to Poland and Switzerland, and finally to England in 1941. All this while having three children, multiple lovers, and being seen as an average housewife and mother.

Her 20 year career as a Soviet s

Another good nonfiction spy history by MacIntyre. This one relates the history of one of Soviet Russia’s most successful does during WWII and the early Cold War. It was a really interesting look at a hyper component spy who lived a broad life, and was more than just an ideologue. I appreciated that the author was able to tell her story with a clear respect and regard for her talents, while neither demonizing her for being an “enemy” spy nor lionizing her because of her political beliefs. Ursula

If this book was fiction, the author could rightly be criticized for crafting an unbelievable chain of events. Ursula Kuczynski was born in Berlin into a wealthy, intellectual Jewish family. Her devotion to communism, and her work as a spy for Soviet Russia took her virtually around the world, including assignments as a radio operator in Shanghai, several spots in Europe, the WWII years in Switzerland, eventually ending up in a small English village where she hid messages for her Communist handl

Ben Macintyre is on top form with his latest foray into the world of espionage. This time his subject is Agent Sonya, a quite remarkable woman whose life reads like fiction but is most definitely fact. I found the book compulsive reading, and although sometimes Macintyre’s chatty style becomes a bit…well, too chatty and although there will no doubt be carpers who manage to ferret out a few inaccuracies (I found one myself. Sonya’s daughter would be unlikely to start nursery and the Girl Guides a

This is one of the best books I have read. It filled out the picture of what was happening leading up to, during , and after WWII. The book includes the Spanish Civil War, the rise of communism in China and the Japanese invasion of Manchuria, the persecution of the Jews by the Nazis and the role of Russia in the war. I found it fascinating to read about the scientists who leaked the secrets about the atomic bomb to Russia. Of course the characters in the book are the most interesting. Their idea

This is my second time to read Ben Macintyre’s work on Cold War spies, totally engrossing and totally perplexing. At the time Ursula gave herself over to the cause of communism, the alternative was rising fascism in Spain and Germany. Her commitment was absolute, her journey the stuff of spy novels, which in fact she wrote in her retirement years. This is the story of a remarkable unprepossessing woman, mother of three, spymaster for 20 years and handler of nuclear scientist double spy Klaus Fuc

This is about a woman who is recognized as one of the most famous female spies for the Soviet Union. Near the end of her career as a spy, she got information from an American traitor on the design of the atomic bomb. Before that, which is most of the book, she was primarily a short wave radio operator who radioed information from spies she recruited to the Soviet Union. This lacked the suspense and intrigue of two of Macintyre's other books that I read - A Spy Among Friends and The Spy and the T

Quite a story. "Agent Sonya" was the code name for Ursula Burton, who spied for the Soviet Union for decades. Macintyre is forthright about Ursula's motivations which combined idealism with thrill seeking. He says that her children adored her although she often sacrificed their interests to the cause. Her claim that she did not really understand how horrible Stalin was is not terribly persuasive. I get that Ursula was dedicated to fighting fascism (who wouldn't be?), but her dedication to commun

4.5 stars Ben MacIntyre may have surpassed Erik Larson as my favorite narrative nonfiction author.

Ursula was a housewife, lover, adventurer, and communist devotee. She was also a spy. Most spies are loners, male, and only leave the profession when they die or are killed.

Ursula had 2 marriages, 3 children, and left the spy world for good when she lost her affinity for it.

For decades she hid in plain sight, with no one quiet believing the English housewife who baked scones couple possibly be one o

This is a most intriguing true story of "Sonya" (codename), a German woman who was a spy for Russia during the first half of the 20th century. She was a committed Communist who led an extraordinary life in Shanghai, Poland, Switzerland and finally the UK.

McIntyre weaves a compelling account of Sonya, her 3 marriages, children and her life as a spy. She was clearly a bold and adventurous woman. The book contains numerous photos of Sonja and her fellow spies and family members which help to recre

Ben Macintyre’s books are such reliable choices for non-fiction spy reads. Agent Sonya is no exception. Although not a heart-racing thriller, it provides great insight into what can cause someone to become a spy, often brutal government systems. Further explored is the common theme for women spies, so thoroughly underestimated by many simply because they were women, to be dismissed by officials despite being right under their noses.

Another fantastic offering from Ben Macintyre. Larger than life characters, thrilling insight to the world of spying before, during and after WW11, in all its utter brutality. Written in his own thrilling style with at trace of humour where necessary. This book gives a really in depth insight into east west relations during the war and into the Cold War. Part thriller, part history book, and part documentary. I cannot recommend this book highly enough.

An enthralling true story of a mother and wife of three who took multi-tasking to new levels. Sonya rode her bike to deliver weighty info on the atom bomb to renowned spy Klaus Fuchs who delivered the atom bomb recipe to the Russians. M15 agent Milicent Bagot would have bagged Sonya but the boys upstairs underestimated both women. Sonya’s journals are a primary source for McIntyre’s thoroughly researched true spy story. Photos of all the major players are an added bonus.

The author did a good job of keeping the reader engaged throughout the storyline. However some parts I found the vital information missing probably due to some reasons. Some parts of the story line repeated itself. Over all our makes the reader interested in many theories such as communism and the communist regime in USSR.
The aftermath of WW2 on various European countries.
Overall - I would recommend this book to be read atleast once.

It is truly unbelievable that this person taking the name of Sonya did so much harm for the sake of a belief. This incredibly well written book exposes the world of spying, of which I was clueless. I sometimes had a hard time keeping up with all those names (!) and had to reread to get them to understand who was who. The included photos are quite interesting, the writing style excellent and I would highly recommend it to all.

This could be Ben Macintyre's best book. The story of the most successful spy of the twentieth century (possibly of all time), spanning the rise of Hitler, the communist revolution in China, and the beginning of the Cold War. "Sonya" combined her highly dangerous undercover work with being a wife (more than once) and mother, escaping capture by the narrowest margin on several occasions. If you know Macintyre's books, you will love it; if you don't, this is a good place to start.

I have just finished reading Macintyre's "Spy Among Friends" and, as always, totally engrossing. As much as the Philby book was amazing, everyone who has read anything about WWII spies knows about him and his incredible activities. I had never heard about Ursula Kaczynski and am still overwhelmed by her. Macintyre's research and the depth of his knowledge is outstanding but combine that with his writing style make it great reading!

After having read several other books by Ben Macintyre, I was really looking forward to this one, only to be disappointed. A chart or, perhaps, a scorecard, outlining all of the persons involved, together with their various aliases, might have helped. As it was they all blurred together. I grimly saw the story through to the end, each page increasing my dislike for "Sonya," the despicable central figure of the book.

I absolutely loved this book. It read like a thriller and had my attention from start to the Acknowledgments. I was intrigued with this spy who Macintyre paints with some admiration and fondness. I found myself liking and admiring Ursula and wishing for a good outcome to her astonishing life. This book is well written and reads like an espionage novel.

I intend to read more of Ben Macintyre's books and do some further reading on Ursula Kuczynski and her family.

This is a fascinating book about a German Jewish woman who was a Soviet spy, working/living in China, Poland, Switzerland, Britain before and during WW II. She was smart and - as a woman - was often assumed to be less powerful than the men in her life, though she was their superior in the world of spying. And all the while, managed to raise three children and run a household. This is a very interesting book, a lot about China before the War and the actual life of an underground agent.

Big fan of Ben, but this is not up to his usual. Maybe it’s due to the fact that the spy in question, who undoubtedly had a significant impact, was basically boring. Nothing like Zig Zag or Philby or any of the weirdos in Double Cross. No cliffhangers. Interesting insight into young zealots and true believers. Also more evidence of ineptitude at MI5, when it comes to white, well behaved individuals.

Quite brilliant a book you cannot put down. Cast list includes Klaus Fuchs (incidentally interned in the Isle of Man at the same time as my father zl) Roger Hollis, Kim Philby to name the main contemporaries. A beautiful perceptive biography of a disturbed but sincere traitor who should have been picked up by British Intelligence.

A fascinating story. Sadly depressing though in the knowledge that the reason she got away with it for her entire career as a spy was that the men at organisations like MI5 and the FBI continually dismissed her as a potential agent because she was, in their eyes, simply a housewife. The KGB were very smart to recruit women like her.

I have always enjoyed MacIntyre's books on spies, and believed them to be relatively accurate. However, in this book Agent Sonya, in Switzerland in 1938, listens to the BBC "on her transistor radio." The transistor wasn't invented until 1947, and its use in radios didn't happen until the 1950s. Sloppy writing and editing! Makes me suspicious of other details.

Ben Macintyre has once again proven that he's among the best historian and writer of the espionage and history. His latest book featuring the story and life of one of the greatest female spies in World history, the woman who pretty much kicked off the Cold War is well informative, fascinating and brilliantly written.

Another great spy narrative by Ben Macintyre. He effortlessly weaves the intricacies of espionage, idealism, and personal relationships into the pertinent historical settings that both inform and entertain the reader along the way. If you liked The Spy and the Traitor, you'll surely enjoy Agent Sonya.

Interesting history of a true believer in the Communist Era.
Agent Sonya was extremely competent and was able to pass all the preparatory formulas and active work on the initial atomic bomb to Russia as it was happening. The USSR was never really behind the USA/United Kingdom in bomb development as a result.

Ben Macintyre has done it again! I’ll officially follow this author anywhere, this is not just one of my favourite books of the year but potentially one of my favourites of all time. Ursula Kuczynski lived an incredible life, and le Carré’s maxim about spies being the reflection of their country’s soul has never been truer. Highly, highly recommended.

Macintyre might be my favorite active storyteller. He takes non-fiction, weaves incredible, entertaining and gripping stories. I always learn something new and have fun reading his books. Agent Sonya provided the female perspective of the spy world. The story of a woman trying to balance raising three kids, multiple secret lovers, and a full time job as a Soviet spy.

Ben Macintyre has written many excellent tales of extraordinary characters doing amazing things to protect or in some cases to threaten their countries during war and peacetime. None of the characters described so far have been a patch on Ursula Kuczynski: mother and spy. If you are even remotely interested in reading real life spy stories you will love this book.

Remarkable story but did not finish it - too much minor personal detail about the participants that proved unimportant to the underlying political and military activities going on around the world at the time. While I understand that Macintyre wants to provide the human dimension and record each thought the participants had at the time, the method grows wearying.

Fantastic book. It is interesting and so readable and what an amazing woman - love or hate he politics she was an incredible woman. This is the first book i have read by Ben Macintyre but i am already looking for more, his narration is also fantastic.

Yet another of Ben Macintyre’s books I absolutely loved. Thrilling true story of a spy who was underestimated again and again because she was a woman. But she changed the course of history! Wow. (Bought this immediately for my mom for her birthday!)

I enjoyed his previous work but thought this one got too sidetracked from central theme by numerous sidebars into multiple characters. The individual parts didn't hold together to create compelling reading momentum and narrative unity.

My Review

This book has to be the ultimate spy story especially because it about a woman, a wife and a mother. It is almost unbelievable that a women could accomplish so much as a spy when most successful spies were men.

The story of a self-made "career woman" ,albeit for the other side, way before it was usual. Sonya had it all including travel, adventure, job flexibility, and multiple partners. Quite the life story.

Biography of Ursula Burton, Agent Sonja, a Soviet spy. Her tradecraft and cover were superb and she is considered the most important female spy in history. This true story is rich in detail and remarkably readable.

Very well researched, well written story about the life of an accomplished spy. My only gripe with this book is at times, there are far too many different individuals mentioned to try to keep track of.
Ben Macintyre is an auto buy for me. Non-fiction that reads like action, mystery, thriller?? YES. PLEASE.
Macintyre is a beast! Well done and thank you Ben
Ben Macintyre always does a terrific job and this book is no exception, but I definitely enjoyed it less than his previous books, probably because the dogmatic protagonist was so unlikable.
Very readable; but in many ways she is a peripheral figure to Fuchs and Sorge.
Very interesting; BBC Radio 4 book of the week; followed up by his presentation at Cheltenham Literature Festival

An incredible story and a great history of the tumultuous 20th century.

it good a book and i just want to read more

I love Ben Macintyre's books. He always finds the most interesting subjects.

Excellent.

Sometimes rating and reviewing a memoir can be really difficult. Who am I to judge someone’s life story? I almost was unable to rate this but settled with the 3 stars. While I enjoyed Carry by Toni Jensen, there were some parts of the writing and layout that didn’t quite work out for me but I will start with what I liked.

Toni Jensen is an indigenous woman from the Métis tribe in particular but is white passing. I don’t see much indigenous representation

2.5 stars Thanks to the Marketing Manager | Random House Group | Penguin Random House for the chance to read and review this ARC and to NetGalley for the download.

How do you critique a memoir? You don't. A persons life and their thoughts about their life are theirs to own. So how do you review a memoir? You can't critique a memoir, but you can critique the manner in which it was written.

I had a problem with this memoir. To me it felt disjointed, a bit hit and miss. There were sections that I en

Carry is a collection of essays about Toni Jensen’s experiences with many forms of violence, including domestic and gang, while focusing on gun violence and its personal and historical impact.
While it was engaging, I didn’t realize beforehand that it's a series of interconnected essays, which made the timeline disjointed and at times it felt like info-dumping with statistics and dictionary definitions. The essay format made the book lack that feeling of connection I usually find and appreciate i

I am struggling with this review. The book has left me open and raw and angry and sad and deep in memories I never, ever, wanted to revisit [and thought I had dealt with, but apparently, I have just shoved them into one of those compartmentalized boxes in my brain and moved on], and it has also made me so incredibly angry and sad for the author. Even though she has worked through a lot of what happened to her in the past, how does one ever move on from that kind of trauma? And she cannot ever er

When I first picked up Carry I thought it was going to be about Jensen's experience as an indigenous woman with gun violence. To some extent that is what it is, but Carry is also about violence against women, children, animals and as she discusses fracking, the raping and pillaging of the land. Through these essays Jensen correlates different forms of violence and provides evidence of how one type of violence breeds another. We have seen on the news how peaceful protests at the Dakota Access pip

Carry: A Memoir on Survival on Stolen Land, by Toni Jensen, is a memoir in essays, on a range of topics but with violence as a common theme. Domestic violence, settler violence; the violence of erasure; the violence of system racism; the violence of classism and white privilege, gun violence, violent crime, drug violence, and police violence. The brutal murder of George Floyd, Trayvon Martin and so many others on the hands of police. All through her own experience as a Métis, as a survivor.

Carry by Toni Jensen is a stunning collection of thoughts and essays bound together to create a memoir of sorts and a glimpse into the world of a woman that has been immersed and experienced a multitude of sobering experiences: violence and tragedy in such a vast array of situations ( gun violence, racial injustice and violence, domestic violence, amongst others). All of this being presented from the viewpoint of a Native American.

This book is real, raw, difficult to read (however it is a much

Positively haunting. Totally engrossing. I don’t read many nonfiction books, let alone memoirs. But this book was as gripping and fraught as any novel, and it is beautifully written.

This book is about families. It is about alcoholism. It is about the struggle of native people. It is about guns and violence. It is about teachers and students. It is about Black Lives Matter and it is somehow already about COVID. It is the story of one woman’s experiences. It is about birds.

In other words, this book is about America. And it is a wonderful read.

“This isn’t a story, then, so much about being Indian in America or even being Métis in America. It’s a story about being those things and striving toward whiteness; it’s about the cost of that striving.”

Toni Jenson’s voice is one we need in this country. Her work, Carry: A Memoir of Survival on Stolen Land, brings to the fore an image of America we would rather normalize or ignore. Jensen confronts the language we choose to tell our stories of racism, white adjacency, violence, gender, family,

This book took me longer than I expected to finish, but just because it was a lot of processing to sit with. I saw that there were some lower reviews on this book, but I don't think they are truly fair. This book isn't an easy read specifically because it is more metaphorical and extensive than appears by simply the text in the book. However, if you give yourself the time to engage with it, it's remarkable and beautiful. Especially in the time of indigenous people's day, I highly recommend this

I received this as an ARC on Netgalley - This is a mostly dark and gritty account. It’s hard to say whether or not I liked it as it was more of an experience that had ups and downs. Also growing up around guns I could relate to some of the experiences the author was describing but others were so foreign that I had to stop and think through what she was presenting.

Carry is a memoir reflecting on the violence/gun violence Tori has seen throughout her life. I especially liked the passages about her time at Standing Rock, during the NODAPL protests. As dark as this was, some of this darkness is necessary. We experience too much as Indigenous people, and sometimes it has to be put on paper.

Carry is a lyrical memoir, composed in a series of vignettes that move fluidly across time and place. Toni Jensen recounts her experiences growing up as a Métis woman, mixing personal stories with essays on broader issues in American culture. She returns again and again to gun violence, but also addresses sexual violence, addiction, abuse, racism, misogyny, police brutality, and the historical and cultural trauma imposed on Indigenous people. These are heavy topics, but Jensen’s prose does not b

Thanks to Penguin Random House for the free copy of this book.

CARRY is a memoir in essays by Toni Jensen, a Métis woman from the Midwest who later traveled all over the country as a journalist and professor. The book tracks scenes from her life alongside this country's epidemic of gun violence, and how the personal and the national stories collide.

Really enjoyed this memoir about a Métis woman and her experience being an indigenous woman in this America and with gun violence.
Webster’s definitions, gun violence, birds and racism all wrapped up in the searing beauty of Toni Jensen’s words.
This book wasn’t quite what I was expecting it to be, but I appreciated the poetic nature of each essay and the careful attention to language.

In this finely wrought collection, poetic in range, arrangement, and compression, Jensen tells the story of her own life against the backdrop of US gun violence, domestic violence, racism, and classism. Jensen’s own author photo communicates the emotions one comes to feel from reading these essays: exhaustion, sadness, outrage, fear, and courage. In the photo, she stands outdoors with her back against the wood siding of a building, looking straight ahead. Taken from the side, the image shows Je

This was a very hard book for me to read. And I’m not talking about difficult in the sense of not being able to get through it - on the contrary, Carry is a beautifully written collection of essays and memoir, and I didn’t want to put it down. But I recognized a lot of myself and my own life and traumas in Toni Jensen’s, and for that reason I had to set it aside from time to time, and read it slowly. I also don’t know how on earth I am going to be able to do this book justice in a review…

I feel a bit at a loss for words for this review. The author places such a weight on the importance of words and the power of them. I hope I use my power well in this review.

It's hard to put into words how to describe this book. There are passages that feel as if Toni Jensen has reached inside my head and put my own thoughts to paper.

This isn’t my genre of choice (although Carry doesn’t pigeon-hole into a set genre, I don’t think). The book was sent to me with a suggestion I read it, and I’m glad I did. It’s a beautifully-written, important book that’s original and thought-provoking. Her use of language is always original and often breath-taking. I resonated with her love for words, for collective nouns, for definitions – and for birds.

"Does a domestic-violence bullet enter the body and exit differently than a regular bullet? What is an irregular bullet? If the move toward the language of domesticity is a lessoning, a demoting of sorts, then what is the language of violence about race? An escalation? A shout to the whisper of the domestic? Dont mistake me--I am not advocating here for more whispering. We have all been quiet too long and at such a cost."

So this one is tough for me to rate and review. To begin, I absolutely loved the content and the writing choices were bold and daring but not so much that I think it would turn off the average reader. This memoir in essays reminded me so much of another favorite: I am, I am, I am by Maggie O'Farrell. Both are stunningly, poetically written, with a focus on extraordinary and everyday brushes with death. Jensen is a born storyteller, someone whose curiosity about language and the effects of words comes through clearly in her writing. I fell head over heels for her narrative style from the first page. Toni Jensen comes "from lace-curtain Irish married into Métis." She touches on so much of the essence of the moment, while calmly explaining the etymology of birds and their collective nouns. We're learning about a tiding of magpies and then we're at Standing Rock, a riot of robins leads to sex trafficking, an exaltation of larks child abuse, the migration of the sandhill cranes racism, a meiny of swallows divorce, a cloud of blackbirds the Trail of Tears. I tore through this book in a day, and

This memoir is one of the most interesting memoirs that I've read because it covers a vast range of super important topics, including gun violence, Native rights, environmental issues (especially as it relates to Native land), domestic violence, traumatic experiences, and racism. To think that one person has personally experienced and encountered all of these facets of our society is almost unfathomable. In this interesting collection of essays, Toni Jensen connects various American violences—the taking and plundering of both lands and bodies, the incessant destruction of guns in “this, our America”—through her sharp and almost scientific language. She makes incredible intellectual leaps, connecting disparate events through the surprising ways our words mean so many things at once. This is may be one of the best books I’ve read this year. Author Toni Jensen has drawn such a wide net to capture ideas that normally remain elusive and just beyond our grasp. Even the title CARRY: A MEMOIR ON STOLEN LAND is worthy of repeated reflection. Equal parts diary, memoir, didactic lecture, poetry and yes, dictionary, the book asks readers to consider and reflect upon a host of old and very pressing issues that refuse to settle quietly. If anything, they are bubbling up now as never bef

Carry by Toni Jensen is a powerful collection of essays that takes a critical look at gun violence in the US and how it intersects with domestic violence, Indigenous women's lives, and the land we occupy. I really appreciated the way that Jensen was able to connect the personal and the political through the autobiographical aspects of this book. I also personally enjoyed her etymology break downs of certain words that created the themes of her essays. I know some people weren't really into that,

I don't like to rate memoirs. It seems strange to put a star rating on someone's real-life story, something they've written how they remember it, and how they interpreted it. And I always seem to get something out of every memoir I read. Carry is powerful, so very current, and a poetic expression of the violence Toni Jensen has experienced so far in her life. Violence that is hard to read.

I read Carry quickly, speeding through it almost like ripping off a band-aid, knowing it would be difficult
