Toni Jensen's Carry is a memoir in essays about her experience as a Métis woman, with a particular focus on how gun violence has become rampant and touches numerous lives. It's also about identity, trauma, being a writer, etc.

Guns are woven throughout, from her father's own possession, to encounters she's personally had, to other people she's known who have been affected by them. For example, she writes of the Pulse night club shooting in Orlando, a place that she used to live and which her stu

I love this book! I read a big portion of it twice. Some of it is
hard to read as it speaks the truth. It covers everything that is
wrong with America today.
The book is written in essays, there's a first-person, then a second.
It's very easy to follow along the way.
This book is a keeper! I don't know of another book written about the
events that we have all had to Carry.

Thank you so much Toni Jensen, the publisher, and NetGalley
for the chance to read and review this great book!

Carry is part memoir, part essays on topics that demonstrate what ails American society; like gun violence, domestic violence, displacement, racism, and historical trauma. Theses essays are beautifully written confirming the author's belief that words are important and powerful.
However, these essays contain razor-sharp observations of exploitation and suffering especially for minorities and more so for women.
While it is a dark book it is a must-read to get an understanding of the dysfunctional

This was a great view into a world I don't always see, at the same time connecting to the world I know.
Most of the book is focused on discrimination against Native Americans, yet it highlights other minorities as well. At the same time it points out so many things in America that we have come to just consider normal. Things we should be outraged about, but are mostly indifferent. I strongly suggest giving this a chance if you like to learn about people, issues and situations outside what you kno

This is language focused writing. The writing is dense but has a flow that shows her skill. In Carry, Jensen often breaks definitions down for us like "to worry" as a form of both choking/tearing something slowly and to be distressed and anxious. She is so crafty with her parallels. She is cognizant of the words she is using, writing that she is aware of the connotations of 'boy' and 'man' when it comes to Black victims of violent crimes, for instance. Because language matters.

The way the autho

There's some very powerful stuff here but I did not connect with the writing at all and I found the structure of this book really disorienting. This is not really a memoir it is more of a series of essays tangentially about violence with no real clear through line. I'm sure people will love this and I definitely respect the author for her openness, but this was not for me.

Also, I have to say this, I have never seen someone present Webster's dictionary definitions in a book this much. It was jarr

There are occasions when, struggling with a memoir, I find myself thinking that rather than taxing readers a writer would have done better to consult a professional therapist. Toni Jensen’s CARRY: A MEMOIR OF SURVIVAL ON STOLEN LAND is such an occasion.

I’m not saying that a good memoir of grievances is impossible, just that it’s difficult and requires equanimity and latitude that are utterly lacking in Jensen’s book, which is further marred by borderline misandry and a number of tiresome authori

This series of essays might set you back on your heels. Jensen has explored, in a thought provoking way, what is means to be Metis and what it means to be female. And, what guns mean in society today. She has used entwined her family history with a stern look at stereotypes. While it's a very serious collection, it is leavened with occasional flashes of light. Thanks to Netgalley for the ARC. Read one essay- appreciate it- and then read another the next day. Excellent.

Where do we go from here? That is the question that haunts after reading this book. Toni Jensen's memoir is poignant, strong, straight forward and scary as hell. This book covers, the strength of women who face violence in their everyday lives. The strength of women who have children that need to be protected. The strength of women who make hard choices. "Our America", has serious issues concerning guns, and Ms. Jensen is not afraid to address the issue. So... where DO we go from here?

Carry is a memoir in the form of essays. It is beautifully written, although the style might not work for everyone, but I found the writing to be gorgeous and haunting. The essays are all about violence in some form or another, focusing on domestic and gun violence in particular. Reading it is heartbreaking, but also brings to light a conversation we as a nation need to be having.

Thank you to NetGalley and the publisher for an advance copy of this book.

This was a series of essays so it felt somewhat disconnected, but it was beautifully done. The common theme is violence which is also timely in our world at this time when violence is so fife. I consider it an important read even though it is difficult to read and will stay with you for a long time.
I voluntarily read and reviewed an advanced copy of this book. All thoughts and opinions are my own.

Carry was a pretty solid read. Jensen covers a lot of ground - mental illness, Native American struggles, midwestern life, gun violence among many, many other topics. Most of the these essays were fantastic, but some seemed to stop the momentum of her narrative a bit. I appreciate the honesty and frankness of her essays and agreed with her sentiments almost all the time. This was quite a thought-provoking read and some of the details contained within will stay with me for awhile, I'm sure.

***Thanks to NetGalley for this ARC in exchange for my honest review***

This phenomenal memoir beautifully and heartbreakingly describes Toni Jensen's experience as an indigenous woman in the United States while also exploring violence in its many forms. It is a well-balanced mix of personal narrative with social commentary that left me with all the feelings. Her thoughtful and intelligent perspectives are presented in writing that is as exquisitely crafted as it is socio-politically astute.

This book comes at an important time in our history. It delves into the intersection of gun violence, the author's ancestry (Native), and contagion theory. However, it is done so very well through stories the author tells regarding her own personal experiences.
I learned quite a bit of interesting information about the Native experience, and in particular the experience of people who are known as métis - half Native peoples.
The book was very well written, interesting and engaging. I didn't thin

A wide-ranging series of essays and point-of-view articles dealing with gun violence experienced by the author. I found the last two chapters on contagion and ghost logic the best. Throughout, the subject matter but 5-star, but I felt some of the chapters dragged and were not as tightly constructed as these.

I was hoping to really like this book, since there isn't much I've about/by Native Americans, but just couldn't connect w/ this author. If I had to read another tidbit about birds or a definition of a word, I may have been tempted to scream.
One thing I can say is I love for a book to challenge me to learn something new and this book did have me doing some research on who/what the Metis are.

Carry is a collection of interconnecting essays from Toni Jensen discussing police brutality, domestic violence, gun violence, human trafficking, and rape through the author's own experiences living as a Métis woman.

This was a very honest and at times a difficult to read but is an incredibly relevant and valuable read right now.

Thank you to NetGalley and Ballantine Books for the ARC.

Absolutely the best memoirs I have read on indigenous women ever. Written by one that wrote a strong and compulsive story about her own history. Insightful and eye opening. I believe this to be a must read. For everyone no matter if you're make or female. No matter what your skin color or your religion. Deserves a tip spot on your TBR stack Happy reading! #Carry #NetGalley

Wow! This book! Toni Jensen’s ability to blend non-fiction essay style writing with memoir is unmatched. I was surprisingly gifted this book on its published day and it was every bit (and even more) as good as I’d hoped.


Read this. Listen to Indigenous people. Learn that we are all comfortable in our complacency.

An important series of essays that highlight various aspects of being native that I think are often never told especially by native women. of course gun violence is central in most of the stories as well and it was great how they both tie in with each other but the last couple of chapters were a drag to get through.

Halfway though realizing that this was not fiction especially pulled at my heart. The body and the soul carry burdens through generations and our country continues to brutalize those who do not contribute to its corrupt wallet enough. Why does money and overpowering have to be the measure? What if it were caring and love as we ideally imagine a mother having for her child.

I was unsure of this while reading the first few chapters. The use of second person at the start was not my favorite. But, I absolutely fell in love with this memoir as it developed. Jensen skillfully weaves together her life and experience with larger American stories and themes.
Beautifully written!!

This is a heavy read, and threads of abuse (human and animal), gun violence, poverty, and Native people living on stolen land weave their way through. It’s uneven and roundabout and that mostly works to its advantage. There is also a thread of listing dictionary definitions for terms that I just don’t think works, or doesn’t work however the author intended.

Jensen has made art from her many experiences of violence (gun violence in particular, but other kinds as well) and discrimination. The other thing she carries is anger at the government for all its mistreatment of Native Americans. I memoir for our times. Thank you, Toni Jensen, for helping us wake up.

Carry is a collection of essays bound together into a memoir but it's so much more. Carry is about carrying the weight of domestic violent. Carrying the weight of gun violence. Carrying the weight of racism, of sexism. Such a timely novel in a voice that needs to be heard.

Interesting memoir that talks about carrying guns and the consequences of it. The author’s life was permeated by gun violence right next door. At times the narrative is not so compelling, but at times it really is.

4.5 out of 5 stars.

I really appreciated how she told her story. It flowed well and felt incredibly accessible.

Her story was super interesting and had a pretty powerful message. I highly recommend it for anyone who enjoys P.O.C. memoirs.

The way this read was creative and flowy. It was hard to follow at times because it bounced around, but it’s a great read. My husband is a descendant of the Sand Creek Massacre, so I found that chapter to be very interesting.
I loved this book. It is an eye opener!

Throughout, the subject matter but 5-star, but I felt some of the chapters dragged and were not as tightly constructed as these.

I was hoping to really like this book, since there isn't much I've about/by Native Americans, but just couldn't connect w/ this author. If I had to read another tidbit about birds or a definition of a word, I may have been tempted to scream.
One thing I can say is I love for a book to challenge me to learn something new and this book did have me doing some research on who/what the Metis are.

Carry is a collection of interconnecting essays from Toni Jensen discussing police brutality, domestic violence, gun violence, human trafficking, and rape through the author's own experiences living as a Métis woman.

This was a very honest and at times a difficult to read but is an incredibly relevant and valuable read right now.

Thank you to NetGalley and Ballantine Books for the ARC.

Absolutely the best memoirs I have read on indigenous women ever. Written by one that wrote a strong and compulsive story about her own history. Insightful and eye opening. I believe this to be a must read. For everyone no matter if you're make or female. No matter what your skin color or your religion. Deserves a tip spot on your TBR stack Happy reading! #Carry #NetGalley

Wow! This book! Toni Jensen’s ability to blend non-fiction essay style writing with memoir is unmatched. I was surprisingly gifted this book on its published day and it was every bit (and even more) as good as I’d hoped.


Read this. Listen to Indigenous people. Learn that we are all comfortable in our complacency.

An important series of essays that highlight various aspects of being native that I think are often never told especially by native women. of course gun violence is central in most of the stories as well and it was great how they both tie in with each other but the last couple of chapters were a drag to get through.

Halfway though realizing that this was not fiction especially pulled at my heart. The body and the soul carry burdens through generations and our country continues to brutalize those who do not contribute to its corrupt wallet enough. Why does money and overpowering have to be the measure? What if it were caring and love as we ideally imagine a mother having for her child.

I was unsure of this while reading the first few chapters. The use of second person at the start was not my favorite. But, I absolutely fell in love with this memoir as it developed. Jensen skillfully weaves together her life and experience with larger American stories and themes.
Beautifully written!!

This is a heavy read, and threads of abuse (human and animal), gun violence, poverty, and Native people living on stolen land weave their way through. It’s uneven and roundabout and that mostly works to its advantage. There is also a thread of listing dictionary definitions for terms that I just don’t think works, or doesn’t work however the author intended.

Jensen has made art from her many experiences of violence (gun violence in particular, but other kinds as well) and discrimination. The other thing she carries is anger at the government for all its mistreatment of Native Americans. I memoir for our times. Thank you, Toni Jensen, for helping us wake up.

Carry is a collection of essays bound together into a memoir but it's so much more. Carry is about carrying the weight of domestic violent. Carrying the weight of gun violence. Carrying the weight of racism, of sexism. Such a timely novel in a voice that needs to be heard.

Interesting memoir that talks about carrying guns and the consequences of it. The author’s life was permeated by gun violence right next door. At times the narrative is not so compelling, but at times it really is.

4.5 out of 5 stars.

I really appreciated how she told her story. It flowed well and felt incredibly accessible.

I loved this book. It is an eye opener!

Barnett has a heart for those who were unjustly sentenced to more time than their actions deserved and uses her own resources to fight for and obtain clemency for her pro bono clients. Wow. Whether you're interested in criminal justice reform or know nothing about it, Brittany Barnett tells a compelling story. A young lawyer battles unfair sentences handed out in the War on Drugs, a law put into effect in 1984, by President Clinton. In this memoir, Brittany Barnett, co-founder
of the Buried Live Project, recounts her successful attempt to gain
clemency for seven pro bono clients who were sentenced to life in prison without
parole for first time drug offenses. This memoir is horrifying to read as Barnett takes
you through the lives and downfalls of each of the seven victims.

Brittany is an amazing person, working tirelessly on getting people serving life sentences for first offense drug charges out of jail. People incarcerated for the maximum of time, caught in the war on drugs and it's unjust sentencing guidelines. As a law student, one woman's story brings the stark reality of this phenomenon to her attention. Knowing that she must make mass incarceration about individual people, she does an excellent job of doing just that for the readers of this book.

Good Account of Getting Clemency fir Federal Drug Charges

Many people are put into prison for harsh drug laws of years past. Small things sometimes caused people to get life. The story of a woman struggling though prison, watching her mother die in prison due to bad healthcare and seeing her daughter from age 9 grow into an adult without her is harrowing. The young law student who works on several cases and appeals to President Obama is heartening.

I read this one on Audible and I found it to be amazing. I learned so much about how unfair the minimum sentencing laws were and how the war on drugs has ruined hundreds of thousands of lives. I am so glad that I has the chance to read A Knock at Midnight and hope that Brittany K. Barnett will get the chance to share more stories in the future.

A powerfully illuminating must-read.

A Knock at Midnigh is a remarkable memoir, extremely compelling and full of character, detailing driven attorney Brittany K. Barnett's early life in Eastern Texas, the trauma of her mother's incarceration and the subsequent impact it had in her life, as she begins to work tirelessly to advocate for her clients against their own inhumane and nonsensical life sentences for drug offenses, all while working full time as a corporate lawyer.

I’ve always prided myself on my ability to teach myself things. Whenever I don’t know a lot about something, I’ll read a textbook or watch an online course until I do.

I thought I was pretty good at teaching myself—until I read Tara Westover’s memoir Educated. Her ability to learn on her own blows mine right out of the water. I was thrilled to sit down with her recently to talk about the book.

I had a really tough time reading this book.

The physical and emotional abuse made me want to put it down and forget about it. The manipulation, the abuse she went through left me speechless. While not unique, family issues are still so taboo. Brainwashing your own self into thinking it's your fault, that it wasn't that bad or that you imagined it will hit way too close for comfort for a lot of people.

Tara Westover’s book “Educated” is a distressing & discomforting - alarming & startling exposure of her Mormon fundamentalist family.

“Educated” is a memoir of nonfiction - but names and identifying details have been changed. Aaron, Audrey, Benjamin, Erin, Faye, Gene, Vanessa, Judy, Peter, Sadie, Shannon, Shawn, Susan, Robert, and Robin are pseudonyms.

“This is not about Mormonism. Neither is it about any other form of religious belief. In it there are many ty

"Not knowing for certain, but refusing to give way to those who claim certainty, was a privilege I had never allowed myself. My life was narrated for me by others. Their voices were forceful, emphatic, absolute. It had never occurred to me that my voice might be as strong as theirs."
- Tara Westover, Educated: A Memoir

So good. So good. SO GOOD. Ok, I'll try to elaborate. Tara Westover's memoir is incredibly engrossing not just because of the rollercoaster of traumatic events that occur throughout her life, but also because of her ability to weave humanity and complicated familial relationships in her portrayal of events. While it's easy to take these events and market it like a thriller novel, it's that sense of reflection and poignancy in her carefully crafted words that is the book’s strongest asset. As awf

I grew up with my nose perpetually in a book. So, the idea of not being able to go to school, of being deprived of an education, hit me really hard. It was hard for me to grasp that things I take for granted, like knowing what the Holocaust was or who MLK, Jr. was, were black holes to Tara.

Tara Westover is the child of a religious fanatic, someone who sees the government as pure evil. And by government, he means schools, hospitals, vaccines, seat belts, car insurance, etc. Everything we think o

A monumental memoir that should be required reading for all. The description doesn't do it justice. It's not about getting a PhD, it's about growing up in a family that doesn't believe in school, thinks doctors are a part of a sociologist conspiracy, and that any day the government will shoot them dead--if the end of times don't come first. The experiences Tara describes are horrific, yet oddly relatable--even if your family is nothing like hers (and let's hope it isn't). By the end, she has to

Everything about this book amazed me. I will not stop thinking about this book for a very, very long time. I don't think I can even do this proper justice in a review other than telling everyone to go out and READ THIS BOOK! Easiest 5 stars ever. Loved it.

To be honest, I don’t even know why I’m bothering to review this.

There is no scenario in which I am a more trusted source than Obama, Oprah, the New York Times Book Review, and the Goodreads Choice Awards combined, and if they’ve all already told you to read this (which they have) then I don’t know why my recommendation would push this whole thing over the edge for you.

This memoir is so brutal at times and hard to read, your heart just breaks for this girl, and for some of her siblings.

Every year, in order for the publishing industry to survive, one poor traumatised adult must delve deep into the blocked recesses of their minds and produce the Next Top Abuse Memoir. It’s a tradition as old as and as common as Christmas. One could argue we all have Joan Crawford to blame for this. The family has strong beliefs that center

I was blown away by this book. I finished it a few days ago and can’t stop thinking about it.

Tara Westover grew up under the watchful eye of a survivalist and fundamentalist family. Her parents did not believe in sending children to school for fear of being brainwashed, they did not believe in doctors, hospitals or medication. Tara grew up with her family of survivalists in the mountains of Idaho without a formal education, connection to society, or doctors. Her parents didn't want the children in public schools and chose to remain hidden from the 'evil' government. They kept busy preparing for the end of days.

Educated is an incredible story and it's written very well. It was emotional and hard to read at times, but I found myself truly captivated from beginning to end. This book actually reminded me of The Glass Cast

This was impossible to put down! I usually save my audio books for my car trips, but I found myself listening to this one at home. A story about Tara and her childhood growing up in a Mormon family. Her father was a survivalist and thought the world might end at any moment!

Their family home was situated in the shadow of Buck Peak mountain and they lived in poverty. Tara and her six siblings endured much pain under the volatile father and one brother who proved to be quite dangerous. The mother s

Tara Westover is capable of crafting a beautiful sentence.
Her overall story left me processing mixed reaction.

It's impressive that although she was "uneducated" until she attended BYU at age 17, she continued to such high levels, receiving scholarships and fellowships to study at Cambridge and Harvard, earning her PhD.
At the same time, I felt shadows of skepticism. It's her mother's word against hers; one says she is a home schooler, one says she wasn't home schooled - but she somehow learned

When a girl raised on a mountain in Idaho by her survivalist fundamentalist Mormon family sets foot in a classroom for the first time at the age of 17, how will things turn out? Can she ever escape the past?

Yeah, I made that sound like one of the sleazy thrillers I'm fond of but Educated is a memoir, not a potboiler. I don't normally read memoirs but I decided to take Random House up on their offer when they came knocking.

Educated is the story of Tara Westover's childhood on Buck's Peak, a mount

Well, this one was a special book. I didn't like what I read in the beginning. But it's a reminder of what harm religion can do. But quickly we came out of this Sam Harris-like territory, and went into more chaos.

There are a few cases like Tara's. But not everyone of them can write like her. She reminds me of Beryl Markham with her biography, West with the Night.

Reading this book was very much aligning with the values that I hold sacred. The written word, if acquired, can be a formidable weapon.

Educated, Tara Westover

Tara Westover was 17 the first time she set foot in a classroom. Born to survivalists in the mountains of Idaho, she prepared for the end of the world by stockpiling home-canned peaches and sleeping with her "head-for-the-hills bag".

In the summer she stewed herbs for her mother, a midwife and healer, and in the winter she salvaged in her father's junkyard. Her father forbade hospitals, so Tara never saw a doctor or nurse. Gashes and concussions, even burns from explosions

I went into this one with really low expectations (I'm an incredible snob, and make a point of disregarding such popular books as silly crowd-pleasers). Having finished this, however, I can't actually think of a single thing I found wrong with it. Worse still, I enjoyed every page.

Apparently, I need to reevaluate my opinion of beach-reads.

Written with the skill and resonance of a work of fiction, Tara Westover's memoir is heart-breaking and frank and yet hopeful in its telling.

Westover was born in 1986, grown up in a rural Idaho radical Mormon Family dominated by her father Gene who was determined to raise his children away from the clutches of the government and the wider world. She had never heard of the Holocaust, Napoleon, or Martin Luther King and she had thought Europe was a country. When she gains a place in college throug

A very high 4 stars.

Educated is a powerful and heartbreaking memoir. Tara Westover grew up in Idaho in a Mormon family. She is the youngest of seven children growing up on an isolated rural property. A fundamentalist version of religion fed her father’s paranoia and his antigovernment and survivalist view of the world. Until she was 17 years old, she had never gone to school and was barely homeschooled. Clearly brilliant, she managed to get into college at Brigham Young and eventually made her w
Okay this is my next reading for sure

It’s good to read a nonfiction book by a woman who grew up completely differently from me. My family struggled financially, but the library is free, and every weekend Mom would take my sister and me to the library. It was the greatest thing ever: You got to pick out books and they just gave them to you. FOR FREE. My parents, who are not well educated, wanted a different life for my sister and me, which they did their best to do by making both of us book smart.

Tara Westover’s family, her father

"They believed in modesty; we practiced it. They believed in God's power to heal; we left our injuries in God's hands. They believed in preparing for the Second Coming; we were actually prepared."

Even in a rural, religious Mormon town in Idaho, the Westover family was different. They didn't go to school. Tara Westover's father believed school would take his children off their Godly path, which included helping out in the family metal scrap yard and forgoing the doctor in favor essential oils and

One of the most powerful and well-written memoirs I’ve ever read. This tells of a young woman’s off-grid upbringing in Idaho and the hard work that took her from almost complete ignorance to a Cambridge PhD. Westover’s is an incredible story about testing the limits of perseverance and sanity. Her father may have been a survivalist, but her psychic survival is the most impressive outcome here. What takes this astonishing life story to the next level, making it a classic to sit alongside memoirs

The book is split into three parts: growing up and her childhood; College, predominantly at BYU; and, further education and the cracking of familial relationships. This book, I found, was largely an exploration of her familial relationships and the empowerment of education.

This is a real jaw-dropper of a memoir. Tara Westover is raised in an isolated fundamentalist Mormon family in Idaho. Her father is a bipolar and paranoid survivalist, with a deep distrust of government. The Westover children run wild, helping their father with his junkyard scrapping business and their mother with her mid-wifing and herbal and essential oil concoctions. The children do not go to school and are not (for the most part) home schooled beyond the very basics of reading and arithmetic

OKAY. UNPOPULAR OPINION TIME.

I listened to the audiobook (which is the only way I can read nonfiction) and the reader was excellent. Seriously. But, I can only listen with rapt attention for so long when it’s just car accident after car accident, junkyard accident after junkyard accident.

Tara Westover was raised by in a Mormon Survivalist family, and was fed a steady diet of religious fundamentalism, anti-Western medicine diatribes, and conspiracies against things like seat belts. She was also emotionally abused for many, many years by her father, as well as emotionally and physically abused by her brother Sean. That she escaped that life at all is remarkable. That she did so through a course of self-education that ultimately led to advanced degrees from Harvard and Cambridge is

Gene Westover, a devout Mormon man, wants to be left alone to live modestly, stay off the government's grid, homeschool his children, practice faith-healing and prepare for the End Days in the isolated foothills of Idaho. His wife is submissive to his authority as she feels a good Christian woman should be and works as an unlicensed mid-wife and herbalist, busy cooking up meals and healing salves. Westover's childhood and adolescence were lived in an deeply dysfunctional, violent, fundamentalist Mormon family. Her father was a diehard survivalist, anti-government, anti-doctors, anti-school and learning, and he hoarded food, petrol and guns. Most of his children didn't have birth certificates. He believed that everyone who wasn't rigidly fundamentalist was influenced by some vast sinister force he called “the Illuminati”.

It isn't often that I get as irritated with a book as I did with 'Educated'. The author, Tara Westover, appears to have a mnemonic memory going back to her early childhood. This book moved me.

Author Tara Westover first went to school at the age of 17 much to the dismay of her survivalist parents. Prior to that she never attended school: college would be her first experience with formal education. Not only was going to college a way to get an education, but it also served as an escape from an turbulent family life.

Westover is smart and thoughtful and writes beautifully about growing up in the hills of Idaho and adjusting to the outside world as a young woman. This book evoked the most powerful feelings in me. Unfortunately not all of them were positive.

That is the term the publisher chose to use. I would have used a different term. She was isolated and never attended school. She was the youngest of seven children.

A captivating memoir, well written, easy to tear through, and kind of heartbreaking. It was positioned by some as a way to understand what is happening in America, and you certainly got to see a family that is off the grid and very poor. But I think it was much more a story about abuse. Emotional and physical, Tara's story is most impressive that not only did she break out and get an education, but she escaped the abuse from her father and brother that kept all the rest of her family in check. “Educated” is a wonderful beautifully written book. It was out of my usual genre in that I do not particularly like memoirs. The premise of most is “I am an important person—everyone wants to read about how great I am— and a publisher will give me a few million to “write” (usually with assistance of a real writer) about my life." This book is nothing like that. It is deeply personal, painful and powerful and tells a story that needed to be told and that people should hear. It is also as enthrall

Book snob that I am, I steer away from memoirs. They tend to template: a young woman goes through a rough patch, then tries something impossibly challenging, which yields a self-discovery (often a realization that it was all her father's fault).

And that template is here. I didn't trust all of it, surely, and found it incomplete. Yet, I also found it un-put-downable.

This was a real page-turner. I read it in one day. So I have to give credit to Tara Westover for how she wrote this ~330 page memoir. It was engaging and interesting for the majority of the book. That is the principal reason for my 4 stars.

The author of this memoir grew up in a rural area in Idaho. Like every book Glennon writes, Untamed felt like a conversation between my soul and her soul. Wow. I want to eat this book so it becomes part of me. I'd really love to memorize it so that Glennon's words could come spilling out of my mouth as needed.

#vlbookclub Untamed by Glennon Doyle. I couldn’t put this book down and finished it in 3 days. It gave me everything I love most: a real life human who’s putting their pain, struggle, wins and losses out in the open and shares all that she learned in the process. The way the book is structured- it keeps you on your toes. A new lesson, a new realization, a new AHA moment is around the corner in every story she shares. This is the first book I’ve read of @glennondoyle and im officially a fan.
This book was written for Glennon Doyle to validate herself while simultaneously looking down on other women. Nothing about this book was empowering.

Read this book. I know you've heard about it. The hype is real. It's a beautifully written, blisteringly honest, unflinching examination of a woman's journey to herself.

When I started this book I was all like, "fuck yes, with that cheetah analogy. Get you, queen" and then I read another 20 pages and I was like, "ugh... calm down, queen."

Rambling and lacked something. How can a book about being honest about who you are feel insincere? I have tried to put my finger on what makes it off for me and the only thing I can come up with is the tone does not sound like she has found joy but anger.

I just don’t buy it.

Another inspiring and insightful book from Glennon Doyle! I really enjoyed this memoir, and I especially liked her story about how she met the love of her life, Abby Wambach. I also appreciated the advice about learning to trust yourself more and having the courage to break free from harmful gender stereotypes. This is a book I'll probably read again. Highly recommended if you're looking for some inspiration.

Ive never been so torn on my feelings about a book before. I have loved Glennon’s two previous books. I’ve bought them and given them to family and friends, but this one…Im not so sure.
Before this book I would classify Glennon as a Christian writer of memoirs. Im not sure what I would call her now…and neither is she.
Here is what I can say for sure: Glennon is an incredible writer. She has a gift for arranging words on a page so beautifully that it causes you to hang onto every single word. With

I couldn’t finish this book if I’m being perfectly honest. She comes across as a bit preachy & knowing all the right ways to do something. If someone wants to use Botox or straighten their hair - let them without being judgmental . I think the last straw was when she said she broke free of her blow dryer & let her curls go free, but her author photo is a photo of her with straight hair.

Things I now know about the author of Untamed:

1. She often addresses her children as baby, often in the form of a question, such as: "Baby? We can do hard things."
2. She and Abby, her wife and also my favorite human in the book, nearly always begin sentences with the word babe. As in: "Babe? Are you sure you want to do this?"
3. She sees no need to explain herself to anyone, ever again, a concept which I've been working on myself for quite some time, and which I did find heartening and inspiring.

I was looking forward to reading this book but that feeling didn’t last long...right from the start I felt like I couldn’t relate to this woman who claims that “a responsible mother is not one who slowly dies for her children”. Do we make sacrifices for our kids? Of course! but they are not so paralyzing and life altering as this woman claims they are. And don’t get me started on the whole cheetah story 🙄.

I normally love her and the way she writes but this one was hard. It started well and just went downhill the more I listened. This book was very disjointed and didn’t flow. I felt it was more of a lecture and had to take breaks because it just wasn’t enjoyable.

I really, really admire Glennon Doyle. I've read all of her books. I follow her on social media. Together Rising is one of the very best nonprofit organizations out there.

But this book was not my favorite. I can't quite put my finger on why.

Glennon Doyle is an activist, speaker, writer and founder of her own philanthropic organization, “Together Rising”, a community focused on raising funds for high-risk women and children. Using her knowledge and life experience, Doyle brings her bestselling author skills back to the table with “Untamed”.

The best way to describe “Untamed” is as

There was no rhyme or reason why the structure would abruptly change many times throughout the book. I can't even begin to count the times a section of the book would begin about one topic and meander into s

I love glennon and her honesty. I was not crazy how this was written. Like streams of consciousness, kind of all over the place....

1.5 stars.

I want to interrogate every person I know who gave this "memoir" 5-stars. Perhaps we didn't read the same book. This memoir was a collection of blog posts devoid of substantive material written in an easy to swallow 2019 tone. No chapter is longer than a couple of pages because Glennon understands her audience spends much of their time on social media and can only chew small, palatable bites. I could envision the inspirational quote squares for Instagram as I read. Her tone is sanctimo

Glennon Doyle’s biggest flaw is also her greatest strength: she thinks her experience is singular. It has allowed her to be the mouthpiece for so many women trapped in the patriarchy and unsure how to get out, but it also puts a barrier around her. This is a memoir about a woman leaving her husband for a wife and finding herself, but it’s not about coming out or queerness. It is, but Glennon won’t fully lean into that; instead she invents her own language and narrative to discuss something that

I really wanted to like this book more. I like Glennon and her activism, a lot, and I really appreciated her chapter on racism. I think, as other reviewers have mentioned, I was expecting a memoir rather than a lecturing, continuous mic drop. Another reviewer mentioned ‘self aggrandizing’ and I’m afraid I agree. I’m happy for Glennon and all, but this book did not resonate with me very much. I liked sections of it very much, though. She’s so engaging.

DNF this book in part 3. I’m really surprised with all of the high reviews on this book. Glennon is very preachy and frankly, does not stop rambling. She basically said everything in her first book was a lie, well, that doesn’t set the tone very well for this book. Homegirl is quite smug, not a fan of this one. 👎🏻

Untamed is a stunning collection of essays on feminism, spirituality, and intersectionality, just to name a few. Doyle is untaming and unlearning western society's expectations of how a person should look and act accordingly, and uncovering the reason (or lack thereof) that we have been conditioned to think this way, the cages we unconsciously live in. The Knowing inside of her guides her away from the boxes of religion and sexuality, and in turn she finds her Self, as well as the truest love sh

The book women need to read at this precise moment in time to hear one clear and overarching message:

Trust. Your. Damn. Self.

If taken seriously, the message of Untamed will completely upend lives...may it be so.

I wanted to like this more than I actually did. The intention behind this book is great-allow women to be their true selves not dictated by what the world expects of them. That in itself, I’m onboard with. But for much of the book I found myself swinging between “yes!” And “ugh!” She comes across as pretentious and unlike able in some chapters and others I wanted to be her friend. It was kind of a let down for me. Not sure that I will read her others based on this one.

This might be a wonderful self help book for the young woman who is bulimic at age 10 and an alcoholic/drug addict for over a decade. Glennon found answers through words, blaming white men, and inner "truth", however the chapter where Glennon's mother lost a night's sleep because Glennon wanted to cut her bangs at age 40 might be the actual big reveal into her insecurity and years of abuse.
I particularly found disturbing her contradictions. She preaches being true to oneself, but as an example

I’m sure I will get flack for this, but this book was NOT for me. It started off strong, I liked her anecdotal stories that showed her vulnerability and things I had not thought of before but then she went on this God journey and said about 100 times, “and then I met Abby” and “After I met Abby,” “I love Abby so much,” “Abby is so great,” like I get it. This book is basically an homage to blessed Abby and how much her life changed after she became “untamed.” Which I agree with rejecting societal

Glennon Doyle is the kind of human we look to in these hard times. And this book is the kind of literature we should read. As much as we are staying inside, we should endeavor to look inside, too—the way that she does, the way she encourages others to. A necessary, beautiful book.

3.5 stars!

This is my second book by this author and I have to say it’s one of the prettiest covers I’ve ever seen, which if I’m being honest, is what drew me in. I went back and forth between the physical copy and the audiobook, which was read by author Glennon Doyle.

It was a powerful and insightful look into the life of the author, and I loved her fight for inequality, but I always have a hard time rating memoirs. I enjoyed some chapters and some were just okay, but I think the one take-away fr

The whole time it felt like the author was trying to convince herself, and the reader, that she finally got it right and has figured out everything. Too repetitive at times. Felt all over the place, jumping from one topic to another hardly related one without really diving in and exploring the core of the specific problem. Politics and race talks sounded shallow, unversed and out of place.

I enjoy non-fiction books but I rarely read them. Mostly because there is an abundance of fiction books that I have to read. But I felt Untamed needed to be read. I am not in the large universe of people who follow author Glennon Doyle’s blog and I didn’t read her first two books. I was aware of her popularity and her marriage to soccer star and Olympic gold medalist Abby Wambach after divorcing her husband with whom she has three children but that’s about it.

The reviews for Untamed have, for th

Never judge the book by its cover, because the book itself is not colorful and glittery on the inside at all.

This book is all about Glennon, the author, telling us about how she became sober when she got pregnant and then giving all the reasons she could find, to tell why she divorced her husband to marry a girl, the main reason being her internal voice told her so. A lot of chapters also tell us about her kids being extremely empathetic, and amazing. I don't blame her; every mother is biased.

You know what? She bugs me often both in here and in all her other books (for example, she acts super surprised that her daughter got in to this competitive soccer team that she tried out for even though she didn't have the skills, but dude, they show up to the tryouts with Abby Wambach! Of course she was going to get in to the soccer team--even she'd never seen a soccer ball). In other words, though she tries hard, sometimes she doesn't fully see how her life is not like normal people's lives.

Unfortunately I could tell pretty early on that this book was not for me. The tone of the book seems to be “Screw the world, I’ll do what I want”. As a Christian I don’t live for myself first. Please understand that this is just my personal reaction to what was only 20-30 pages of the book. This was my first experience with Doyle and I would love to hear your honest thoughts on whether I should pick this one back up again.

Rounded up from 2.5 stars. This book is not for me but I can understand why it appeals to a large variety of folks. I prefer memoirs with at least somewhat of a clear narrative arc and the timeline in this novel is anything but linear. This felt more like a self help book than a memoir, and while self help books can be great, that was not what I was going for when I picked up this book. Glennon is clearly a skilled writer but this just wasn't my fave!
A beautiful cover is about all this books has going for it. Wish I didn't spend money on this one.

To be honest I didn't like this nearly as much as Love Warrior. Some major reasons why:
1. The format- This read more like bite size vignettes- little slice of life stories with a metaphor that would fit nicely into a magazine article, a longer form facebook post, or as notes for a part of a talk. Which makes sense- that's how she reaches most of her wide audience. I can see why she might have moved to this style of writing. She's a busy lady, here there and everywhere- kids, a new-ish wife, a bu

4.5 stars

I really enjoyed this book. There were just so many pieces of advice or things that she experienced that just sort of resonated with me. There is a lot that I will take away from this book. It just left me with an overall hopeful, positive and loving feeling. It is one of those books that you can go back to over and over and take something new away from it each time.

I think this is a book that people seem to either love or hate. I have heard a lot of people say that she talked so much a

So this cover is gorgeous and I’m sure many of us have decided to grab it based on that alone, I’m guilty because seriously, it’s SO pretty. But, this one definitely won’t be for everyone. I’m a fan of the author, I’ve read one of her books before so I was familiar with her style. She’s very open and honest about her life and her struggles and there were definitely some parts I could relate to. There also many parts that I couldn’t relate to either. She can come across as preachy and while that

‘Every time you’re given a choice between disappointing someone else and disappointing yourself, your duty is to disappoint that someone else. Your job, throughout your entire life, is to disappoint as many people as it takes to avoid disappointing yourself.’

Another wonderful memoir from Glennon Doyle. Loved it

I’m going to sit with my feelings about this book for a spell before I give it a star rating. (Update: I decided on a 3-3.5 star rating.) I did like a lot of the themes and opinions and experiences this author shared with us through a variety of moments curated to become this collected piece. There were definitely things that resonated with and challenged me.
4.5. Exactly the right book to read during social distancing.

Not bad, not amazing either — although I think it's pretty awesome that her ex husband and wife (Abby Wombach) play on the same co-ed soccer team. Coincidentally, I read Wolfpack (Wombach's book) last summer and had no idea they were married until picking this one up.

A real life modern family.

I also agreed with a lot of her points on how religion tries to fit god into a box, or glass, the same with sexuality.

"When women lose themselves, the world loses its way. We do not need more selfless wom

This one is going on my favorites list.


I have only lived with this memoir for a short time (and I do say lived with literally) it was like I got a roommate who was inconsiderate in that they didn't care about being polite, or walking on egg shells. She called me out on my shit and said "What are you gonna do about it?" and I couldn't even get mad because it felt really good to stop ignoring things just because they are hard to face.

In that time that I switched between the physical and audio-bo

In January, I received an ARC of this for an honest review. Usually when I'm asked to do such things, I always decline because the bulk of my reading is actually audios. But I quickly accepted because I loved, loved this author's Love Warrior and Carry On, Warrior: Thoughts on Life Unarmed. I started the book immediately after it came in the mail ... really, it only took about 10 seconds to rip that package open. Ten pages in, I thought, "Oh NO!!!" I wasn't liking this one. I got to page 34 and

In Glennon Doyle's latest novel Untamed she talks about everything (as she usually does) from her split from her husband, to meeting her wife, how that impacted her family, faith, friendships, work and everything else in between. I have read Doyle's two previous book and I thoroughly enjoyed Carry On, Warrior: Thoughts on Life Unarmed , I love how honest, open and transparent she is in her writing, and especially how one can relate to her challenges. I was very excited when I heard about her
I tried so hard not to give this 5 stars but it’s inevitable!!!! This was sweet funny heart hitting and wonderfully written!
Lots of great messages but so obviously influenced by therapy. Still enjoyable and worthwhile. Full review to come.

I remember reading Love Warrior and thinking "there are parts of this story that are missing." I didn't fault the author for excluding them, but it felt incomplete, and I didn't know why/how. After following Glennon on social media and seeing her romance with Abby unveiled, I hoped she would write another book that would fill in those gaps. And hooboy, I'm so glad this book is here!

And it's not just that her story feels more complete. It's that this book hit me at the exact right time in my life

I was so excited to be gifted an advanced copy of this book! I’m a huge fan of Glennon Doyle and this book was by far my favorite! I really wanted to plow through it quickly but found myself needing to slow down and savor each little nugget of wisdom that she shares! I’d find myself laughing out loud then dissolving into tears at how it touched my heart. Most chapters were like savoring a delicious piece of candy... but some chapters were not as sweet and hit at the core of thinking deeper about

The majority of this book felt like a message from the universe. There are words, sentences, and entire chapters that felt specifically written for me in this specific moment in time. There are a few short chapters that felt superfluous and could’ve been left out. But overall, it’s Glennon’s signature brand of honesty, vulnerability, and ‘you can also live this way’ ness that makes the book. Love her or hate her, you will walk away from this book with your head held a little higher. And you will

I don’t understand what the hype was about . This book did nothing for me except really annoy me. The author seemed so shallow and just couldn’t relate to her at all or the messages she received. First there were some keys but then they disappeared and then there were some loosely strung together chapters which didn’t flow.

Indulgent. Preachy. I am love. You are probably not. Maybe I don’t like self help books? I had no idea what I was getting into and people whose taste jives with mine, much of the time, raved about this book. It was a painful slog for me. Won’t be reading her again. Bleck. Need a palate cleanser.

3.5 stars although I’m torn between 3.5 and 4. I really liked most of the book but some of the things she said I didn’t agree with and kind of annoyed me. Mostly she made lots of sense and I found myself wanting to be more like her and also feeling inadequate as I’m sure was not the point of this book. I’m sure she meant it to be inspiring.

Messy, raw and beautiful.

It’s safe to say that Glennon has a true gift. I really tried to take my time while reading and soak in each and every page. The short chapters made me pause and reflect, and I filled a number of pages of my journal with my own thoughts and her powerful words.

Usually once I’m done a book, I either donate it or share it with a friend, but this one I’m keeping forever. I plan on returning to it at many points throughout my life.

Wow. This had lots of little lines that left such a big impression. 🤯 I sort of loved that about this book!

Untamed is one of the most powerful and inspiring books I’ve ever read. It is the story of a woman releasing herself from all the cages, people, institutions, and beliefs that don’t serve her and coming out more radiant than she has ever been. Why? Because she trusts herself. Because she stands tall in her narrative. Because she has reclaimed her entire life and she’s stopped caring what everyone wishes and wants of her, but instead has listened to herself; to her own knowing. She’s become #Unta

But then I started highlighting more and more.. there is some serious gold in here. I've heard many of these lessons, but they're ringing true and more beautifully as written as part of Glennon's modern day life stories. Maybe I kn

Here is what I read in 12 pages-
She decided she knows what is in the mind of a cheetah
Then she decided she became oppressed starting at age 10 because someone told her the story of Adam and Eve
Then she decided shampoo bottles are sexist

I have never been so disappointed with a book and have never quit one so quickly.

Even though I think Glennon Doyle is a little crazy and I would only be able to take her personally in small doses, her book is saying what needs to be said to many women, my sister and myself, included.

thoroughly enjoyed listening to this while walking outside... it was v therapeutic. i rented this book randomly, not knowing anything about the author. i was pleasantly surprised to find her perspectives on how to live freely and true to your own knowing very captivating and inspiring :)

I listened to the author read this book which always makes it better for me. Glennon Doyle paints a true picture of herself: her struggles, her expectations of herself and other people, expectations of other people for her, her longing to figure out what it really means to be a woman. She is nothing like me but everything like me.

This was an interesting for me. I went back and forth between rolling my eyes, at Glennon's seeming naivete- of course SHE can just do whatever the hell she wants- and feeling choked up when she said things I know to be the truth.
As a woman in my fifties, I read this book wishing that younger women- my daughters generation- would read and BELIEVE the message. I was in my forties before I gave myself permission to build a life that works for me. For years after, I still felt guilt for all the pe
2.5/5, rounded down because frankly, it was a disappointment.

WOW this book is a treasure. gifted to me by my mum (i must say i was slightly alarmed when i saw her battered copy with notes in every margin and every other page dog-eared, but my copy would soon come to look the same), i think every woman should read this book. i was highlighting the entire thing and there’s so many nuggets of wisdom and truths that made me just want to scream YES THAT’S IT SHE PUT IT INTO WORDS (which i actually did scream out loud once). i wish i could have given this book

I don't see why is this book marked as self-help?

DNF halfway trough because I just don't care anymore and it just made me angry!!
This book is an insult to other nonfiction books that I have read with similar topics.
Pretty cover, but everything in it is just bland, disappointing, and uninspiring.
Overall, the author's voice is unconvincing. I just don't buy what you are selling type of situation.

I don’t usually write reviews but I had to express my opinion on this one. From start to finish, I couldn’t find purpose or reason for this book, and it completely missed the mark as an important work of literature, let alone something that deserves to be published. The chapters are a collection of disjointed thoughts and the few semi-promising ideas are never realized. My only emotion by the end: disgust. I only finished it as quickly as I did was to get it over with; I’m so glad it’s done.

Got half way through & decided life is too short to read this kind of crap. The author comes across as self centred & unlikable, her ideas & advice seem narrow, as though she is directing it at one kind of woman- white, privileged & mainstream. And while I am two of those things I still couldn’t connect with 99.9% of what she was saying. This is not my style of empowerment. This book is another example of when a book gets too much hype that I should just steer clear.

Glennon can be so brilliant and her writing can really make me think and readjust my old opinions. Some of this book is really good. Some is a little too preachy and religious for me. If you haven't read her, start with her first book "Love Warrior."
All her books make great discussions for girlfriends!

I don’t have the emotional energy to dissect why the market for this kind of blind privilege is problematic. Very Rachel Hollis-y, white feminist, and lacking in self-awareness. It was part memoir, part toxic “self-help” influencer clichés. Big yikes.

I loved this. Just read it.

The authors personal stories and insights were so eye opening. I connected with her memoir and everyone should pick up a copy of this book. Highly recommend!

This is a bit self aggrandizing, but what do you expect? It’s a collection of personal essays, social commentary, feminist ideas, etc. It’s about how she became a new woman; her true self. Is it perfect? Absolutely not. But several essays struck chords with me, especially the one about raising a son (I have two). One reviewer likened this to Rachel Hollis, and to that I say bullshit. This was much better than her drivel.

I love how this book is so self reflective and it really goes deep into understanding. I feel like I'm a lot like Glennon is the way she's so self reflective and able to be so self aware, I aspire to that.

Untamed is basically many short chapters of stories, thoughts, observations, philosophies, train of thought, and it makes you reflect and think about it.

I enjoyed the first half more than the second half. She talks about self awareness, children, family, sexuality, religion, spirituality, and a
Her best book yet. Truthful, raw, inspiring, and spiritual. I seriously want to buy a copy for every woman in my life, hold her hand, look in her eyes and tell her that she is a "god-damned cheetah".

Unpopular opinion but this book is not good? Maybe my expectations were too high.

While I enjoyed a few of Glennon’s stories, I couldn’t help but feel that majority of them were fake... Every piece of dialogue was contrived. I'm torn here. I really liked some of the things she was saying. Women empowerment, be yourself regardless of what the world thinks, love is love, racism is disgusting...love all of that! I was nodding my head and agreeing like crazy. Thinking, "she really nailed this!"

There are hundreds, if not thousands, of Holocaust fiction books in the English language alone. This is not the one to read.

This kind of book is hard to rate. It's based on the true story of Lale Sokolov, a Slovakian Jew who volunteered to go to Auschwitz to save his older brother and, through a combination of true grit and luck, he's able to survive and even fall in love. Who wants to give the story of a Holocaust survivor just two stars? Isn't that a bit heartless?

What a waste of an amazing story on an incapable writer. There is no 'prose', there is really just "he did this, and then he did that". No depth of emotion, no depth of characters, heck - no characters! I couldn't tell you ONE personality trait of Gita's. Lale also, is so thinly drawn I know nothing about him other than he is supposedly charming.

The dialogue between characters is ridiculously empty and the whole thing feels like the most superficial experience of Auschwitz possible.

A unsettling but gripping novel, based on the true story of Lale, a Slovakian Jew caught up in the horrors of the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp during WW2. He speaks several languages, so soon finds himself employed in the camp as the tattooist, the man responsible for inscribing prisoners numbers on their arms. He soon meets and falls in love with Gita, a fellow inmate., but can their love survive the horrors of life inside a concentration camp?

The German government needed workers for their labor camps. In 1942, all families in Slovakia were ordered to provide a child eighteen or older for work detail or risk having the entire family sent to concentration camp. Lale Sokolov hoped that by going to Prague to await these instructions his family would be safe. He did not expect to be forced into a cattle wagon and be transported to Auschwitz. He was determined to do as he was told, reveal little about himself and always be observant.

This is an incredible book with a story that demands to be heard.

The year is 2018 and it gladdens me that books like this are still being written. It’s important that we never forget Auschwitz and that we never forget the war crimes Nazi Germany committed. Why? Because we need to know and understand what humanity is capable of, we need to know what extreme hate looks like so we can work towards building a world free from it. This is one of our darkest hours, and we need to remember it.

There are certain books that tell a story so important that it overrides other aspects of itself, and therefore can overcome certain narrative shortcomings. This is a novel based on the true story of Lale and Gita Sokolov, two Slovakian Jewish prisoners at Auschwitz. Lale, being able to speak many languages, was given the job of tattooing the numbers on the incoming prisoners, he met Gita when she was in his line to be tattooed and was immediately taken with her.
Being the tattooist at the camp gave Lale much more freedom of movement then most prisoners and he came upon money and jewels from the murdered Jews to get food to keep other prisoners alive

Against all odds...

The story of two extraordinary people, Lale and Gita survive the horrors of Auschwitz and find solace in each other. The book is based on their true story.

Lale with compassion and sensitivity, tattoos numbers on the arms of prisoners. While doing this he forms a connection with Gita that leads to a tender and charming love story.

I’m always reluctant to read works of fiction dealing with the Holocaust - although I’ve read my fair share. It’s not that I find it too hard to read about atrocities, it’s that I worry that unless they are done right, fictional accounts run the risk of trivializing this horrific chapter in human history.

The Tattooist of Auschwitz reads like fiction, but is based on interviews the author conducted with its protagonist, Lale Sokolov, over a three year period very late in Lale’s life. A Jew transp

As with all holocaust stories, my heart hurts. It bleeds for all those who suffered and still shocks me.
But the survivors and the hope is unbelievably real. How anyone ever recovers, I will never know. Forgiveness and healing are themselves a miracle and Each story as necessary and precious as the next.

Thank you, Lale, for sharing yours. 4.5⭐️

4.5 stars! My heart opened up and welcomed Lale in from the first page of this powerful story.

Lale Sokolov survived the brutal hell known as Auschwitz for over two years where his “job” was to tattoo prisoners with their identifying number. What he endured and witnessed is nothing short of horrific and devastating.

review_text:
EXCERPT: Thirsty and exhausted, he is surprised when the piece of paper is yanked from his hand. An SS officer pulls off Lale's jacket, rips his shirtsleeve and pushes his left forearm flat on the table. He stares in disbelief as the numbers 32407 are stabbed into his skin, one after the other by the prisoner. The length of wood with a needle embedded in it moves quickly and painfully. Then the man takes a rag dipped in green ink and rubs it roughly over Lale's wound.

The Tattooist of Auschwitz (The Tattooist of Auschwitz #1), Heather Morris

In April 1942, Lale Sokolov, a Slovakian Jew, is forcibly transported to the concentration camps at Auschwitz-Birkenau.

When his captors discover that he speaks several languages, he is put to work as a Tätowierer (the German word for tattooist), tasked with permanently marking his fellow prisoners.

Imprisoned for more than two and a half years, Lale witnesses horrific atrocities and barbarism—but also incredible acts of

A powerfully emotional book about the love, resilience and surviving through the worst possible circumstances. The Tattooist of Auschwitz is a true story of Lale, a Jew, who find himself trapped in a pool of uncertainty.

A true story that tells you all the horrible truths of what happened inside the camps. The unfairness of life and the people trapped inside. The families who tried to stick together with every strength left in their body. The

4 Stars

Lale Sokolov was taken to Auschwitz via cattle car. While being transported, he made a decision to survive. Almost immediately, Lale was made the “Tatowierer” - the Tattooist of Auschwitz - he tattooed the numbers on prisoners that came into both Auschwitz and Birkenau and he saw the haunted looks on everyone’s faces. He learned to be quick, efficient, and look down. One woman haunted him and he memorized her number and he waited.

Perfect 5 stars for the The Tattooist of Auschwitz! This book follows the true story of Slovakians Lale and Gita who experienced spending several years in the Nazi concentration camp during the Holocaust period. Lale was a linguist; a Jew; prisoner 34902; and was a Tetovierer (tattooist in German) in the Auschwitz concentration camp in Birkenau, Poland.

Lale was giving the role of tattooing fellow prisoners identification numbers on their arms.

Written based on oral testimony from the protagonist Lale, this is a harrowing tale but with a feel-good ending about life and even love inside Auschwitz. Kind of along the same lines, yet on opposite sides of the barbed wire, as The Book Thief, Morris weaves a story about what life was like during the darkest parts of WWII and describes, sometimes in excruciating detail, the various tortures that the prisoners of Auschwitz underwent. Apparently, the spokespeople for Auschwitz have not a few mis

I really don't know how to rate this - on the one hand the actual true story that this novel is based on absolutely deserves to be heard, on the other hand - did Lali (not Lale as in the book) actually approve of this fictionalization of his life story considering it was published years after his death? Because I think it would have had more of an impact if, you know, the whole story had been non-fiction. Though that is my major complaint about all fictional WWII novels that focus on the Holocau

This book is a thoughtful, fictionalized account of a true story and one that certainly deserves being told. Though it isn't a new story, it still had the power to shock and appall me, the way I am again and again when I read of this shameful time in human history. It isn't, perhaps as engaging in terms of plot as some other books I've read dealing with this subject, but it is nonetheless a deeply moving account of two people in horrendous circumstances, which should never be forgotten. The Tattooist of Auschwitz by Heather Morris is an incredibly sad story of a young mans experience as a prisoner in the concentration camp during the holocaust. The cruelty and horrors that he went through just to stay alive were heartbreaking. This is a true story and one that will stay with me.

The Tattooist of Auschwitz is a story based on the true-life experiences of young Slovakian-Jew, Lale Sokolov, who was forcibly removed from his home town in 1942 and transported to Auschwitz-Birkenau. Lale managed to survive this experience until the camps were liberated by the Russians towards the end of WWII. The Tattooist of Auschwitz chronicles the real life story of Slovakian Jews Lale and Gita Sokolov, who first met in the infamous concentration camp in 1942.

Although the pair fell deeply in love and ultimately survived the atrocities of Auschwitz, their journey was by no means an easy one. The trials and tribulations they each endured are vividly and affectingly illustrated in this phenomenal story by Heather Morris, with whom Lale personally shared his detailed history with in his final

The Tattooist of Auschwitz is the first novel by Australian author, Heather Morris. At the age of twenty-five, Ludwig (Lale) Eisenberg, a Slovakian Jew, was transported to Auschwitz. He was tattooed with the number 32407. He was transferred 4km down the road to Birkenau (Auschwitz II) where, possibly due to his multi-lingual knowledge, his grooming and his demeanour, he was assigned to help Pepan, the man who tattooed the arm of each Jew entering the camp.

In July of 1942, he was re-tattooing nu

Australian author Morris has written an enthralling story about the Holocaust that is a mix of memoir and historical fiction. Morris tells the story of Lali Sokolov, a Slovakian Jew imprisoned at Auschwitz in 1942, whose knowledge of multiple languages lands him a job as the tattooist for the camp. Inking numbers on thousands of arms enables him to meet Gisela Fuhrmannova, known as Gita Furman. The two fall in love and clandestinely develop a relationship while living at the concentration camp.

He too has chosen to stay alive for as long as he can, by performing an act of defilement on people of his own faith.

The Tattooist of Auschwitz is based on the real-life experiences of Lale Sokolov, a Slovakian Jew who was sent to Auschwitz Concentration Camp during World War II. He worked as a tattooist at Auschwitz-Birkenau camps tattooing identification numbers on thousands of prisoners held there. He witnessed violence, death and horrors over the three years he spent in captivity. We've been watching the Mindy Project (a rewatch for me, first time for my husband) so when I saw this series of six essays by Mindy Kaling it was an obvious download. The Kindle version is free to Amazon Prime members and after you download them you can access the audio free as well. Obviously I listened to this in audio read by the author - this essay is about social anxiety in Hollywood, how she made friends after moving to Los Angeles to write for The Office, her 40th birthday compared to BJ

Oddly enough, even though I like Ms. Kaling when I see her on talk shows (primarily Colbert), I have never seen a single episode of 'The Office' or 'The Mindy Project'. I DID read her first book, as well as her early play Matt & Ben, and enjoyed both. This is really just a short excerpt from her new book Nothing Like I Imagined, and while I relate a LOT to her social anxiety, I also realized that she is perhaps best when taken, like this, in small doses.

Also: since she speculates here about Mat

People who know I have social anxiety like to say things like: “You may not want to go out, but you should just force yourself. You’ll be glad you did!” That is a lie.

I loved everything about this and the affirmation of everything that comes with being introverted and socially anxious and lonely but still preferring that to being in the company of people who aren’t really friends. Finding the friends you feel comfortable with and don’t drain your energy can be as hard as finding a romantic m

Loved these totally relatable stories about being socially awkward and yet wanting people around. You don’t picture her being awkward in any way, but the stories she tells are so me! And being at BJ Novak’s 40th birthday party at chateau marmont! Yes please!

I enjoyed this short story in which Mindy shares about her social anxiety and how it relates to her birthdays - from her 9th to her 40th! The way Mindy writes, you really feel like you're her friend. It almost felt like I too was invited to BJ Novak's 40th birthday bash, but sadly, I wasn't.
I wish Kaling was always writing books and also I relate pretty strongly to her feelings about parties.

I will be logging these essays as separate books, because I have individual thoughts on each and for those numbers, baby. Buckle up these will be detailed, long, and spoil everything. (No one has to read these. This is for me)

I'm pretty this essay is my favorite one. I love friendship content.

While this offer would make most kids jump for joy, Mindy was filled with dread because she (incorrectly) believed that her South Asian (Tamil/Bengali) parents "would accidently mess up some important aspect of the quintessential American birthday party". She had me at the title! This short read was filled with Kaling's humor and down-to-earth thoughts/feelings. It was a fun way to spend a little time.

Nothing Like I Imagined


Since this is a collection of quick personal essays I’ve decided to review them all in one swoop anthology style.


Please Like Me (But Keep Away) - 4 Stars - This essay reviews the time when Mindy moved to LA to write for the office and had to find/make friends as an adult. A most daunting task indeed. She speaks of wanting a close group of girlfriends and even her experience in trying to join one and of how she somehow ended up with a male BFF. Making

Did Mindy crawl inside my brain to write this essay?

Quotes:

For a socially anxious person, it is both flattering and disconcerting to be asked into the holy sacrament of best friendship by a total stranger.

There’s a misconception that celebrities must love socializing, because all we ever see them do is get dressed up, go to fancy parties, and wait for people to take their picture. But you can be famous and still be shy, a plain introvert, or even a person with social anxiety. I once read somew

Oh my God, she's so self-important, obvious and judgemental. Like we all don't know who she's talking about just because she doesn't actually write out their names?

We're supposed to think she's the cool girl for eating a burger while making fun of girls who eat salads because there's pressure to be thin?! Like that makes her any better than they are...

Honestly, I'm so done with her after reading this, and the rest of her so-called bullshit essays. I don't know how they've got such high ratings.

Social Awkwardness
Review of the Amazon Original kindle eBook (2020)

Funny short essay about writer/actress Mindy Kaling's social awkwardness told with her typical self-deprecatory humor.

Please Like Me is one of the six-part Nothing Like I Imagined collection of autobiographical short comedy essays by Mindy Kaling available through Amazon Originals.

I LOVED these 6 books released today (10/6/2020) by Mindy Kaling. I would recommend reading them and then listening to them. I could listen to her all day telling stories. They were funny, uplifting, touching and get 5 stars ⭐️ from me.

Classic Mindy!

Whether she is being utterly relatable (anxious about her 9th birthday party in her curry-scented, ethnic home) or utterly unrelatable (anxious about her best friend’s 40th birthday at celebrity haunt Chateau Marmont), Mindy will have you chuckling all the way through.
Loved it! And I totally agree about those party favor bags, haha
I feel seen.
I highly recommend listening to the audio version of this. I laughed out loud so many times!

Second in the series

Hysterical. I feel her anxiety. Learning some new escape options. This makes me want to back and read her other writings.
I feel the same, Mindy. Just because I want people to like me doesn't mean I want to hang out all the time. Funny, quick read.
I cannot deal about how relatable this was.

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

This story in particular starts somewhere interesting (the idea of being weird and not fitting in because of being Indian and having Swiss cheese instead of Kraft singles) and then goes so

2.5/5 stars

Please Like Me (but keep away) is a very quick read. Yup. That's how I have to start off this review. It was okay-ish. I was loving it, relating and possibly falling in love with Mindy, right before she started sounding like a rich, whiny, spoiled celebrity who can't be bothered with anything that isn't for HER in life. While, I had trouble swallowing some of her selfishness and privilege (that she somehow isn't aware of) , there were many good, relatable quotes and an overall, adorab

Short Story 2/6

First of all, this title reminds me of her book “Why is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me? (And Other Concerns).”

I don't know how Mindy managed to touch on such deep and personal topics in just one short story, but of course she did it. This story was all about social anxiety and being introverted and lonely in a new city with no friends. It was so relatable and she was able to put all my thoughts into words. It felt like I was listening to my friend talk to me.
