"

Honest and endearing read!

My 2nd short book by Mindy Kaling and such an  honest and endearing read. Mindy talks so easily about her not-so-easy-to-deal-with social anxiety, about her struggles as an Indian kid torn between Indian and American cultures (in places silly but definitely not an easy one), about her barometer for making friends, about craving female friendships in a new city but not just women to surround herself to make her feel not alone.

This quick read will make you laugh at place

In this original story, Mindy tries to convince me that I don't want to be her friend. This is because she doesn't really like people she doesn't know and has social anxiety. WELL Mindy, I hate to tell you, I feel like I want to be your friend more. She is a wonderful friend, from the way she explains her relationship with BJ. I am jealous. At least now, I know how to not scary you off. If we ever meet on the street, I will try not to run up to you say "I want to be your best friend", instead I

Mindy Kaling is my spirit author (if that is such a thing?) I LOVED this essay. It genuinely made me laugh aloud twice, and when I wasn’t chuckling aloud I was grinning to myself knowingly. It just made me smile as she shared her realisations that she would rather be lonely than bored, and rather be lonely than be friends with non-friends. It reminded me when my mum eloquently summed up why I had trouble making friends and socialising with people I didn’t know, “your problem is that you can’t st

This essay was definitely a nice reminder to myself that I don't need to force myself to find new friends. I would rather be lonely than bored. I would rather be lonely than to be friends with people that aren't really friends. At the end of the day being with people that don't make you feel seen or alive makes you feel lonelier than being by yourself. Mindy's stories about her introversion, quest to find friends, and social anxiety when she's 40 and well-known assured me that I'm not alone. She

So relatable, as always superbly written

Written in the honest and self observant way mindy does so well, the woman could be writing about toe nails growing and STILL make it a page turning and realistic commentary,
As always a 5* piece of writing that captures her feelings and those of a lot of others and is open enough to tell the stories how they really played out with a hint of knowing that shes certainly no the only one!

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

The Office is my husband’s favorite show and I totally hate it. I have glimpsed bits and pieces while he was watching and I hate Mindy and her body language on that show. I read this story as it came up as a suggestion on good reads. The content is mostly relatable and Mindy hit home where she talked about social anxiety and her barometer for making friends. I now love her for this piece ‘Lonely in LA’, it felt like she’s speaking my mind.

Mindy's description of her mom buying white cheese slices is so relatable - even to people who didn't grow up in a minority culture family. Can't we all remember a time when our parents just didn't get it?, but in reality it was just us wanting society and our peers to accept us. It's comforting to know that even still as an adult, she struggles with social anxiety, especially since celebrities are so often portrayed as attention seeking and confident.

My favorite of all of the essays, and the one I related to the most (and read more than once). It's SO difficult to make friends - real friends - at any age, but there's so many extra pitfalls as an adult female and I feel like Kaling nailed so many of the ones I've dealt with. (That insanity about restaurant ordering? I've experienced that firsthand, but with no one I consider a genuine friend).

Yes, I like you, Mindy Kaling, and I will gladly keep away!

This (free!) short Audible piece was ready by the author and I felt her words all the way down to the soles of my Irish-goodbye-dreaming feet! There are a small amount of people I don't mind hanging out with, but even with those I love best, I get overwhelmed/exhausted and need to go be by myself. Why can't people want to sit quietly and read a book, do art, or watch Netflix with me?

Loved Loved Loved!!

“Losing friends is hard, but losing fake friends, as it turns out, is pretty damn easy”

Growing up with anxiety I related to every aspect of this! I love Mindy from when she was on The Office and on! It’s funny yet hits home! Trying to find friends that I relate to and trying to get out of certain social events as an adult is hard and Mindy portrays exactly what it feels like! If you have social anxiety please read this!!

I fear I would be one of those random women demanding Mindy be my best friend that she references in this essay... Of course I'd be too shy to say it out loud, but I'd be thinking it. I really enjoyed the exploration of her anxiety and the challenges of finding meaningful friendship. Can't wait to read the rest of the series.

Short, sweet, funny, and relatable! It's always refreshing to see someone who you would otherwise think was completely outside of your spectrum (ie rich and famous where the world is their oyster) and realize that while, sure, they live a very different and privileged life they are still human- still no different than the rest of us in so many ways.

Mindy Kaling discusses cheese, and how important you think cheese is at your party as a child -- you know, that peer pressure to fit in and throw the perfect bash? And that all leads up to having a famous athlete steal your toast moment, which is fine, because being socially awkward means you may not want to be at a party anyways. And that is perfectly okay!

I like how Mindy Kaling is open about her life and is willing to share her experiences with us. I also like how she talks about herself in a way that makes you think she isn't a celebrity, but a normal person. This makes her stories very relatable. If you want to read a short, funny story, I recommend this book for you.

Great read

I suffer from social anxiety as well and this book gave me new ways to cope. I now know I can attend social events but have some people who know me well to make it a good experience. I was shocked to know Mindy has social anxiety. She is funny and brutally honest in this book. I just love her work.

I really enjoyed this essay. Mindy narrates her social anxiety is an entertaining and profound way. At several occassions, I agreed with her musings. Definitely worth a read!

One quote I really loved is:
Why is it that chatting with friends is energizing, but making small talk with acquaintances takes such monumental effort?

I Found My Twin!!

This is so me, and I didn't write It! Well detailed and truthful. It really shows we all are human, but we have differences that should be respected not slammed. The woman thing wearing ourselves out thinking what others may be thinking - RIGHT ON TARGET! Great job Mindy! Keep being you!

Mindy Kaling at her best— funny, timely, slightly self-deprecating, and relevant. Mindy’s gift is being able to recite my thoughts in a funnier and more articulate way. Pretty much everything about this essay collection was so relatable, even though I don’t spend my evenings running away from star-studded parties.

Relatable, witty, personal essay

What I love about Mindy Kalings writing is how she makes me feel like each part is written just for me, it's so relaxed and relatable it's like having a conversation with your mate.

Absolute Perfection

This one is incredible. It felt like Mindy was inside my head when it comes to social anxiety and my small but mighty friendship circle. Thank you Mindy for bringing this into the world and sharing with us all.

Very cute and relatable

Short, cute, relatable. I love the stories she told and that she got right to the point. I love Mindy and if I see her on the street as much as I would want to I won't ask her to be my best friend.

I'm not actually done yet, but this book is becoming more problematic by the page. In re: false memories and page 128: False memories are absolutely a thing. But when the example you use to illustrate this fact is a 1980's feminist who falsely accused her father of abuse and you follow up with "in the early 1980s and 1990s hundreds of innocent people were wrongly accused of sexual violence under similar circumstances. Many of them went to prison for it" you are being supremely irresponsible. The

After a reread I'm flipping a near 180 on this one. It's a very surface level look at Stoicism and western Buddhism aimed at dudebros. It still has some good things to say, but it's got so many problems that I don't even want to get into it, I just want to distance myself from it at this point and apologize for recommending it.

I would suggest Why Buddhism is True and The Practicing Stoic instead as much better books to read that cover the same ground more in depth, without any of the negatives.

I started out liking this book, I really did. By the time I was halfway in, his smug attitude about things he frankly knows jack shit about were getting on my nerves. He made some excellent points, all of which have been made countless times by other, more competent writers. Read Sartre, Camus, Siddhartha by Herman Hesse, and various Buddhist texts instead. Regurgitating Eastern philosophy and existentialism while swearing a lot only gets you so far. I stopped reading and returned this book.
What a load of self-indulgent, sexist codswallop.
Have you ever been in a bar and had a know-it-all tell you everything you need to know about life without any evidence to back up what he's saying? That's what this book felt like.
Definitely written by and for straight, white, entitled males. I have no fucks to give for this book or the author.

I knew after the first chapter that I probably wasn't the intended audience for this book. Most of it was sort of a "duh" for me, but I continued on in hopes I would learn something new...WOW, this author is SO self-indulgent. He misses no opportunity to remind us about what a complete "fuckboi" he was in his twenties. The problem with this is that his tone (and the fact that he brings it up over and over and over and over again) makes it sound like it is almost a point of pride rather than some

Has anybody been unfortunate enough to be sitting in a pub/restaurant, enjoying the ambience and possibly a meal, and out of nowhere, a rather drunk individual parks himself beside you, grinning profusely, and then just doesn't stop talking about his life, your life and everything HE thinks that you should be doing, but without any solid proof to back himself up? I have, and this book by Mark Manson made me feel like I was back in that pub, but with an even dodgier individual attempting to give

There are a lot of points in the first half of the book that I agree with: prioritizing fewer things and the right things; defining the right values and what you are willing to struggle for; being addicted to outrage and victimhood to avoid responsibility and acknowledging mistakes; etc. However, the tone is VERY heavy on this edgy dudebro persona that gets tiring easily, especially in the beginning where the author drops the F bomb every other sentence in order to seem “real” and contrarian. Th

“Giving too many fucks is bad for you.”
The Subtle Art of Not Giving a Fuck, Mark Manson



Where to begin?

Well for starters, Mark Manson is a real douche. There has never been a better husband than Mark Manson. Why? He doesn't put up with bullshit. If his wife looks like shit he tells her. He won't tolerate her looking bad no matter how much time she has spent getting ready to go out.

And we must take note of how edgy Manson is. He actually figured out you can remove the word care and replace it wi

Based on the title, I was pretty stoked for this, and the introductory essay explaining the author's Not Giving a F*ck theory made a lot of sense to me and made me really happy. Essentially, he says that the internet and the media demand that we give a f*ck about everything, but we only have so much time on Earth and so many f*cks to give and we have to choose who and what we spend those f*cks on.

Makes sense.

Unfortunately, the rest of the book turns into the same self-help drivel you see in any

you think you're getting a light, irreverent lifestyle/self-help book, but then it's actually just a few good ideas taken from Buddhism and then mixed in with conservative nonsense about "snowflakes," mixed with some casual misogyny and backdoor bragging. A book only a white straight man with rich parents could write.

I don't read self-help. I simply don't believe in the self-help genre. If you need a book to help you live your life you have bigger problems than whatever brought you to that book. That may seem harsh but its just my opinion and you are free to ignore it.

Since I don't read self-help, you may be asking "Erin, Why did you read this book?
Blame Popsugar. I'm doing the Popsugar 2017 Reading challenge and needed to read a book from a genre I don't usually read. As you can see if you look at my book

My, my! What a catchy title!



I wanted to see what all the hype was about, so I picked this up. And now that I'm done? Well, I agree with everything Manson says, but (like other reviewers have mentioned) everything he's written about is common sense stuff.
Is that revolutionary?

I think we have all seen this book on various bookstore displays, whether it be at the shops or the airport. The bright orange cover and the provocative F*ck word in the title. I like Manson's straight talking, no BS style. He lays it out for you in simple terms, and then tells you that you need to get over yourself if you want to be happy. That nobody is happy all the time, and that you will always have problems. It just depends on what you choose to worry about th

The Best of Nothing Like I Imagined
Review of the Amazon Original kindle eBook (2020)

This was the best of Mindy Kaling's series of comic essays on her recent life as a single mother and social introvert. Its main topic is her career as a TV producer esp. for the Netflix TV series Never Have I Ever (2020-). There is a bonus episode as well which follows Kaling in a "day in the life" scenario. This was lighthearted and entertaining and gave a peak at her behind the scenes work life.

Big Shot is one
This one is about a lesson Mindy learned when she tried to act like a big shot. It also tells us what an average workday looks like in Mindy's life. 💁‍♂️

I don’t know why Amazon didn’t release these essays as one ebook. I love all the different covers, but having so many different files to buy, download, and keep track of is unwieldy. And I had no idea whether there was an order to them. Turns out the last one of the collection is the one I picked to read first. But the upside is that it’s a way to cheat on my Reading Challenge!

Anyway, I love Mindy, I love her shows and movies, and I’ll read anything she writes. All of these stories are really g

Love it!

I love the warmth of Mindy Kaling’s writing.. ❤️ Makes you feel like you are talking to your best friend.

I love Mindy. This is still 5 stars. But this is the essay that I would like to say I'm a little wary of her last few paragraphs on fame and fortune. Just reminding everyone that the poor doesn't exist to make the rich feel better. I don't have anything against donating to charities but it's annoying when people do charities to make themselves better.
five stars for confirming that mindy kaling, rashida jones and ezra koenig are friends!

It was name dropping for obvious reasons, but Mindy works in the entertainment biz. What's really heartwarming are the little blurbs with pictures and her family life. I kinda want to know who is Max Davis.
Now this was a good story. But while I think the self-reflection is important, I still think that “Max Davis” was rude and his apology or rationalization of his behaviour was not sufficient.
Okay, who knows who "Max Davis" is because I want to know who the jerk is.

It wasn't until I got to the end of this essay that I realized that Big Shot wasn't the third essay like i'd assumed but the final one. Oh well...Big Shot is about how Mindy was inspired to essentially become a "big shot"- by picking up the tab of people she liked or wanted to impress- after hearing about how Jeff Ingold treated B.J. Novak and his friends to dinner. I love how she describes the act of treating people as a "voyeuristic experience" which she gained a lot of pleasure from. To me it

Direct and funny Mindy as always!

The last of Mindy's mini books but yet another well written read. It's her personal story on what generosity actually means and what it takes to be a 'big shot'. A host of A-list celebs appear in this short tale including Mindy sending cookies to Huge Jackman! The last section included a sneak peak of a day in her life with pictures which was just ok.As always, Mindy's directness and humor shines through the anecdotes and I look forward to more of her stories in

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

The combination of honesty + money + gossip + flaws is what makes this story great. We all have the same issues around donating and charity, I think, it's just rare that someone is open ab

This was the perfect way to wrap up Mindy's essay collection. It started with a funny story and, like Mindy does best, took lighthearted, fun stories to talk about deeper things. She talks a lot about her issues with generosity and overcompensating as a minority compared to the white men in the industry, as well as her struggles with constantly wanting people to like her. I think this is something that almost everyone struggles with, but it's not something that especially celebrities talk about

So this was a good read. A few lines made me pause and think and I immediately related to how I felt.
The one good part was how she drew the differentiation between GIVING and GENOROSITY

being generous is being absolutely above expectation. Even a thank you, to the point that it may look like you don't care, but you should care but not care for the after in a way that doesn't make you look callous or irreverent.
One of the better essays
I also loved how she took us through her day and broke the

The story/lessons she learns about being charitable without recognition is endearing and relatable. I thought it was a nice way to end the series of essays, but then she throws in an “extra” of her daily life. While I enjoy reading about her daily activities in that witty way she has of telling stories, I could have done without the swearing. Ending the book with the F*word put me off the whole thing. I’m being generous in giving it 4 stars.

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

This is actually the last part of the whole series. It's a good way to end it. It also includes a 'day in my life' kind of part at the end for people who are interested.

In this book she has shared an incident in which she hasn't shyed away from criticising herself. She's aware of the difference between generosity and giving.
She recognises her past mistakes and has grown above them now. It's like a coming of age tale squeezed into an essay.

The whole series was a good read all in all.

Authentic, funny, vulnerable

Mindy Kaling has such a real voice. She is able to talk about her life in a way that gives you a peek into the celebrity world as well as the real world foibles of a human being. I love her humor, which is both self deprecating and quick witted. As a fellow second generation American Tamilian, I am very proud of Mindy Kaling’s ability to talk about the immigrant experience in such a down to earth and relatable way.

In her final essay, Mindy talks about treating an A-list celebrity and his family to a Christmas dinner in Hawaii but not being thanked for it at the time and feeling bad about it. I wish she had named the celebrity!

A day in the life of Mindy Kaling was bonus content which was fun to read about!

Very intriguing and thoughtful essay

On what it means to be generous. I loved how Mindy took the reader on her journey of how her attitude and perspective on what it meant to her to have “made it” and how she tried to leverage it into relationships with others. I especially loved the ending as it truly shows the introspection and growth she has achieved along her journey.

In the story, Big Shot, Mindy talks about how she chased acknowledgement from others; paying for meals just to get some recognition in return. I can relate -- I always want people to like me although I don't like them. We should live life on our own terms.

I also loved seeing the behind-the-scenes portion as a producer.

I LOVED these 6 books released today (10/6/2020) by Mindy Kaling. I would recommend reading them and then listening to them. I could listen to her all day telling stories. They were funny, uplifting, touching and get 5 stars ⭐️ from me.

Perfect

This essay was a perfect ending to this incredible series. As someone who loves charity, it made my heart feel some serious things to go on that journey with her. I've always been a fan of Mindy's work, but these writings made me a fan of her.

Another great collection!

Funny and an easy read.
Mindy always keeps it real with her readers/listeners and that’s something I really appreciate about her. These short essays give you a glimpse into her life. I love all of these!

Nothing like I imagined

I enjoyed every one of the essays written in this series. Well written and funny. I read this series because I had recently watched "Late Night" and liked the character that Mindy Making played. Thanks

A fascinating glimpse inside the Hollywood machine, and Mindy remains incredibly relatable despite being in fantastically unrelatable situations (at least for me - imagine buying Hugh Jackman cookies?!). Love her writing as always.

Reflections and lessons learned:
“As it turns out I care more about people liking me more than seeing through justice”
Oh, if only more of us could be more honest about these obsessive moments! Wonderfully analysed

I love how Mindy enjoys treating other for their meal, but freezes when recognized. Don't we all want to be recognized and be the big shot? I don't know about you, but if I was a big shot, I too would freeze when actually recognized.

Enjoyable series!

I was hesitant to read Mindy Kaling's series of short essays but on the advice of a trusted friend I did. I found her to be funny, sincere and very interesting. I believe I will have to check out her other books!

Keeping it real

Loved the she kept it very real!
And sharing of ‘a day in the life of...’
I’m a huge fan and appreciate that she shared this aspect of her life and life lessons with us.

The end of Mindy's "Nothing Like I Imagined (Except for Sometimes)" collection with a bonus Day-in-the-Life section conclusion. "Big Shot" is a purposefully cringey story with admittedly funny writing.

Honest and relatable

What a gem! This is so refreshingly candid and human..a laugh out loud recount of Mindy’s journey to learn one of life’s big lessons. I would read it again when I’m feeling down just to give myself a pep talk.

It's kind of weird that I have to buy each chapter/essay separately on amazon. Nothing really groundbreaking about these essays but I like Mindy Kaling, I enjoy watching her interviews, and reading this book feels sort of like a series of short chats or blog posts. Entertaining.

Miss Big Stuff..who do you think you are?!

Great story about working and then segway into how Mindy is able to pay for other people's meal. Leveling up her game, but twisted lesson learned. Bonus story: a day in the life of Mindy Kaling.

Great Essay!

I really enjoyed listening to Mindy tell her story! She writes so effortlessly and really captures your attention. It feels like you are right there reliving these memories with her!

I began reading this right after I completed my binge of The Mindy Project, and honestly, Mindy Kaling is so brilliant that as she quite accurately points out in this book, I am obsessed with her. J/K, all I want to say is that her wit dazzles as usual through this book.

I loved the....end? The part with all the pictures. It's nice that she learned a lesson I guess but I wanted to end strong on some good laughs and this was hm let's say a little sad? And I feel a lot of secondhand embarrassment here.

Love this!!

Mindy is one of my favorite writers and actors out there. Hearing her real life stories and the things she is going through just make her all better. Thanks for sharing your world with us!!

The one in which Mindy develops an unhealthy obsession with buying fellow celeb's dinners, or her own way of buying interactions. Funny, with a heartfelt lesson about giving for the right reasons. Also, shout out to the Max Davis sleuths. Y'all are doing the Lord's work.
Very interesting take....

Amazing

Mindy is an unrivaled talent. She has a witty, fun voice that makes anything she writes a delight to read.

Lovely Prose

Her story was beautiful written that I could envision myself watching every action occur in real time. Mindy is truly a gifted, prolific writer.

A fun fast read

Funny and forthright. Can totally imagine getting man in perks together and gossiping. Perfect for when you miss gossiping with your gals.
Satisfying end to this short series of essays. :)

2 1/2 stars

I may be in a reading slump. This did nothing to pull me out of it.

Great writing

I enjoyed reading anything Mindy has to offer. She has a very unique way in captivating the reader into her world. Looking forward to reading more from her.

I'm So Glad We Had This Time Together

Who doesn't love reading about a successful Desi woman who's funny, creative & vulnerable? And willing to share it with The World?!
A great funny book to read if you want to learn the difference between being a giver and being generous
This essay can pick you up from a very bad mood. I can clearly say I love Mindy Kaling’s writing. She is peppy, quirky, and honest! Loved it!!

So in love with Mindy Kaling

Will leave a full review after I've read the rest...

Can't get enough

Love these short stories. It feels like a cup of coffee with a friend. Mindy has a gift for engaging her audience.

Tea spilling

Loved listening to this not only because mindy has a great voice for audio books but also because there’s some juicy tidbits in their & I laughed a lot
An amusing story, but a little braggy.
To be honest, I liked the bonus more than the actual story - HOWEVER, the original story was still amazing. I loved the humor, especially tied in with the lesson. 5/5 stars - worth the read

Enjoyable

This is a light easy read. I find I enjoy Mindy’s humor and directness. I would recommend it for something light up read.
phew! The redemption of this story really saved it - it was really going south to me before that.
Worth a read
I loved the glimpse into a day in the life of Mindy.
Probably my least favorite of the essays, but still enjoyable. Nice to know that social awkwardness doesn't dissipate with fame.
Mindy is funny as usual and very relatable, overall a very relaxing light read.
This one is my favorite of her small essays. Love the lesson learned.

Profound

This essay is why I like Mindy’s writing. She is of course witty and funny, everyone knows that but her writing also comes across as honest and profound.
Cute. Fun. A breezy 30-minute read.

Love the authenticity

If only everyone could be little like Mindy and admit their shortcomings, then we would all be more understanding of one another.
Quick and fun read. Enjoying the accompanying photos.
Quadruple threat.
Mindy has such an easy way of storytelling... it’s what has always endeared me to her.

the one where mindy essentially makes a vlog in essay form and we love to see it

4/5
Well Read, was able to follow and made one think about how one tries to impress others without realizing we need to live self first.
I'm kind of bummed this is the last one. I want more!!! Such a great storyteller!

Love her

As funny in print as she is in her shows. Can make me laugh harder than anyone. She is the real deal

It’s only a quick read but funny and insightful. I love her work and it sounds like she does too!
She does a great job of talking about a serious issue in a way that is humorous, self deprecating, and teaches a great lesson.
This was a fun and quick read to start my day.

Adorable, just like she is. I have a feeling even more people are going to stop and tell her they want to be her best friend.

Mindy Kaling's stories are always such a treat to read. She has to be one of the most down to earth, honest to a fault, and hardest working folks in LaLa Land. These short stories from Amazon are like a fun size candy bar. Yeah, sure, you want more, but even just that one bite is so good!

Amazing read

I lobe the inside look at a life such as Mindy's. She is inspiring, yet relatable at the same time.
Liked the run through of generosity vs giving. The epilogue which is a day in the life is great and it includes photos.

Hilarious

Baby Nurse saves the Day
Review of the Amazon Original kindle eBook (2020)

Funny short essay about writer/actress Mindy Kaling's hiring a baby nurse when after giving birth to her daughter Kit.

Help Is on the Way is one of the six-part Nothing Like I Imagined collection of autobiographical short comedy essays by Mindy Kaling available through Amazon Originals.

Nothing Like I Imagined


Since this is a collection of quick personal essays I’ve decided to review them all in one swoop anthology style.


Please Like Me (But Keep Away) - 4 Stars - This essay reviews the time when Mindy moved to LA to write for the office and had to find/make friends as an adult. A most daunting task indeed. She speaks of wanting a close group of girlfriends and even her experience in trying to join one and of how she somehow ended up with a male BFF. Making

Short, cute and Touching

Short, cute, and touching. I think everyone can relate to wanting to have there mother by their side, especially a new mother. I loved she talked about her fears of not having her mom there with her. This will make you yearn for the love of your mother or a mother like. God knows what you need when you need and he will give it to you.
Heartwarming.

I understand the point of the story is how much she appreciates the role her baby nurse played in her life and acted as a mother figure to her, I hope others in a tax bracket high enough to afford hiring people to help with things most people have to do themselves out of necessity appreciate this one. There are some classic funny lines, hut ultimately too privileged for my taste.
Babies don’t have kneecaps ?! How am I suppose to deal with that information?

This essay explored Mindy's expectations versus reality when it came to adjusting to motherhood/ child rearing; expectations which were largely influenced by her late mother who didn't have a baby nurse and didn't rely on a nanny or babysitter, instead opting to depend on extended family to help raise Mindy. As a result, Mindy believed that when she became a mom, she'd be independent and do it all like her mother, but a friend advised her that the time after having a baby would be both physicall

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

The story of Rose is another one in which I want to do a bit of eye rolling, like Mindy did you really not realize that having a South-Asian-descent lady around during the first few months

Mindy captures the behind the scenes of Indian - American families almost exactly as how it is, her hilarious pregnancy experiencee and the charming bond between her and the baby nurse. As always, it's honest, hilarious, endearing and a crisp short read! I think I'm definitely going to finish reading this series quick and pick up any book that Mindy writes in the future.

My LOL line from the book - "Putting her (Mindy's baby) tiny body in the car seat took fifteen minutes. There was an incompreh

Extremely enjoyable!

Another great piece by Kaling. Laughed out loud at this:

And when it came to a baby, I was not prepared. I had read the baby books, of course, but could remember literally nothing but one fact: “babies are born without kneecaps.” What the hell was I supposed to do with that information? Invite some gangster to take retribution against me by kneecapping my baby and then laugh when he realizes it’s physically impossible? That was no good to me; I would have needed to lay the gr

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

Admitting you need help is one of the hardest things to do as an adult. I’m happy Mindy used her celebrity status for good: opening up about her journey into motherhood and showing that it’s okay not to be okay. I don’t yet have children of my own but hope to some day, and I can only imagine the constant fear of whether what you’re doing is right, perfect or “normal.” I’m glad Mindy found her own normal.

My favourite one so far out of the collection. I have three more to go!

This was such a sweet, heartwarming essay on her first pregnancy & the relationship she built with her daughter’s nurse, Rose. We also gain some touching insight on Mindy’s relationship with her mother & her fears about motherhood and the apprehension of asking for help.

I will read anything & everything Mindy has to write! Definite 5 stars for this one. Also - that knee quote made me LOL.

"Don't complain, don't explain"; it's a quote Mindy's mother lived by.

In this part of the series she talks about her decision to hire a baby nurse and how that plays out for her. It's emotional, comedic, humane. What I liked about this part is that she has humanized a 'celebrity mom'.
She compares how motherhood was for her mother vis-a-vis herself.

She is single, has lost her mother and is somewhat terrified about motherhood. She finds her way eventually. Kudos to her!

Lovely perspective on asking for and receiving help

I love Mindy's conversational style and clean writing. This is a wonderful, emotional fast read that touches on a very difficult thing for many people...asking for and accepting help. Mindy shares her thoughts and emotions so openly that it reads like an email or text from a friend rather than a story you downloaded and read first thing before getting out of bed on a Saturday.

All of the feels

This essay, like the others released in this collection, has made me laugh and cry. Mindy Kaling has long been my idol, and her honesty and voice are comforting. Although in this particular essay she talks a lot about her doubts and fears, I still find myself asking, "Is there nothing Mindy Kaling can't do?" This is a must-read if you love Mindy Kaling and/or good quality writing.

I’ve said this so far after each one of Mindy’s stories, but this one is my favorite. Mindy’s story about life postpartum without her mom really resonated with me. Like everything she writes, it is hilarious and brilliantly written. She describes things in a way that made me feel like I was listening to my friend tell a story. There were also some really touching parts that will stay with me. Short and sweet— I hope she never stops writing.

Help Is On the Way is a short story in the Nothing Like I Imagined series by Mindy Kaling. You can read these stories in any order.

I don't know what it is like to be a single mother, but I can imagine from what I've seen friends go through that it is no walk in the park. I'm glad Mindy found someone to help her get through those initial scary times and develop the confidence to rock motherhood!

Also, I saw what you did there at the end, Mindy Kaling....Fortunately, it wasn't a spoiler!

This essay from the Amazon short collection of stories by Mindy Kaling also made me a laugh. In this essay, she talks about how her baby nurse, who she didn’t think she would need, turned out to be a blessing in disguise as she helped her tremendously to deal with the challenges during the early days of motherhood.

I didn't want to like an essay about a famous person who had the luxury of hiring someone to take care of their baby. However, I can't help but love the bond between Mindy and the baby nurse. I love the way she steps in and provides such a comfort and help for Mindy at a time when Mindy misses her mom so much.

Pregnancy reality check

Kudos to Kaling for writing this book. Pregnancy and motherhood can be difficult for anyone, regardless of the mother's income and resources available to her. I enjoyed reading her stories of woe and realized that being a single parent is a tough path to follow after achieving Hollywood stardom. Kudos to Kaling 🤠

Another delightful snippet from the world's most delightful celeb. It must be difficult for her because she writes in a way that makes me, and I'm sure all of her other billion fans, feel that we actually so know her.

Whether it's a TV show, movie, book (audio, please!), I will be the first in line to hear what she has to say.

It was good to read about Mindy's own experience through having her baby as a single mom. Happy for her that despite the anxiety and fears she had Rose as her support system. Every woman could use a mother figure when she herself was on the edge of becoming a mom.
It's a hard thing to explain, it just is..

The one in which she discusses new motherhood, and the difficulty of asking for help. Definitely a more emotional one, but Mindy cuts the more touching moments with bits of her relatable humor. Leave it to Kaling to write a short story about being a parent that any young woman (and, frankly, any woman) can see herself in.

Funny and honest

Mindy, as always, is both funny and honest. She has the ability to pull at you heartstrings and make you laugh at the same time. I’m looking forward to enjoying the rest of this series of quick reads.

This one was my absolute favorite. I LOVED these 6 books released today (10/6/2020) by Mindy Kaling. I would recommend reading them and then listening to them. I could listen to her all day telling stories. They were funny, uplifting, touching and get 5 stars ⭐️ from me.

This set of essays really made me chuckle, the view of motherhood pre- and post-event is something exceedingly relatable, even if I couldn't relate to hiring a Rose! I still loved reading about the relationship with Rose and thoroughly enjoyed this entry in the series.

This essay is about how Mindy hires a baby nurse to assist her after the birth (and subsequent months after the birth) of her daughter. It’s not relatable to me, but I see how it could be for other single moms. 4 stars for keeping it clean.

Five epic stars. More women need to talk about their pregnancies and what comes after -- and Mindy Kaling is talking about how it feels to come home a single mother, the worries you have, and how you find a support team (even if that's a nanny) to help you.

Not a parent, but I am a daughter. So from what I read, Mindy and my Filipino-American family have similar values. Loved hearing about the ups and downs of motherhood as well as the sense of found family with Rose. Honest and hilarious.

We All Need A Rose In Our Lives

Funny & light-hearted, even though the small-talk at parties "shivered me timbers" making me nauseous. Introverts arise & make an alternate plan! But read this since it won't hurt.

We all need help sometimes

Candid and moving story from Mindy Making about her life during her pregnancy, not having her Mom there to help her with advice and help after her pregnancy.

This was a really cute essay on Mindy's path to motherhood and all her insecurities around being a mother. Admitting you need help is hard for anyone to do, and it's honestly comforting for Mindy to be so open and candid about all of her struggles (while also making me laugh).

This is one of three or four free Audible offers of Mindy Kaling's writing and the first I listened to. In this one, Kaling talks about hiring a baby nurse, how strangers can grow to become family and, ultimately, accepting that it's okay to ask for help.

This essay is about Mindy having a baby and hiring a baby nurse to help out.  Sometimes it is hard to ask for help as adults; but they say it takes a village to raise a baby. Loved reading about Mindy’s relationship with Rose. A heartwarming and honest read!

A Love Letter To Moms

This installation of Mindy's series talks about her introduction to motherhood. While her own mother had already passed, she writes about the motherly love that carried her forward.

Pregnancy Chronicles of a single Indian woman

Quick read. Cute chronicle story of her decision and experience to become a single working Indian mother and great advice from a friend.

I love Rose!

This essay was just so sweet. I love Rose! I love that she was exactly who Mindy needed, like it was fate that she was the one who helped her. I hope now that Mindy had another baby, that Rose is back to save the day.

Mom

Mindy can easily make me laugh. This time she moved me to tears. I was blessed to have my mother with me after both my babies were born. Rose is the next best thing to her own mom. It made me feel so happy for Mindy. I miss my own Mom.

Another great short story from Mindy. This was a wonderful story, about navigating pregancy, and motherhood without her mother, and her learning she needs to ask for him.

Mindy is so much more self aware, and emotionally Intune then she gives herself credit.

Mindy is the best!

Mindy is one of my favorite writers and actors out there. Hearing her real life stories and the things she is going through just make her all better. Thanks for sharing your world with us!!
rose sounds wonderful and i love her
A surprisingly emotional story about accepting help, being able to adapt and change your mind, and becoming a new mother without your own mother by your side.

So Good

Beyoncé Pad Thai good. This was my favorite one. Well done, Mindy! You outdo yourself time and time again - super funny and so so true.

Charming

Authentic family stories that are told with humorous zest. I can not wait to hear the others in this series.

Good story

the short story was well done..the heartfelt worries of a new mother..helped by the experience of a wise older woman..well done

Trevor Noah is a South African comedian who currently hosts The Daily Show on Comedy Central. Born a Crime is about growing up in South Africa: living under apartheid when his existence was evidence of a crime, life after apartheid, the deep bond between a mother and son, the unique challenges of growing up mixed race, and living with an abusive stepfather. OMG! This has got to be the BEST audiobook I've listened to all year. Trevor Noah reads his life story with passion, gusto, and unflinching accuracy. Touching, humorous, and sad, Trevor Noah finds exactly the right words to talk about poverty, the hatred of apartheid, but most of all the love he has for his mother and the love she has for him. A three-part collection of eighteen personal essays, Born a Crime recollects stories about Trevor Noah's coming-of-age in South Africa under apartheid, as the biracial son of a single Xhosa woman. The memoir-in-essays centers on Noah's relationship with his mother, but it spans a vast range of topics, from the author's experience of his country's racist education system to his brief stint as a DJ while a young adult. Somewhat surprisingly, Noah mostly avoids discussing his career as a comedian.

Trevor Noah is a damn good writer. Who would have thought? I like his comedy, but we all know that doesn't always translate into good book writing. I also often end up rolling my eyes at memoire writers who are barely out of their teens, but Noah does a smart thing here, writing about something bigger than his personal life. It's a narrative about South African apartheid first, peppered through with stories from Noah's childhood and youth. This book is a winner all around - it's educational in a

A lighthearted and sincere memoir by Trevor Noah, a South African comedian and current host of The Daily Show. In Born a Crime, Noah details his experience growing up in apartheid South Africa, where his parents - a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father - committed an illegal act just by conceiving him. Throughout this memoir, Noah shares many funny coming-of-age stories, ranging from his awkward first romantic encounters with girls as well as how he once set a neighbor's house on fire. Wh

'Born a Crime' is a fast-paced narrative of Trevor Noah's life. I knew nothing about Trevor's background except that he is an American celebrity. I liked his talk shows, like million others.

His story comes as a huge shock. Looking at him today, I find it hard to believe that he went through so much, so early in life. Read by the author (a stand-up comedian and presenter of The Daily show) who does a brilliant job, I highly recommend the audio if you have not already read this fascinating, entertaining and informative book.

Can't wait for the second installment being releases next year.

4 high stars. I had no idea who comedian Trevor Noah was, but there were enough rave reviews about his book Born a Crime to make me curious. I'm so glad I read it. Noah was born in South Africa just before the end of Apartheid. His mother is black and his father was white, and given the times in which he was born, he was literally "born a crime" as a mixed race kid. His book focuses on his early years growing up in South Africa. I'm not sure I can do justice to what makes this book so excellent.

I mean, 34-frickin'-years-old is a little young to be writing a memoir, don't you think? Geez - most people haven't even begun to live yet at that age!

Well . . .

Despite what my husband says, I'm the first to admit when I am WRONG.

Noah's tale of growing up in South Africa is hilarious, heartbreaking, and horrifying. (And, so I'm not accused of ample alliteration, it was also pretty damned gripping, and suspenseful.)

a·part·heid (noun)
1 a rigid former policy of segregating and economically and politically oppressing the nonwhite population.
2 any system or practice that separates people according to color, ethnicity, caste, etc.

What makes this memoir so special and moving is the tone in which Noah conveys the story of his childhood growing up "coloured" in South Africa: As the son of a Xhosa woman and a white immigrant from Switzerland, he was the product of an (under Apartheid law) illegal relationship - he was literally "born a crime". Trevor Noah was the only white kid in the black neighborhood, the only black kid in the white neighborhood, and the only mixed-race kid in the colored neighborhood. He didn't always know where he fit in, but he always knew who he was.

Noah was born in South Africa while it was still under the system of apartheid. He is the product of a black woman from the Xhosa tribe and a white Swiss father, who broke the racial purity laws that could have landed them in jail for several years if their "crime"

"Born a Crime" is an enormously engaging memoir about the early years of Trevor Noah's life. Noah is the successful host of The Daily Show, the satirical American news show on Comedy Central. He was born in 1984 during apartheid in South Africa to a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father. His parents could have been jailed for five years for having a mixed race child, and Noah could have been sent to a state orphanage. He spent much of his childhood indoors at his grandmother's home with hi

This is an entertaining way to explore some very heavy topics: Apartheid, global poverty, criminality, the absurdity of racism, etc. Trevor Noah narrates his own book and does a great job with all the voices, languages and accents, adding a layer of authenticity and immediacy to the narrative. Noah could have become an angry young man, but instead he chose to find humor in the difficulties. That instinct came directly from his mother, who mixed tough di

Trevor Noah is a successful comedian and the host of The Daily Show. Of South African descent, his childhood and upbringing were anything but easy. Born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother, during Apartheid, his birth was a crime. He spent the first years of his life in hiding, for his discovery could land his parents in jail and him in foster care. This is the story of his struggles and how he prevailed over them.

Part coming-of-age story, part memoir and part history lesson, this w

This book is a must-read/listen for every South African -- and also anyone interested in learning about African History!

Listening to this story was like having Trevor Noah in my living room, sharing some tea and rusks. A brilliant tale of growing up during the Apartheid era - not something I was affected by - and the impact it had on his family and lifestyle. These are the anecdotes which should be shared with our youth so that they have perspective on how fortunate their lives are today.

Being born in apartheid South Africa as a mixed-race kid, from a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father, Trevor Noah was literally "born a crime".

Through his captivating writing, Trevor Noah brings light upon insane social and political injustice, apartheid, religion, being a chameleon, gender role, chain of poverty, and more. Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah, Trevor's mother, was a strong, independent woman who refused to abide by so

I saw this book on the shelf,I read the beginning pages and couldn't put it down! The vivid scenes how Trevor dealth with racism is compelling. It is astounding how this book talks so much about African Americans living in the shadow of the dominant white group. I sympathize with him being biracial, based on his upbringing he didn't have the privileges as his peers did. The color of his skin dictated a lot of prejudice,ignorance and bitterness.

Growing up in a religious household he didn't know m

I have a confession to make- I have never seen The Daily Show and I have never seen Trevor Noah. My interest in this book stems from my interest in South Africa and all the tumult that is a constant there.
This book are snippets of Trevor's childhood and upbringing, but through them we get a history of South Africa from just pre the end of apartheid till Trevor was 25 yrs old. Thanks to his being a child of a Black mother and a white father- Trevor was born a crime (pre end of apartheid). He had

I'm a loyal viewer of The Daily Show with Trevor Noah. So I've been looking forward to reading his book. It's well written, interesting and at times very moving. He's had quite an incredible life. I knew very little about what it's like to live in South Africa.

My favorite quote from the book is this -

"Regret is the thing we should fear most. Failure is an answer. Rejection is an answer. Regret is an eternal question you will never have the answer to. "What if... "If only..." I wonder what would

This was a really interesting book - Trevor Noah is a great storyteller.

Like most people, I learned a bit about apartheid at school but - especially as a kid - you can’t really understand it if you haven’t lived through something similar. Noah, however, makes his experiences understandable, both during and post-apartheid. His life and childhood were so infinitely different to my experiences, and I found learning about life in South Africa fascinating.

Candid, witty, brutally honest, dark and yet humorous, so basically typical Trevor Noah with a knack for finding humour in bleakest of topics ranging from teenage heartbreak to racial and domestic violence. He can make light of any issue when he means to convey a message without depressing the audience and he can be very sombre and serious at times as well.
The book makes a great study of apartheid and what it meant for those who suffered it. It makes an even greater read when u hear it in Trevo

We've been watching the Mindy Project (a rewatch for me, first time for my husband) so when I saw this series of six essays by Mindy Kaling it was an obvious download. The Kindle version is free to Amazon Prime members and after you download them you can access the audio free as well. Obviously I listened to this in audio read by the author - this is a buddy adventure story about Mindy and BJ Novak, one night in Los Angeles....

The Goodreads community was not quite as here for this one, but I was. Honestly, any BJ/Mindy story is a hit, I'd have fun reading their dry cleaning receipts. But this is sufficiently more fun than that.

A really mellow drifter attempts to steal B.J's laptop. The drifter posing as an Office fan. B.J interrogating while Mindy blocks his exit via pining him in the driver's seat by standing in front of the door and her 8th month pregnant belly. A story!

Confirmation that B.J. is the exactly the typ

Nothing Like I Imagined


Since this is a collection of quick personal essays I’ve decided to review them all in one swoop anthology style.


Please Like Me (But Keep Away) - 4 Stars - This essay reviews the time when Mindy moved to LA to write for the office and had to find/make friends as an adult. A most daunting task indeed. She speaks of wanting a close group of girlfriends and even her experience in trying to join one and of how she somehow ended up with a male BFF. Making
Funny essay about a night out with BJ Novak and a homeless person. So funny! I just love the way she tells a story!

Mindy's obviously a great storyteller and as I was reading, I could just picture everything that played out, almost as if I were watching a show; I could totally see how each essay could be turned into one-off episodes on YouTube. Anyways, the drifter incident was bizarre and the Mindy-B.J. duo were hilarious, but the best part was how Mindy summed up her reaction to the drifter (and all of his weirdness) with a "y tho?".

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.
This one is kinda eerie and hilarious.

Anti-climactic
Review of the Amazon Original kindle eBook (2020)

A story of a dinner outing with author Kaling and her bff B.J. a fellow writer. Not really on a level with the Once Upon a Time in Hollywood teaser hint of the title, but a fun story nevertheless.

Once Upon a Time in Silver Lake is one of the six-part Nothing Like I Imagined collection of autobiographical short comedy essays by Mindy Kaling available through Amazon Originals.
Those short stories are fantastic! They are perfect to read while talking a break from intense studying. My brain loves this.

Rating: 2.5 stars

I don't understand why they don't just put all these essays into one collection. I wouldn't call this a book in a series because it's just like one extended monologue. It reads like the transcription of a stand-up bit. I read this while I was lying in bed trying to"greet the day," and finished it in 10 minutes. I don't know a ton about Mindy Kaling fan or anything, but her voice is distinct and clearly comes across the page. (I didn't listen to the audio.) This is a humorous and

This short essay is just a strange story that happened to Mindy and her best friend BJ one night while going out to dinner. It’s interesting but I’m left a little confused as to why this was published as a stand-alone. Her other essays have a “lesson learned” or some point to them. This story, while interesting (and I suppose she did learn something from it) didn’t resonate with me like her other essays did. It’s just a funny-strange story that someone would tell at a party. Not one that warrant

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

This...seemed out of place. Less an essay, more of an interesting podcast story in and of itself (ooh...how meta). The note about how Mindy never wants to listen to podcasts but wants to h

Drifter Chronicles!

My 5th short story read from Mindy on her super wierd yet super funny encounter with a homeless/drifter man and her friend,  B. J.. I can literally visualize how Mindy and B. J. from 'The Office' would have enacted such a scene.

The nice part about Mindy's writing is she shares simple stories about her life, ties it back to some lesson she learned or an observation about the larger truth of the world. This coupled with her writing makes it relatable and hence it works!

This part of the series had a lot of references I didn't get. The story also seemed pointless to me; except for her own condition at the time and her surprising, real bravado! That's a treat to look out for.

The other parts in this series are better than this one and have more substance.
It is mysterious though and like a scene from a movie, the events play out perfectly; much like fiction!

This short story was about a weird, funny story that happened to Mindy and B.J. Novak. I really enjoyed it and it was a fun story to hear, but it felt a little out of place. It's kind of a different wavelength from the other stories she has shared so far, and I feel like it shouldn't have been a standalone. But either way I enjoyed it.

Nice quick lunchtime read. I wasn't sure what to expect as I've only seen one or two movies that she's been in and sad to say I've never watched any of her tv shows, but I am familiar enough with her style of humor to be intrigued enough to read this short story. Nothing extremely spectacular, but a nice quick break from reality when/if you need it.

I LOVED these 6 books released today (10/6/2020) by Mindy Kaling. I would recommend reading them and then listening to them. I could listen to her all day telling stories. They were funny, uplifting, touching and get 5 stars ⭐️ from me.

Short, sweet, and to the point. The tidbit about Manson and one of the Beach Boys was trippy. Not my favorite in the series to be honest. I sort of want to see this written as a fictional story though.

What do you do when a dirty drifter who looks like Sean William Scott breaks into your car? Mindy Kaling will tell you what she and her friend BJ did. Compared to other short stories in her collection, not my favorite, but hey -- still good.

Goofy, charming bite-sized tale

This is a funny anecdote that is well crafted into a hilarious story. An excellent way to spend a break at work or just an escape from the trashfire raging around us.

Fun quick read!

This was a quick fun read that makes Mindy feel relatable. Great transition read between books if you are looking for something fun to clear your mind for the next story.

It's a short essay about Mindy's encounter with a homeless man at Silver Lake, LA with her friend B.J. Novak.

It's a funny essay. But, it was bland. I'm not dismissing her experience. I can imagine how she would have felt during the ordeal. It just didn't work for me.

I’m going to be honest, I usually love Mindy Kaling but I’m not sure what I just read and what the point was?

✔️ 2020 Popsugar Reading Challenge - A book with "gold," "silver," or "bronze" in the title

I wanted to rate this story lower because it was so short & had no moral, but it was honestly as entertaining and hilarious as a sitcom, so my gut says 4-stars. I had a smile on my face the whole read & literally LOLed several times. Why can't this series just be an extremely long book?!

Loved it

I loved the series hands down couldn't stop reading and going through one essay after the other
Mindy can read a take out menu and I'd find it entertaining such fun read /listen

Amazing!

Amazing story! I don't know if I would have been brave or crazy enough to confront a drifter the way Kaling did. Kudos to her thinking quick on her feet and God bless her for her zany.sense of humor.

Short and sweet

I love Mindy and her outgoing personality. This short story shows just how genuine she is about her thoughts and daily events that she is freely able to share with her readers and draw you in to want to know more about her crazy ventures.

Loved!!

Mindy is one of my favorite writers and actors out there. Hearing her real life stories and the things she is going through just make her all better. Thanks for sharing your world with us!!

The one where she puts her pregnant self in harm's way to save B.J. Novak's laptop. If this were part of a longer short story collection, Once Upon a Time in Silver Lake would be closer to filler than substance. Still, I always love to hear stories about her and Novak.
This one didn’t hit the spot as much for me, but it’s… a story.

Hilarious

Mindy does it again! She makes storytelling effortless and gives me a false hope that I could do this someday.

Mindy discusses a rather bizarre incident that occurred while she and her best friend, B.J. Novak were out in Silver Lake one night during her pregnancy.

Not as funny as the first three essays.
Ha! That was a weird and comical story. I do so like how "girl next door" Kaling seems, despite her Hollywood claims to fame.
I love that she can make Charles Manson amusing.

Great story

This sounded just like I was listening to a close friend tell me a hilarious story at a small party. Well written and full of humor.

Intriguing

This was a good story to read. Because of the incident and the accidental connection to a story. Mindy sure knows how to tell a story.

Sushi Love & Odd Things

It's Mindy again! Pull up the chair, Ottoman or floor & join her for a few more. Wine, anyone? More sushi!
Still good, but loved the other books more. These books really need to be longer-we want more Mindy!!

Reflections and lessons learned:
Short story musings - Charles Manson and a different take on pregnancy!
Not much to say, again, but this story was great and left me absolutely dumbfounded. 4/5 Stars - A short but interesting read
Such a random story! But hugely enjoyable nonetheless, I really hope Mindy Kaling publishes more essays soon, I will be there with bells on.
What would you do if you found a homeless man in your car snooping through your laptop?

Creepy things happen everywhere

Mindy recounts the normal dinner with a friend evening that ends up taking a creepy, possibly dangerous turn. Glad no one got hurt.
A story about a wacky adventure between a very-pregnant Mindy and B.J. Novak in the wilds of L.A. Moral of the story: ALWAYS lock your car, kids. Always.
Not as fun as the other ones but still love the glimpse into her world and her mind.
Funny, very descriptive, very Mindy. Also quick. Thank you Amazon.

Part of a Convo

I liked the presentation.
I felt like she was in a conversation with me just recalling a night out story.
Weird and hilarious anecdote that happened to Mindy and her friend. Felt a bit out of place in the series.
Funny and weird story.
This was probably the weakest of the series, but still enjoyable.
She could write a grocery list and I would love it. I'm a fan of this funny lady.
This one was funny but extra short.
A Mindy and BJ adventure in Silver Lake

the one where there is seemingly no point

2/5
Always an entertaining read.

Makes You Think - Good

Well told memory of am actual event many of us may or could experience today. Quick read and kept my thoughts racing to what's next?! Well told.
This is a genuinely strange little story, which I suppose is why she wrote down.

Once Upon a Time..

LA heat + Thai food + Charles Manson + drifter + Seann William Scott= funny, entertaining, quick read. Good story!
This was one of my faves in this series.

Fine enough

I don’t dislike these essays but I don’t love them. They are entertaining anecdotes that seem like they’re being told to me by a friend.
Weaker story of a hot fall night out with a connection to Manson.
i loved it but just not as much as her others

THIS ONE WAS SO GOOD
Totally relate, this is SO weird, LOVE LOVE LOVE
Mindy is a national treasure and I love her voice. Great audio.
Funny as always Mindy tells a story she experienced with so much humour that when you think back its like woah that was kind of serious.
I love Mindy Kaling, her audiobooks are always some of my favorites. They make me feel like I actually know her, and truthfully, I wish we were friends in real life.

Why does Mindy make even annoying , werid or scary situations sound fun, because she is there.

Another fun short story by everyone's bestie.

3.5

The weakest story in the collection, but I’m always up for hearing about her adventures with BJ, so I still liked it. Super weird, though!

Mindy Kaling's latest series of essays are just as insightful and witty as her memoirs. Each essay has a different theme, though I'm reviewing the set as opposed to individual essays.

Kaling brings her trademark wit and humor to everyday life and how her life has changed since becoming a parent. She offers funny quips and touching insights in an engaging and enjoyable fashion.
I love Mindy Kaling so I'm really excited to listen to this series!

Before starting this book, write down some good habits you want to build and some bad habits you want to break. This book is filled with practical steps and examples. Yes, there are plenty of habit-building books out there (just as there are plenty of diet books but yet there are still more new books published every year). Plenty of people are seeking the right book that resonates with them. The key points in this book are:
* Compound Effect - Very small changes over time will have a big impact.
*

TLDR;
- "You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems."
- The best way of building a habit is making it part of your identity.
- Make it easy to start: Habits are the entry point - not the goal. "Read 30 books" ⇒ "Read before bed every night" ⇒ "Read one page". Reduce a habit into a 2-minute first step.
- Stick to the plan: "Professionals stick to the schedule, amateurs let life get in the way." Don't be a "fair weather runner" if you want to run a lot.
- Make it

The first great book about habits was the Power of Habit. That book was quite theoretical and difficult to apply. This book, Atomic Habits, has a completely different approach. James Clear focused on writing a book that goes deep into every single step of habit creation from a practical point of view. At the end of the day, who we are and what we will achieve depends so much on these small habits that we do every day. James Clear argues, that focusing only on improving those habits will lead to

To exaggerate, we can develop great working, social. and creative habits or destroy ourselves with neuroticism going haywire, find great ways to optimate oneself or madness, just read anecdotal filled pop psychology/science/philoso

I received this book as a Goodreads giveaway yesterday and immediately settled down to read it. I am always very skeptical of self help books because they often do no get to the root of issues. This one did. James Clear's main arguments are that habits are the compound interest of self improvement and that your identify emerges out of your habits. So, you must expereince a shift in identity for your habits to hold. This made a lot of sense to me, but I do think that Clear should have addresses d

This book has helped me build a more productive morning routine and I love it! ☀️ Being a morning person has always been a struggle for me, but this book gives you very clear and very easy steps to create the life you’ve always imagined.

If you’re proud of how your hair looks, you’ll develop all sorts of habits to care for and maintain it. If you’re proud of the size of your biceps, you’ll make sure you never skip an upper-body workout. If you’re proud of the scarves you knit, you’ll be more likely to spend hours knitting each week. In an episode of the North Star Podcast with David Perrell, the software entrepreneur Daniel Gross said something that I thought was wise:

The definition of a habit, for me, is something that doesn’t require willpower. How can I build a large collection of habits that are healthy—that are correct—and save them to RAM in my head so that I don’t have to think about them? I would like to have that done by the end of my 20s. I’d like to be in a good place in terms of body composition, in terms of wha

Reading this book feels like reading a homework assignment. James Clear wanted to read a lot of books and make a summary of the concepts he would implement for self-improvement. He also made a point in improve himself in the most hacky way possible. Instead of keeping the summary as personal notes, he published it. The fact that the author boasts about being a writer only makes it worse. You can actually smell the cheap tools he uses to put words into text and build chapters out of thin air. I w

This is a dual review of two books about habit. Habits are important things in one’s life and there are numerous books on the subject. The classic book, a must read, is The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People by Stephen R. Covey. Another two popular books about habits are The Power of Habit by Charles Duhigg and Atomic Habits by James Clear, that came out very recently. Having read all three of them I combined my notes for the last two in this post. No matter what stage in life you are, it is al

Atomic Habits: An Easy & Proven Way to Build Good Habits & Break Bad Ones is a practical framework for how to build and keep new habits. To create a good habit, author James Clear suggests:

- Make it Obvious
- Make it Attractive
- Make it Easy
- Make it Satisfying

While at first glance these may seem overly simplistic, Atomic Habits delves into each of these concepts and also describes how these same ideas can be inverted to break bad habits. The content is easily digestible.

Different parts are

This is basically reinforcement for Duhigg's books on habits. There is some good advice--get rid of obstacles, use cues of things you like to do with things you need to do (i.e., everytime you check facebook, do pushups or whatever). It's good advice, but nothing new or unique.

This book is what I expected "The power of habit" to be. Where TPOH mostly is a collection of stories/anecdotes, Atomic Habits actually goes over practical ways of implementing your own system. It's great! Here's to stop reading and to start doing... :)

I was enlightened by "Willpower" and got some great takeaways from "The Power of Habit", but this is next-level in terms of practical steps and also generating pivotal mental shifts both for the immediate and long terms. Important note: it gets better with each successive chapter - something critical to know since the opening is understandably crucial to the author, but not so much to many readers. Read it.
Randomly started listening to this one because I'm trying to get out of my reading slump and I reaaaally enjoyed it! Some tips were super helpful!

It's complicated ... my relationship with self-help books that is. On one hand, I'm one of those people who always wants to learn and improve, while also getting in my own way due to character/personality flaws, which I'm well acquainted with, which is why, occasionally, I read yet another self-help book, hoping to get inspired or to learn something that will result in me taking action.

I heard about this book from different sources which propelled me to put it on hold.

My usual scepticism was p

This life-changing non-fiction title is one often spoken of, highly praised, and much recommended. I would say it is well-deserving of all this celebratory hype it has garnered over the years for how concise and yet detailed its content are, how many different suggested areas of daily improvement are included, and how easily implemented Clear makes them appear.

I used to follow James email letters, so I knew already something about his philosophy. The first part of the book, where he talks about principles of habits ( in theory ), is the best, and I loved it. However, subsequent parts are about application of those principles, which are quite useful, but not mind blowing.

Overall not bad.
4.5 stars. Who bet the author that he couldn’t slip multiple porn references in? Who was it?

Enjoyed this one much more than The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business, as it's more to the point.

Some great takeaways and excellent reminders. Each chapter succinctly summarized at the end, very quotable. Highly recommend.

1-Sentence-Summary: Atomic Habits is the definitive guide to break bad behaviors and adopt good ones in four steps, showing you how small, incremental, everyday routines compound and add up to massive, positive change over time (via Four Minute Books'

Well, there’s almost no single shred of original content here. It could be a fine book if it’s the first self-improvement book you have started to read.

The science is also flawed. He presents the following elements for habit:
1. Cue
2. Craving
3. Action
4. Reward
Not to mention that its a skewed copy of principles presented in Power of Habits (to authors credit, he mentions it), craving starts to appear strongly only when your brain has learned to associate the cue, action, reward which happens wit

I really enjoyed how easily digested this book was. We all have certain habits we want to learn or unlearn and we usually start strong but lack the motivation to stick to it. This book really expanded my mind about what it actually takes to make habits stick and how motivation has VERY little to do with it.
I added a few of key quotes from the book that touch on some of the steps: why the smallest habits matter, awareness, repetition over perfection, focus on environment, how to keep going when

James Clear has a big following because of his newsletter –which I am subscribed to–, and that can probably explain the many good reviews. But this document, which is already only a 45-page free-to-download "ebook", is too long and could be synthesized in a 3 page tryptic. Although the intention is good and the concept an important one, and the proposals described to get rid of bad habits and attain desired ones are with no doubt good ones, it's a full blown action of "copy-writing": self-help m
This is THE book for habit building and tracking. James Clear provides clear insights on various aspects regarding habits and the four laws are simple and easy to remember. Definitely recommend!

I love how actionable the advice in this book is. There's no fluff -- just straight up information about habits. The psychological, scientific, and anecdotal evidence presented is great. I also love the chapter summaries -- great teaching tool! That being said, the constant plugging of his site and other products bothered me, this may have been more apparent in the audiobook though. All of the referenced links require you to sign up for his email list, which, as a content-creator I understand, b

8/10

Atomic Habits is a useful book. It’s a practical guide to identifying and changing your habits. It’s something you can actually put into practice in your life.
I think that all of the concepts in the book are good and useful to know but some of the action points I think are slightly oversimplified. If you take the action points in some chapters and modify them to your specific situation you can still apply most of them but you do have to do some critical thinking with the material.

“Every action you take is a vote for the type of person you wish to become. No single instance will transform your beliefs, but as the votes build up, so does the evidence of your new identity.”

I've read a number of books on how to form positive habits, including The Power of Habit by Duhigg, and in my opinion, Atomic Habits by Clear ranks as the best. It covers what could be considered as ideas of common sense, but presents these ideas in a well organized and logical way.

Basic concepts inc

It's rare that I buy and read self care books, but I'm happy I did it this time. Atomic Habits focus is on the small improvement. This is very well written, simple to follow and practical for developing many different habits. A brilliant book, with excellent case studies and grounding in the psychology of human behaviour.
This is exactly what I needed to read. A perfect book on establishing habits and teaching your goals one tiny change after another through a personalized system.

A clear, practical guide to developing good habits. The information in this book is fairly solid and worth reading for most people. My only concern is whether the information is presented in a way that is effective: that is, after reading this book, what percentage of people will actually change their behavior? I suppose this is the ultimate question of all self-improvement books, but I found that this one in particular, while effective at organizing and presenting information, didn't do it in s

James Clear’s Atomic Habit can be summed up as ‘small changes lead to bigger results’. In order to create a habit – do practice, so that the difficult task becomes automatic. There are a few but important insights from this book.

To create a good habit:
1. Make it obvious
2. Make it attractive
3. Make it easy
4. Make it satisfying

To stop a bad habit:
1. Make it invisible
2. Make it unattractive
3. Make it difficult
4. Make it unsatisfying
