A super easy and short read with straight forward messaging - small (hence atomic) changes can compound and lead to great results.
The book goes on to provide a practical guide to building habits by describing the basic principles of habit change and how one can build the right system to sustain them.
Kudos to making this seem really easy and attainable, thus giving the reader a boost of motivation and confidence to get started.

Nothing particularly new here, but a pretty good overview of consistent habit formation techniques (make it obvious, attractive, easy, and satisfying) and ways of framing the development of new habits (thinking about habits not as working towards a goal, but towards building your identity as a certain type of person). Good nuggets to take with you if you are building your own new habits, and an easy book to work through.

At the end of this book, through Clear's easy-to-follow and practical guidance, I have successfully implemented (or stopped) all of them.

This book took what felt like a few abstract ideas of how I would one day, eventually, improve my quality of life through being more disciplined and focu

Let me start by confessing how much I dread self-help books. I always thought of it as EDM among books. But, hell. EDM has surprised me from time to time as well. I was really expecting to find the book distasteful. But, I thoroughly enjoyed it. James Clear hooks you in from the introduction pages. He attributes everything good about the book, to the geniuses who came before him, while admitting that the book might be full of fallacies considering he has written it.

The anecdotes were simple but

My rating : 4.5/5
Atomic habits is for all those people who want to know the following:
▪︎what are habits exactly?
▪︎how habits are formed?
▪︎how when repeated,they can make or mar your life (depending on what habits you choose to inculcate )
▪︎why is it difficult to maintain good habits whereas we can easily slip into bad ones
▪︎it's compounding effect
All in all this book will help you to form good habits and break bad ones by giving you tips,tricks,rules or laws whatever you may call it as.
I highly

"Every action you take is a vote for the type of person you wish to become. No single instance will transform your beliefs, but as the votes build up, so does the evidence of your new identity."

A must read book! My favorite self-development book. It was a motivational and inspirational experience.

"Boiling water will soften a potato but harden an egg. You can't control whether you're a potato or an egg, but you can decide to play a game where it's better to be hard or soft. If you find a more favorable environment, you can transform the situation from one where the odds are against you to one where they are in your favor."

James Clear's simple language, concepts and short exercises in book keeps a reader connected and motivates in frameworking new habits.

Perfect read for self improvement
I really appreciated this book. It was super interesting to look at habits the way James describes them. Definitely going to try and apply some of these methods to my life.

Likely the best summary of techniques to maintain good habits and get rid of bad ones. Each chapter starts with a real life story that shows how those has been applied in real life rather than just "theory". Also, the book explains how habits are connected to our identity and therefore, why they are so relevant to us. Highly suggested!
It's not a bad book but there is nothing groundbreaking here. The author could have said what he wanted to say in far fewer pages than this book.
If you’re interested in how to build habits and how to keep them this is great! Easy to follow and super interesting & motivating.

3'5/5

Simple in its narration, straight to the point, interesting concepts to grasp. Will I get my shit together after this? Pues habrá que verlo.

I don't understand the authors compelling need to include their personal sufferings in the book. There is one other author who did this, The Irrationality Series, Dan Arielly also talks about his burn wounds. It was extremely painful to read and so was this authors suffering, the episode about the baseball bat smashing his skull into pieces, was absolutely painful to read. I was able to visualize it in my mind and the picture wouldn't go away. This is how the book will be remembered by many audi

I’ve been reading James Clear’s work for several years and absolutely love it! This book was no exception. His advice, as always, is clear, practical and actionable. I feel like I need to read again and take notes and make this my habit-building manual.

This book gave me immense validation as I was pretty much already doing almost everything that the book suggests. I just didn't know that it was called Atomic Habits. Felt good to know that my lifestyle choices and my decisions were right. Thrilled in fact, especially considering how many people have loved the book.

Additional tactics is what the book taught me. These few pages towards the end of the book helped me fine tune my habits and explore more in detail.

Detailed review coming soon.

Atomic Habits by James Clear has been one of the beneficial books that I have read this year. And I wanted to share the notes and ideas which helped me with you all.

The crux of the book is that Habits are the compound interest of self improvement. The effects of your habits multiplies as you repeat them just like money. A simple change in your daily habits can guide your life to a very different destination.

According to James Clear, all habits revolves around the below four step model and any be

A marvellous book, and greatly exceeded my expectations. The book starts with an introduction to the basic of habits the compounding effect of small actions, its role in your identity, and the process of building better habits.

One of the main themes of the book is that habits depend on the systems you've set in place, and not on your motivation alone. "If you’re having trouble changing your habits, the problem isn’t you. The problem is your system. Bad habits repeat themselves again and againno

I found James Clear's book, Atomic Habits, in a local bookstore at just the right time--the very beginning of a new year when all those resolutions I always make were being formulated and implemented. Clear gives concrete (even step-by-step) advice on how to begin and maintain new desirable habits as well as how to ditch the habits that aren't working for you. And he's inspiring!

This book does a great job at breaking down why we build habits in the first place and therefore how we can change them. Clear is very clear (pun intended) on the processes that need to be put into place to build good habits and limit bad habits. Many of the examples Clear used i was noticing in my own life and was able to remedy them immediately. For example "You’re more likely to find a behaviour attractive if you get to do one of your favourite things at the same time." I knew that I spent ti

Great insights, examples and nice reminders. Clear provides actionable nuggets to improve your life - if you so choose!
Notable Quotes:
“The quality of our lives often depends on the quality of our habits. With the same habits, you’ll end up with the same results.”
“A slight change in your daily habits can guide your life to a very different destination.”
“At some point it comes down to who can handle the boredom of training every day, doing the same lifts over and over and over.”
“Every action you

I feel confident to recommend this book to anyone who feels like they need some inspiration for productivity, goal setting and routine formation. There are many books about habits but I doubt most of them offer insight like this one, I can not say for sure however, because I haven't read most of them. Here are some of the points that resonated with me, I apologize if it won't be very well articulated, I procrastinated on writing this review, but again, it was low priority and I do this only for

I don't often use stars anymore because I don't feel they accurately represent my thoughts on a book. This is the perfect example of why- don't take a 2 star to mean awful! Here is why ⬇️:

The main ideas and principles of this book are incredibly important and I imagine helpful to many people. He does a great job of highlighting the importance of seeing the beauty and impact of focusing on small improvements that compound over time. I can absolutely see why this is such a leading book in the self

I plan to run a 90km ultra-marathon in June 2020, and this is the book that is going to help me get to that starting line!!! Brilliant...tiny habits eventually compound into great ones. June 2020...here i come!!!
The book has some very useful tips in creating personal change. Also very informative about the psychology behind habits.

This is a memoir in which the author, while in law school and while having very dark thoughts, decides to seek help in the form of a group therapy session. Initially, therapy seems to do a lot of good for Tate. She’s forced to start talking about her issues with eating and sex, and the therapist (Dr. Rosen) helps her give voice to issues long left unspoken.

But as we go along, the therapist’s instructions and his role in the author’s life grows, especially as he suggests that she join additional

“I was afraid of marrying my heart with the scoring that rose naturally between people, the inevitable bumping against other peoples desires, demands, pettiness, preferences, and all the quotidian Negotiations that made up a relationship. Scoring was required for attachment, and my heart leapt the grooves”.

“The deep secret that I carried was that I didn’t belong. Anywhere. I spent half my days obsessing about food and my body and the weird shit I did to control both, and the other half trying

Giveaway Win!

I want to start this review off by saying that I don't think traditional forms of therapy are for everyone. I've tried going to therapy and I've tried taking anxiety medication and neither were for me. That does not mean that those things won't work for someone else. Mental health treatment is not a one size fits all type of thing.

For me these are the things that work for ME (these are not recommendations for anyone else)

1) taking time away (a day or two)from everyone (total solit
I love reading about other people's therapy, so was fascinated by this account of unconventional group therapy and its life-changing consequences.

Just what the doctor ordered to forget about the pandemic and no electricity- what’s better than reading about someone else’s crazy messed up life! Lots of humor and misery kept me engaged until the very last page!
Group is an engaging and entertaining read. The author goes deep as she brings us with her to group therapy sessions and shows how the difficult process of revealing personal secrets allowed her to develop more intimate relationships.

In this memoir, Christie Tate, a lawyer with an eat

I can’t really in good faith recommend this book to folks (unless you’re simply looking for non-fic that can be taken with a hefty grain of salt).

This was salacious and entertaining and... honestly kind of iffy.

Tate is a crassly funny narrator, and this book presents a no-holds-barred account of her experience with group therapy and coming to terms with traumatic memories and eating disorder recovery. I liked the metaphor of the scored heart that she uses throughout the book. Just like how one

This is a complex review for me!

I got to read this book as an ARC and I was super excited about it since I am first-year therapy graduate student. I think that I was coming at this book from a different angle. The book is from the perspective of a client in therapy, specifically group therapy. Christie is a very successful law student and professional who finds herself in need of help.

My main critique of this book (it is a memoir) was that I really struggled with ethical issues throughout the

I love reading advice columns and shows about people in therapy. I find the way people see their own problems fascinating, and I find them even more fascinating when taken through another person who is there to consider and possibly disagree with the way a person sees their problems. I am frustrated that I can't read a million books about people sharing their experiences in therapy. But I get it. Sometimes when I watch/read/hear these stories I think, "Wow, how can anyone be okay sharing this mu

“My turn, your turn. Back and forth. So this was how it happened. This was how you built an intimate relationship. Word by word. Story by story. Revelation by revelation. Just like group.”

An intimate debut memoir centering on group therapy and how opening up to strangers saved a life.

I’ve often wondered how freeing it would be for a stranger or group of strangers to know my secrets. To have a group of people that did not hold back, judge or even tell you what to do. Simply a group of individuals
Thoughts soon.
Review to come but I definitely recommend this one.

This is difficult to rate because I didn't have any problems with the writing or how the author presented herself as a person, but the whole thing made my skin crawl. Everything Dr. Rosen did felt gross and unethical and over the line. There were so many times when Christie was about ready to quit going to group, and I was like "Good for you! Recognize that this isn't ok!" and then she always went back. I am glad that she ultimately got what she wanted and is in a good place. However, I don't th

I didn’t really ‘finish’ this book as such, I gave up sixty pages in. If this is an actual memoir and not simply a piece of fiction, then there is a psychiatrist out there in the world somewhere that seriously shouldn’t be practicing. I am a huge supporter of therapy, but this type of ‘therapy’ is unethical and just plain wrong. What a weird thing to decide to write about and share with others..

Oh wow. Five stars all the way around.

I know that several reviews I’ve read are stuck on the ethics of Dr. Rosen and the way he chooses to practice in his group therapy, but you know what? It didn’t bother me. I see the value in the way he makes everyone uncomfortable and let’s them feel things and get angry and work through it as a team. Having a support system is so important. Having a place to go every week at an exact time to keep the feeling of purpose alive in people who are struggling to

This book was really uncomfortable to read. At times I also found it horrifying and disturbing. I applaud the author's desire to seek help, but the group she attended came across as "cult-ish" and/or something that would be endorsed by Gywenth Paltrow (Goop). Any group that requires you to come to their organization 3 times a week for 90 minutes $800/month screams cult-ish. This kind of "therapy" is not realistic or sustainable for the average person. Most people cannot dedicate that much time t

user_name: PinkAmy loves books, cats and naps
review_text:
I listened to the Audible version of the book, read by the author.

Memoirs are difficult when the writer comes across as unlikable, more so when that writer narrates her story. I suppose a certain amount of self-importance is necessary to assume one’s life is worth a story, unless you’re someone famous like Michelle Obama or you’ve had an extraordinary life experience or deep insight, none of which applies to Christie Tate. She comes across as privileged and unlikable, but that wasn’t my biggest

Tate's evolution of self through totally honest, soul-baring & nontraditional-style group therapy will leave you feeling mentally taken apart & put back together. 'Group' is raw w/ insight & vulnerability & it was kind of therapeutic just reading it, as it creates a sense of hopefulness & positivity. Fantastic non-fic story!

As someone who has had therapy as a part of my life for as long as I can remember, I have always been fascinated by what it is like for other people. I am so grateful that especially during this last decade mental health and therapy have been normalized so much.

I started attending therapy when I was just a child during my parent's tumultuous and quite painful divorce. While it was something that was monumental in my ability to process many hard encounters and feelings, it was also a very isolati

****Now available!****

Thank you to Christie Tate and Simon & Schuster UK for a copy of the book in exchange for an honest review.

As I've said before: I LOVE a memoir. The more ordinary the person, the better! Me and nosey self just love a snoop into other peoples' lives and BOY did I get a snoop!

Christie is a law student battling with an eating disorder and intimacy issues and finally decides to take the plunge and start therapy. She is recommended Dr Rosen by one of her friends and she goes to
DNF at 22%. Just didn't care about all these different people in the group's complaints. Was grossed out by some of the therapist's the sexual comments.

Welp so, full transparency here, I have an eating disorder. I used to go to this awesome group a few years ago and now struggling to drag myself to this new group therapy. I tried reading this to find me some motivation to go, but it ended up being an upsetting read for me personally.

Dr. Rosen's therapies are strange and unorthodox and not alike anything you'd find normally. If you have questions about normal group therapy, ask google, your therapist, or myself. -- This book is not about anyone

This is quite a strange read and one that I alternately liked and didn't like.
It is extremely personal and I found the parts where there are lots of reference to sex a bit much.
I didn't particularly like the characters and found the whole American obsession with therapy hard to understand.
We basically join Christie on her journey, via group therapy with Dr Rosen, in her search for personal enlightenment and the opportunity to free herself from a lifetime of crushing self-doubt, self-harm and lac
I would go with 4.5. Refreshing and honest - and full of hope.

I usually do not read memoirs, but one of my friends is a librarian and had an advanced copy of this book. As a retired psychotherapist, I have to question some of Dr. Rosen's techniques and ethics. He could have directed the group to intervene more and could have helped the author better handle her emotional outbursts, which were over the top, creating havoc in her life, and really distressing to her. While I agree with his stance on not keeping secrets, I would hope readers understand that go

I have no idea who Christie Tate is but reading her memoir was perhaps one of the most intimate experiences I’ve ever felt reading about someone else’s life. Group is raw, powerful, funny, tear-jerking, and honest. I flew through the pages in a few short hours soaking it all in; every page left me wanting to know more, read further. I 100% recommend for a cathartic reading experience!

I'm no stranger to recovery memoirs or tales of therapy but I can honestly say I've never read a book like this before! Unpredictable, heartfelt and absorbing, I read this book and can't stop thinking about it.

Comments were deleted somehow.

Book was " off" for me. Something fishy about it.
Group was not a book for me. I just could not connect with the information or the author. The information felt too forced for my liking.

"I can be mad at you and still love you, you know"
No, actually, I didn't know that. I had no idea.

There are so many revelations like the one above in Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Saved My Life by Christie Tate that made me realize how much we assume how others feel.

The author, with unabashed honesty, takes us through her harrowing journey of grief, loneliness, depression, and self loathing until she joins Dr. Rosen's many group therapy sessions. She writes with such fearles

Group
280 pages
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Christie Tate had just been named the top student in her law school class and had her eating disorder under control at last. Why then was she driving through Chicago fantasizing her own death? Enter Dr. Jonathan Rosen, a therapist who calmly assured her that if she joins one of his psychotherapy groups, he can transform her life. All she has to do is show up and be honest. So begins her entry into the strange, terrifying and life-changing world of group therapy. ( trigge

I just loved this. It was so entertaining that I flew through it in one weekend. But I offer one caveat: this therapist seems certifiably nuts. While I’ve never been to therapy, some of his prescriptions and recommendations seem so far off. That said, everything seemed to work out for our memoirist here and I’m stunned that she chose to share these same (and embarrassing) stories with the world. Group seemed safe enough... at one point it seemed the entire city of Chicago would have known all he

Christie Tate has always been an overachiever. She buried herself in her textbooks and earned first place in her class at Loyola Law. She lands a plum job working for one of the nation’s leading law firms, but Christie wants more. All her life she has had trouble building and maintaining close relationships. She longs for a family and wishes for death. Told by her mother not to share her personal business, she nonetheless seeks help from Dr. Rosen who assigns her to one of his groups.
A raw, hone

I am found this memoir such an interesting read. I have never had therapy for myself so it’s an interesting look into a probably less conventional group. I’m not sure Group Therapy would be for me but I do like the idea of everyone working together.

Thank you Simon & Schuster Canada and Netgalley for my review copy.

Bravo! I’ve read and loved many memoirs but this one was hands-down my favorite. If I had to sum it up in one word I would call it CATHARTIC.

Dr. Rosen insists his clients tell all because anything less is more toxic than everyone knowing your business so Tate bears all to her quirky, Einstein-like therapist and six strangers - from bulimia to her childhood friend’s father drowning to finding a man who will love her. It’s raw. It

To start, this is intimidating to write a review that has the potential to be taken to group! I am sure Dr. Rosen would have something interesting to say about my fear.

That being said, this book was just this book for me. I neither liked nor disliked it. At times it made me uncomfortable, while at times I identified with it. The writing was uneven and at times confusing. It was also, strangely intriguing and relatable at times.

I am not sorry I finished it, but not sure I would ever read it again

Therapy is an essential part of getting to the core roots of your problems and essentially taking back your life. I personally have never done group therapy but Christine Tate has hit the nail on the head. Her experience with group therapy after overcoming anorexia is quite an achievement. Any one who has experienced depression and suicidal thought can relate to this book. I think the unconventional way that her therapist ran the group saved quite a few people. I give this amazing book five star

Thank you #Netgalley for the advanced copy.

Wow! I loved following the progression of Christie and really seeing therapy work for her. The concept of this group therapy seemed so unique! I applaude Christie and the others in the group share such personal things and to really make connections and force each other out of their comfort zone. So many things seemed so relatable about her thought process, but she trusted in the program and it ended up working for her.

I LOVED, loved, loved this book!

Thank you to Simon & Schuster for this advanced reading copy--I was SO excited to win it, as these types of books are my jam! (anything, pretty much, person growth oriented). Though one never knows if they will be any good.

To my utter surprise...wow, Ms. Tate can write. Much has and will be made of the content/material about which she writes. But writing-wise, she definitely is far more skilled than I expected from her being a hotshot lawyer (her career in this me

Group - How one therapist and a circle of strangers saved my life // by Christie Tate

Sometimes I come across titles or blurbs that leave me thinking "THIS WAS WRITTEN JUST FOR ME." Now, I'm not that delusional that I think that is literally true but I still wonder if someone, something, somewhere had me in mind when this book idea came into existence. For someone that was not even into memoirs until last year, I sure to race through them at full speed now, especially those related to mental heal

I've read three "therapy" books in the last 18 months. I think I'm hungry for stories of transformation, to be reminded that change is possible. Of these, "Maybe You Should Talk to Someone" is still my favorite, but I really enjoyed Group.

Unlike the other therapy books I've read, Group is written from the POV of a patient, not the therapist; it is the story of Christie, a high-achieving law student who is rated #1 in her class and secretly falling apart. When a friend recommends that she go to a

So I’ve been rolling this review around in my head since I finished the book, and to be honest I’m still not sure where I land. From a strictly entertainment standpoint, it was good. I listened to it and found myself really looking forward to the times when I could get back to the story. Christie is no holds barred- and from what she shares in the book we know that complete honestly was something she struggled with before therapy so for her openness, I applaud her. That said, I love to get deep

I am not quite sure what to make of this book, on the one hand it is honest, well written and ultimately uplifting, on the other hand it is a gross invasion of others’ privacy, disturbing to read and I could have done without the yucky intimate details of her sex life. I wonder if part of my distaste is that engaging with therapy appears to be mainstream in the USA whereas it is less common in the UK.
Certainly Christie suffered from post traumatic stress disorder after she witnessed a friend’s f

This book was right up my alley topic wise, and that aspect of it was fine. Nothing groundbreaking, the writing is okay, and the stories were also okay. There is a lot of emphasis on sex and intimacy which I wasn’t expecting, kudos to Tate for putting her bare life out there for everyone to read. It did get repetitive towards the end where the behaviours were repeating themselves just in different ways, but as is the nature of mental illness I guess.

BUT, my biggest concern with the book is Dr R

this book is fun to read because it's messy, but wow is the author a narcissist. I have seen people criticize the book because she mentioned group members stories, but honestly it's mainly about her and her boring life. Her life is not interesting, its the average mid 20 year old woman experience, she just breaks a few more plates. Her fellow peers sound way more complex and I was very worried while reading it about the ways the therapist could be taking advantage of their emotional state. That

Some of the stories and fears shared in this was great and it definitely had some LOL moments; however, there must be some kind of rules broken by the therapist who leads the group when she starts over sharing to the participants in group. If I was going to support, I would feel creeped out when the therapist is taking over and spilling her guts. Still a worthy read for people that find comfort for their issues in a setting like this but it may not be for all.

Goof writing and some stories but ta

"Group" is an intimate memoir exploring author Christie Tate's experience with mental ill health and an eating disorder, and the support she found in an unconventional group setting. Whilst therapist Dr Rosen's methods seem unorthodox, there is clearly validity in his approach. Tate really opens herself up, exposing her vulnerability in a warts and all manner. Yes, this makes for an uncomfortable read in places but I figure if Christie has taken the time to bare her soul, the least I can do as a

An engaging and entertaining memoir of one woman’s experiences with the healing power of group therapy. The author goes deep as she brings us with her to her sessions and shows how the difficult process of revealing her most personal secrets allowed her to develop more intimate relationships.

Read our full review here:
https://booktrib.com/2020/10/27/one-w...

Listened on audiobook. I enjoyed this book and had no trouble with the pace of the story, but unlike the book “Maybe You Should Talk to Someone” I didn’t put it down feeling like I had many, structured actionable lessons or takeaways from Christie’s story. There certainly are lessons but it didn’t feel like the story was written with those in mind.

The whole time I was reading this I was wondering - why am I so invested in the author’s relationship history? But I couldn’t put it down, and flew through it in just a couple sittings. Her story isn’t exactly remarkable, but it was told in such a way that kept me engaged and curious (and laughing), and hoping for her sake that her group therapy would finally “work.”

This book was a really honest and absorbing exploration of group therapy, and the impact it has on people. At times it was an uncomfortable read, and covered a lot of issues from eating disorders, to trauma, to sexuality and attachment issues in a lot of visceral detail. Overall the story was really interesting, and the personal development of the characters made me keep coming back for more. Not for the faint hearted! Overall I enjoyed this.

I received an pre-publication copy of this book throu

I read Group by Christie Tate via Pigeonhole, which released a stave a day for 10 days. I have never been in therapy and have no intentions of ever seeking help from a therapist. I found the book very frivolous and was bored by the end of the book. The book wasn’t for me and held little to interest me.

3.5⭐

I was fortunate to receive a copy of this ARC from Pigeonhole.

It feels wrong somehow to review an autobiographical book, because what right do I have to critique someone's life?!

However, I did find this a difficult read. The therapy setting in America is very different to my experiences in the UK, even group therapy, and some of the work done was quite shocking. It didn't always feel like Christie was receiving the right support and some of Dr Rosen's treatments seemed ethically and morally
Found the author to be self-centred, self-indulgent, attention seeking, over sharing and was uncomfortable reading this book.

This is different from any book I’ve ever read. I read it in a group, and have to admit to getting annoyed a few times with people judging the author and her therapist on his ways of dealing with the group he was leading. I admit it was a different way of handling his group as therapists usually go with secrecy. I am not going to say I enjoyed the book. But I can say it was well written and there was times I could put myself in Christie’s place. I gave it 3 stars. And I would recommend it.

I don't really know how to review this book. "Enjoy" seems the wrong word. It's a very honest memoir of a person's journey through therapy. Lots of the author's thoughts and feelings really resonated with me so it was sometimes a difficult read. Overall I'm glad I stuck with it.

The group therapy angle of this book had me hooked, especially this being a memoir. Christie made me laugh, cry, and feel. Read this book if you want to feel something.

Thanks to Netgalley, the author and Avid Reader Press for an ARC in exchange for an honest review.

Thanks to Net Galley and Simon and Schuster UK for an advance copy of this book.

Okay so let me start out by saying I did have high hopes for this book. I love self-improvement and I was hoping I could learn something. I was under the impression is was majority non-fiction and factual. After about the half way point I was confused.

I believe this book is a blend of memoir and fiction (I’m really not sure how it falls into non-fiction). It does explain the behaviour of a very strange therapist who
Really not for me, I didn’t feel right reading it. I felt as though I was intruding on confidential matters

3.75 rounded up - I love reading books about therapy and group therapy has always seemed so TV-esque to me. At times this story was too much for me - it was totally manic at many points, which is probably the point, and I could have done without graphic sexual details in favor of something a little more ~subtle~. But I applaud Christie for sharing arguably the most vulnerable, embarrassing, and emotional parts of her life! If I were in group therapy there’s no way I’d write a book about it.

Many

Group by Christie Tate is a free NetGalley ebook that I read in early October.

Overstressed suicidal author Tate goes to group therapy to sort things out. She's initially reluctant to share things, be asked questions, acknowledge a complicated relationship with food, then gradually sharing all her inner stressors, realizing her inner worth and reasons for living.

Christie Tate is at the top of her law school class, but unfortunately, she still just isn’t happy. When her friend tells her about her group therapy, Christie decides why not give this Dr. Rosen a chance. Now she is meeting with a group of 6 people every week and telling them everything about her and her life. Christie is put off by some of Dr. Rosen’s ideas at first, but over time she comes to love these people like family. Doesn’t mean she doesn’t hate them at some times too.

This one started

Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Saved My Life by Christie Tate was a really interesting exploration of the author's experience with group therapy. Going into this, I knew very little about what group therapy actually looked like. That said, this was also a very unique therapy experience, so the book is really about exploring the author's specific experiences versus a commentary on any type o

I've done a huge amount of therapy, both group and individual, in my life time. I enjoy learning about other's experiences and what they may have picked up during their time in therapy. Everyone has different needs for therapy and I appreciate the way people can learn from each other. The account just seems extreme and far fetched. I don't want to down play or criticize someone else's experience and I'm very glad this worked for the author. But my deeply personal opinion is that I would have lef

I really enjoyed this author's voice, but did not enjoy the read at all. Tate expressed herself well and I felt like she was the friend you talk about saying "She's such a great catch, why can't she find a man?" I wanted to relate to her, but as soon as life takes a turn she doesn't like, she is literally on the floor screaming like a toddler in the middle of her group therapy. I couldn't sympathize with her and I also couldn't get behind Dr. Rosen's method. It felt like she spent 5+ years being

Thank you to Avid Reader Press and Simon and Schuster for sending me this ARC to review.

I laughed, I cried, I got mad, and I cared a lot about the characters in reading this book. Christie Tate has really put her life out there in this memoir. The book starts with her fixation with wanting to die. Group is an interesting memoir on the experience of group therapy.

Tate is a skillful autobiographical writer, approaching her subject with brutal honesty and striking just the right balance between humour and misery. Her story makes for a compulsive, engaging read.

The therapy itself made me a little uncomfortable at times, with Dr Rosen's unconventional approach and problematic line-crossing. In many ways it was a bit like reading about a cult.

But red flags aside, it was interesting to see the e

When I started reading Group I assumed it was fiction. Imagine my surprise and awe when 1/4 way in I realised it is a memoir. This is a layered account of Christie Tate's all out efforts to create meaningful relationships in her own life. She came to her first group, having made quite clear to the therapist that she wanted to end her life, and if group therapy didn't work within five years, she would do so. So she raged, loved and crumpled at rejection - all witnessed and supported by her group

Loved this memoir!! So brutally honest and refreshing. Also very funny! I laughed out loud in parts :) Group is all about the authors journey through years of group therapy with a bunch of very unique individuals and a quirky therapist. I just fell love with everyone by the end of the book and kind of wanted to go to Group myself :)

Personally I had a hard time finishing this book .I did not care for the way the the therapy Dr led this group or much of the advise given . I am thankful for the oppotunity I had to read this book, however this was a book I did not personally enjoy.

I received this book from the giveaway. This was an interesting ride. I enjoy memoirs and I enjoy books about therapy but this one wasn't my style. I'm not sure for whom this book was written. Christie Tate gets very real and honest and explicit about her past and relationships. I felt it was a little heavy on sex and, as almost everyone has mentioned, the therapist in this book raises some alarms. Mommy blogger Christie Tate (aka Outlaw Mama) recounts her earlier years in her debut memoir, GROUP.

On the day that she is named top of her class in law school, Christie wants to die. Thoughts of self-harm have been floating in her head for some time. She can’t form a lasting romantic relationship or any type of personal connection. She can talk about football and the weather with her family, but nothing more substantial. She fills this void in her life by immersing herself in her work. She also

Christie Tate is a successful Chicago lawyer who has the brain and the skills to thrive in the professional world. Behind her professional persona is a side to her that is struggling immensely. Christie is a recovering bulimic, and after completing a 12-step program, she continues to be extremely unhappy. She is tired of feeling alone and miserable. A friend suggests group therapy, and though it is way out of her comfort zone, she's desperate to feel better. Group therapy pushes Christie to conf

We meet Christie as she aimlessly drives around in her car, wishing that she were dead. Christie is a promising law student turning lawyer. She is also in recovery from an eating disorder, insecure, anxiety ridden, lonely and a total mess. Her friend suggests that she embark on a journey of group therapy, and she does. This was so unexpected - I picked it up and ripped through it in two days, which I have not done to a book in ages.
Christie's story is relatable especially in light of the (enforced) isolation many of us have been in to one degree or another. On the the surface she is going brilliantly, top of her law school class with a promising career ahead of her. Inside she is feeling so disconnected from people and herself, she finds herself wishing someone would shoot her.

Enter Dr Rosen and his groups.

I enjoyed reading this book and learning about group therapy. As someone who has been in traditional individual therapy before, I have always been curious about group therapy and it was interesting to get a first hand perspective from someone who has now been in "group" for years. I can see both pros and cons to group therapy but it was clear to me that for some therapy patients it is a lifesaver.

Quick Summary: Christie Tate is a successful law student at the top of her class but profoundly unhappy. She reluctantly agrees to join group therapy and open herself up to six strangers every week. This memoir follows Christie as her life is transformed by her unconventional therapist and fellow group members.

Group is the November @reesesbookclub pick and my selection for #nonfictionnovember.

Summary: Christie Tate, a Texan, is in her second year of law school when she begins to have thoughts of active self-harm. Tate tells the tale of her introduction to the charismatic Dr. Rosen, and how group therapy ("spilling all your secrets to six strangers") completely changed her life.

This no holds barred memoir was riveting. We meet Christie when she is a law student and top of her class, and yet emotionally at rock bottom. Reading Group is like riding an emotional rollercoaster. When author Christie Tate enters group therapy, she bares her soul to her therapist and group members, and we as readers are privy to all of this. At times, reading this book almost felt intrusive, like a voyeur reading someone's diary. For Tate, nothing is off limits to include descriptions of her what-were-you-thinking choice of boyfriends to her love/hate relationship with her therapist, Dr. Rosen.

So tricky to review.

GROUP is a thought-provoking memoir that focuses on author Christie Tate's experience in group therapy. Christie is referred to group therapy as a type-A law student living in Chicago. An over-achiever who drives herself relentlessly, Christie finds her way to mental health through her therapist and the groups with which she commits to share her actions, her thoughts, and her dreams. While the journey is absorbing and the ending satisfying, there still seem to be missing elements. What was the relationship with her family? Structured as a letter to his teenage son, Ta-Nehisi Coates writes about what it means to be a black man in America. But it was so provocative that often I could only read a

Drawing on an established tradition by American writers of color, 'Between the World and Me' is Ta-Nehisi Coates' own letter to his son. While I was reading, I heard loud echoes of of black writers passing on their experiences with race issues through their lives, including James Balwin's "My Dungeon Shook: Letter to My Nephew on the One Hundredth Anniversary of the Emancipation, 'The Autobiography of Malcolm X and MLK Jr.'s 'Letter from Birmingham Jail.' I honestly do not feel right putting a rating on this man's experiences, heartfelt thoughts and wishes for his son. I grew up in Chicago and I have seen more than my fair share of the racial divide. Yet, I have never before read an eye opening book like this one. I am not going to express my views on what I think of what he wrote, my opinions have no place here. This is his viewpoint, shared by many of the black race and that is what I found astonishing, because it gave me an inside look at how

If you're waiting for the millionth person to tell you to read this book, allow me to be Person 1,000,000. The audiobook is narrated by the author, Ta-Nehisi Coates, and it made the experience deeper for me.

Holy shit this book. I broke down into tears on the subway upon finishing the last page. It's the privilege of white men. Women have additional concerns. Black people can get shot for skulking. My body, which has been defined as white, is almost invincible. No one wants the headache of fucking with a white body. I skulk with impunity.

Ta-Nehisi Coates is a beautiful stylist, one who writes with a power reminiscent of Richard Wright and Ralph Ellison. In every word, every clause, every phrase there is the power of history, the history of his culture, his race, his people and their plight.

Coates leaps off the page at you. He writes and informs about the cultural divide, indeed, the vast chasm, which exists between African-Americans and whites in America. This accomplished writer tells of the young black experience: the trauma,

Speaking truth to the world. And my biggest fear is that the world will not hear him. I think he is right in everything that he says. The Dreamers need to learn to shoulder their own struggles and let go of that "Dream". Unbelievable the amount of truth packed into such a short book. This book has received huge accolades, but will the people understand? The eternal question that "people of color" (for lack of a better term...maybe non-Dreamers) seem to be asking...

Amazing and eloquent.

By all benchmarks known to the publishing world, Ta-Nehisi Coates' epistle to his son Between the World and Me can be regarded an Olympian succes, both in terms of its critical and public reception. Ever since it saw publication, It's been hyped up to high heaven, with Coates even being hailed as the rightful successor of the illustrious James Baldwin. Among this surprising avalance of praise, I couldn't detect almost any voice that had an even slightly unfavourable thing to say about it. As a r

This is a profound, moving, timely book. Coates frames this series of essays as a letter to his son, exploring what it means to be black in America, and how issues involving race have shaped and continue to shape the country in which he lives.

The audio version, read by the author, is fantastic.

It's worth noting that this is a short read—so if you've been meaning to read it but keep putting it off, I hope knowing you can get through it quickly inspires you to pick it up right now!

Silly me. After finishing the excruciatingly painful-to-read Missoula: Rape and the Justice System in a College Town, I figured I should probably read something a bit lighter. To that end, I decided to tackle Ta-Nehisi Coates's remarkable epistle to his teenaged son. Coates began this book after the grand jury declined to indict the officer who shot Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, in an attempt to explain to his son the world as he saw it. The result is a poetic flood that reminds me of wha

Of the long list of reasons why everyone (yes, everyone) needs to read this book (it can be read from start to finish in a matter of hours), I would simply add this: You should read it for the utter pleasure of experiencing an amazing writer at the height of his talent and his powers with language. It's rare to read something so word-for-word perfect.
Re-regurgitation. I need something fresher.

The hype is real. It lives up to every word and more.

It also deserves to be bought as a paper copy to underline extensively. Just do both.

In a word, incredible. I blew through this book. The picture he paints is powerful and inspiring and tragic.

Coates' atheism doesn't leave a lot of room for silver lining, but that bleak philosophy is precisely what drives the intensity of his call to action. There is no silver lining to the injustice that was wrought in the 250 years of American slavery, or the systemic racism that has followed in its wake.

There is more I could say about this book, but I can't do it justice at this moment.

We are bad lie-detectors, we routinely misjudge others, and we forget the context of a situation when we really shouldn’t, Malcolm Gladwell says. So basically, we overestimate our competence in social interactions and blame our errors on the wrong things. Is that so surprising? Seemingly unrelated cases point to the possibility—and more disputably, a need—for an alternate explanation.

“Talking to Strangers” is an interesting look at why we are so bad at that act of understanding one another. As in all of his books (and in most of the genre of pop-psychology, though I'd rechristen this genre "pseudo-psychology" to reflect the pseudoscience it becomes in so many works like Gladwell's as opposed to the valuable scientific discipline that it has demonstrated itself to be throughout the body of scientific literature and more rigorous, intellectually honest popular science works), Gladwell bases his work firmly in the realm of individual anecdotes rather than objective academic research.

I wanted to discover a book that I could recommend to friends and to people that I think are genuinely interested in understanding how people of color often think and feel and to be able to inhabit/formulate/grok a point of view that might be different from their own. On the whole, I expected to understand the points of view Oluo was presenting from the beginning and I didn't anticipate that the book would have

People of every race are going to read this book—at least I hope they are. It is not written just for people still denying that racism exists in America today, but for people who know it does but do not recognize the myriad ways it manifests. Oluo writes so clearly and simply, this book just a pleasure to read, despite addressing emotionally sensitive material. The following is partly a review but mostly a discussion of racism and privilege because, yes, I'd like to talk about race:
Am I racist?

This question hit me as I was sitting on my phone scrolling Instagram. Around the end of May 2020, George Floyd's death took the world by storm. Within hours, my feed was filled with #BlackLivesMatter and black screens. I got a message saying "[Removed for privacy] tagged you in a story". Said story was a story chain where someone tags a few other people and

Short version:
Probably the biggest crap I have ever read.

Longer version:

So You Want To Talk About Race is a waste of time, money and brain cells for anyone who comes into contact with it. Anyone with the smallest ability for critical thinking will find no need for this garbage, and those infected with the intersectionality virus are the proverbial choir being preached to. Every page is filled with hypocrisy, nonsensical jibberish and logical fallacies. Some of the 'gems':

i am not going to review this beyond saying that this is an absolute must read book. for everyone.

review_text:
This work goes deep to the core of the problems and dismantles the grievances that are still causing an unnecessary separation in many of the wealthiest nations on earth.

The book should be read by everyone but is especially useful for white people who want to try to avoid making mistakes in getting active and to especially realize blind spots that could stay undetected. That just a few decades ago all Western institutions were racist, white supremacists that build a world for their people and th

Audiobook....narrated by Bahni Turpin

This was an incredibly valuable book — clear, direct, informative, educational, insightful, easy to understand, intensely personal and full of captivating advice in a graceful and easily accessible prose. As we manage ourselves — engage in the conversations about race and confront the challenges we face — this book will help all of us with much-needed common sense.

Ijeoma Oluo, Nigerian American author, ( named on of the most influential people in Seattle), h

There are timeless books. Ta-Nehisi Coates' Between the World and Me is a timeless book. Then there is another category of books I would call “books for our time.” And Between the World and Me is that kind of book too.

But consider Ijeoma Oluo’s So You Want to Talk About Race. It is definitely a book for our time, yet I doubt many people—me included—would ever consider it a timeless book. Yet paradoxically, Oluo’s book may be an even more important book for certain people to read than any of Mr.

I stayed up late into the night reading this.

I was engaged. I loved the writing, the well-formulated arguments, and especially the focus on everyday micro-aggression. Intersectionality is pretty obvious.

So is the institutional racism.

It's not a trigger word. It's a fact.

Add this to soooo0 many small things in our everyday lives whether in conversation or news or even in our own assumptions DESPITE our best intentions, and we will be forced to realize that the institution is within us all.

Ste

An amazing book of essays about race. Ijeoma Oluo strikes an impressive balance between writing bold, uncomfortable truths about racism as well as crafting her essays so that they feel approachable and digestible. She covers a wide range of topics in this collection, including affirmative action, police brutality, the problem with touching black women’s hair, the model minority myth, and more. Some themes I felt across essays include the importance of actually acknowledging race (a bare minimum

Everything she says is true and necessary, but it comes off more as a shallow lecture than anything new or different. I think it could be useful as a primer or to those who don't spend a lot of time reading about race.

Ijeoma Oluo doesn’t simply want us feeling better about ourselves for having read her book; So You Want to Talk About Race is also a call to action. Most compelling is Oluo’s discussion of the damage caused by ‘everyday racism,’ the kind of racist attitudes or behavior that many don’t think really matters. What one person might see as small inconsequential actions have the cumulative weight of life experience. Words and behavior matter. Everyday racism also feeds into an acceptance of the system

So You Want To Talk About Race by Ijeoma Oluo

I loved this book. I finished it in a day simply devouring Oluo’s word. I can relate to so much of what Oluo was sharing and in so many ways it was validating but also depressing. I feel better knowing that I’m not the only person experiencing these microaggressions, working through these issues and surviving day to day but at the same time having these similar lived experiences makes me very well aware of how far we have to come in the U.S. when it
This should be required reading for every person.

This book is largely for non-POC who wish to be allies or POC who are in denial of, not aware of or unfamiliar with the systemic racism prevalent in American society. Unlike many other scholarly works on race, this book uses language that is accessible and could even be used in an AP Language course. Actually, it would probably be a great addition to an AP Language course.

Most importantly, it needs to be read far and wide by teachers especially or anyone who works with POC.
this is gonna be one of my 'non-fiction-books-i-listened-to-on-audio-but-want-to-buy-a-copy-of-for-future-reference'

This is not a review. I’m not in the mood to read or review books in light of recent events. All I want to say is that all lives don’t matter until black lives matters. The way George Floyd was murdered is horrifying and heartbreaking. I can’t imagine the pain and suffering his loved ones are going through. It warms my heart that people care enough to march during this pandemic. I hope this movement doesn’t lose momentum and meaningful change finally happens. And if you’re tired of hearing about
Educational and easy to understand. I think most people would benefit is one way or the other from reading this.

So You Want to Talk About Race, Ijeoma Oluo’s new book asks. I thought I did, but after reading several chapters I realized no, no I very much did not want to. I think I’d rather talk about my receding hairline, my cholesterol levels, the abnormally large size of my physician’s fingers (the yearly physical is coming up and it will be time once again to check out that ole prostate), just about anything really, because talking about race is uncomfortable, uncomfortable, uncomfortable.

So You Want

For someone who never talked about race in their household, this is a great starter book.
It will require you to leave ur ego aside (if you're white) and LISTEN. Not everything will resonate but some things will make you question ur deeply engrained views and understanding of how the system is failing POC.

An excellent primer in talking about race and anti-racism. It is concise, well organized and well thought out. I felt all of the care that Oluo put into patiently and clearly laying out the basics of racism in the US. My main takeaways are the ways she advises responding to racist thoughts and actions, simple easy ways to reframe conversation. I'm finding it harder and harder to not just give into frustration and emotion, so I appreciated this book for its perspective of "this is very hard, and

So you want to talk about race?
But are we truly listening?

2020 has made many of us sit up and really take notice...but in all honesty we need to do MORE!
This book is an accessible and insightful place to start our research with fantastic bullet points and guides for how to approach and handle the uncomfortable conversations that often surround race, racism & systemic oppression. While taking the time to explain many terms that tend to cause confusion in a very understandable way, peppered with h

I listened to this as an audiobook and I am glad I did. The narration was very good, but it also made me feel almost as if I was having a conversation with the author, or rather listing to her explain conflicts many of us are blind to and thus, often inadvertently or not, allow to perpetuate. I am reading this book in the wake of the murders of Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, and it feels overdue. It is an important and impactful read and one I would recommend to anyone.

Find more

Go. Read. This. Book. Well written, informative, and concerned with the reader learning, not just the author being right.

You should read this:
• If you want to talk about racial topics better
• If you’re great at talking about race
• If you never want to talk about race

Everyone should read this book. This should be the very next book you read.

Written tight as a logical proof and with a careful delivery so that the bad news can be heard by we who need to hear it most. A concrete and highly actionable discussion, reinforced with evidence and examples to make sure that the reader can connect. My fellow white folks: you need to read this. And as the introduction advises, sit with your discomfort when it arises. Even those of us who are trying have a lot to learn. Ms. Oluo has done us the favor of making this piece of our education afford

'Until we have dismantled the system of White Supremacy and racial oppression, we will always need to talk about it.'

While I have been dreading reviewing this book, I have nevertheless been thinking about it a lot since reading it. I must admit I randomly picked it out of a Goodreads recommended list due to its prominence in the racism discourse, cemented by its bestsellerdom and Oluo’s own status as a prominent spokesperson.

The fact that the aforementioned Goodreads reading list itself has attr

I'm a little torn on this book. It certainly provides a lot of facts and advances a lot of arguments that white Americans (all of us, no matter how woke we think we are) need to hear. In the current political climate a book like this is especially important. But I thought the writing was pretty mediocre for the most part; it was no Between the World and Me or We Gon' Be Alright. Still, I think this book does what it sets out to do, and I would not discourage anyone from reading it. In fact, if y
Hands-down the most approachable and succinct book on this topic that I have read, and I've read quite a few. A primer on race that I wish could be required reading for the entire nation.

Excellent book! It is a hard read and I think you need to take your time with this book, or I did at least, to really soak up all of the information. I found reading it one chapter at a time per day or two allowed me to really think about all of the different things discussed.

I learned a lot about systemic racism versus personal/individual racism. This was a concept that I really didn't know much about previously and it has opened my eyes to many things. I also found the concept of intersectiona

Well-written book about an enormously painful and horrible system of oppression. Read this book if you want to learn how to talk about race, how to engage with a person of colour with real respect, empathy and a willingness to interrogate your conscious and unconscious biases and assumptions, and to begin doing more to change your attitudes and actions, as well as those around you.

For many years I thought I was woke - then I unintentionally hurt and lost one of my closest friends who is black, with a few uninformed words. It humbles and pains me that though my intent was good, the impact was devastating.

I had started to see myself, and once you start to see yourself, you cannot pretend anymore.

If only I had read Ijeoma's writing before that. So You Want to Talk About Race, in combination with Difficult Conversations, should be required reading. Ijeoma wrote each short us

This is not a book for readers who want to sit back and pat themselves on the back. It is a call to action for us* to take responsibility for the institutional, widespread racism in our society (*specifically white, privileged individuals). Some of it is uncomfortable. We are not all as "woke" as we think. Every page is useful. This would be great as a required text in schools.

This book needs handed out in social studies courses in high school. Oluo packs so much in this book that I really do think is a good guide for people who have questions about race. She delves into all kinds of topics and I was here for them. Sometimes the writing gets a bit technical, but I think that a lot of pre-teens and above would do very well with reading this and having an honest conversation about race afterwards.

As one of my friend's laments, "The reason why the United States still has

A must-read for all white people, this book is very smart but very accessible. Oluo breaks down complicated issues like police brutality, the model minority myth, and tone policing (among others) masterfully, weaving together personal stories, detailed examples, and stats. This is definitely an entry-level book that feels aimed at white people and people of colour at the beginning of politicized learning. Excellent narration by Bahni Turpin like usual!

This isn't an easy-breezy book. It's not supposed to be.
Some readers will be triggered, some will be defensive, and some will think it's just too heavy, too negative, too un-American because we don't have racism here and stop making everything about race.

This book is about race.
It's in the title.
There is no false advertising here.

For me, this is a good bookend to Between the World and Me. I didn't quite get that book, I couldn't figure out what I needed to learn from Coates.
It was an introduct

EDIT 10/15/2020: I keep coming back to this book, time and again. I think about Ijeoma Oluo’s words more often than I thought I even would—especially what she wrote about race informing all experiences, all facets of the life, of a person of colour: how a thing may not be solely about race, but it is, at the end of the day, in some way/shape/form, about race. It’s helped me stop gaslighting myself whenever I think I am being too sensitive or perceiving things to be a certain (wrong) way—but

“If you live in this system of White Supremacy you are either fighting the system, or you are complicit. There is no neutrality to be had towards systems of injustice—it is not something you can just opt out of.”

Talking about race is hard and uncomfortable. Hackles are raised, emotions are riled up, and it seems so much easier to pretend it away and to shrug off the responsibility. Even if you think you aren't actively discriminating, or that you aren't a right-wing Neo-Nazi, you still can't

An engaging and thoughtful examination of race in these United States. Ijeoma Oluo brings new energy and determination to a discussion that can feel so fraught and loaded and hopeless. The book is presented both as a conversation and as manual, offering tips, guidelines, and discussion points to take the reader from the sidelines to the frontlines.

Its readership, as is so often the case with social justice primers, will be obviously self-selecting. The title alone, So You Want to Talk About Rac

Oh dear.
I bought this book out of a hope to be enlightened, perhaps. Or maybe it was to have a stage set to lubricate productive conversations when race inevitably comes up. I bought it because I am really lucky to have a rainbow of friends...friends who sadly experience racial microaggressions on a near daily basis... and I want to be a better advocate for them.
But at the risk of being deemed an offensive, racist B word, I can't give this book a glowing review.
I expected the book to be tricky,

Ijeoma Oluo did a brilliant job weaving her story into each chapter of this book. there were clear and informative definitions of terms I “know” but hadn’t fully unpacked (racism, intersectionality, privilege, micro-aggressions, tone policing). Oluo’s repeated refrain that “you are going to mess this up over and over again but you need to keep trying anyway” is incredibly powerful. reading a book is not action. but this book helped me understand more what is at stake, why action matters, and whe

I decided to read this book based on its high Goodreads rating. I was hoping the book would canvass the complex issues surrounding race and challenge readers to empathize with others they wouldn’t normally interact with. Unfortunately, this book appears intended for white people hoping to “check their privilege” and focuses solely on race as if only black and white people exist except for a cosmetic chapter on model minorities. The book’s arguments rarely rely on facts or statistics and in the f

This book was touted as the book we all need to read to be able to talk about race in America. And after reading it, I am wondering if I am not the intended audience.

Most of what she said was right. I just hated the way she said it.

The whole book I kept trying to nod and agree with her, but I was left feeling ashamed. How does that even happen. I found myself wanting to yell at her “STOP IT! I’m trying to agree with you!!!”

I was also annoyed about the way she talked about her white mother. It

I wanted to love this but I didn’t. I know I look like a jerk giving an okay rating to a book with this title and deeply important subject matter. I wonder if this was not suited to audio and would’ve been better in print. The narrator, who I have loved in the past, did not work here. I wish the author had read it.
Listened to a long time ago, but never recorded. Excellent.

This is going to be a tough and awkward review for a rather tough and awkward book.
I am white. And male. And straight. Yep, three pretty major strikes. Hard to argue the group I belong to isn't the reason the world is so fucking awful. While I personally didn't make it awful I accept what I represent in the eyes of the world. And it is not pretty to look at.

This was a good overview, a sort of manual for "race arguments on the internet." It's aimed mostly at validating the experiences of people of color, and at helping to clarify things for the population of white Americans who are just starting their anti-racist journey and want a quick explanation to get them going.

I'd give a CONTENT WARNING but it's right there in the title. Expect lots of hurtful stories about living as a Black woman.

Things I thought were very useful:

-The conversational style. T

Absolutely loved everything about this book!
It opened my eyes on so many matters and made me strengthen my ideas and opinions on race related issues.
I finished it with so MUCH thoughts in mind , and I feel like i can talk about it forever now !
Such an engaging and active reading indeed.
HIGHLY recommend it!

Race in America. Let's talk about it. Don't be that person who is all "racism doesn't exist" because that makes you sound like an idiot. You could do yourself the favor of picking up this book and learning about how racism does still exist, but chances are, if you are of that view that racism has been fixed because slavery doesn't exist anymore, well, you're not likely to pick up this book or listen to reason anyway. You're one of THOSE PEOPLE.

This is not a complicated book. It's pretty obvious

Yes, racism and racial oppression in America is horrible and terrifying. The feelings it brings up in us are justified. But it is also everywhere, in every corner of our lives. We have to let go of some of that fear. We have to be able to look racism in the eye wherever we encounter it. If we continue to treat racism like it is a giant monster that is chasing us, we will be forever running. But running won’t help when it’s in our workplace, our government, our homes, and ourselves. This book felt like an Introduction to Race 101 class and I don't mean that in a bad way. I think the book was simple and straight to the point in its approach and easily understandable. Ijeoma gave some helpful guidance on how to broach conversations on race in a more healthy and productive way. She literally put bullet points on how to address certain situations. In my opinion, more non-black/non-POC need to read this book.

The main topic I was drawn to was "What are microaggressions?". As I'v

I’m swapping over to not rating non-fiction but suffice it to say I learned and listened and appreciated this book so much. The audio was really well done and is free if your library subscribes to Hoopla.

I thought I would get more out of this read than I did based on the strong recommendations. Instead, what I received was the same load of absurdity that spews fourth daily from the social justice hivemind. I was unable to find a logical argument or sensible course of action from this text.

How do you know if something is about race? Oluo's answer: It is about race if a person of color thinks it's about race.

So she shuts down any sensible discussion right from chapter 1. Nice.

Even Oluo's own mothe

This is a competent, easily digestible primer on antiracism that I found to be a mostly valuable read.  Some of the topics that Oluo discussed were already familiar to me but enough were new or at least articulated in a new way that I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this to anyone looking more toward the beginner side of antiracism nonfiction.  I do think the actual writing style left a bit to be desired but it's a minor qualm; this book unarguably achieves what it sets out to achieve.

Part of the

We do need to talk about race but it is absolutely critical to talk about whether or not “something is about race.” The idea that an issue or outcome is race based if a POC thinks it is about race (rule 1), does not help to solve that issue, it further divides people and clouds the underlying problem. By incorrectly labeling the cause of a problem, you risk exacerbating the problem. (Thomas Sowell has several great books on this topic).

There are many problems in society, there are lingering eff

A very good introduction to anti-racist ideas and action. The author takes us in a clear path from thinking to speaking to acting in anti-racist ways, and offers clear, actionable suggestions at each step. Probably not much new if you've been following Oluo's work or are familiar with anti-racist ideas, but her writing is as excellent as ever, and the narration was also well-done. As a white woman who lived for many years in the PNW, many of her examples are uncomfortably familiar for me, but I
A simple and beautiful way of talking about race and explaining things that I’m sure many of us need to know. please read this book❤️

Explaining why I really didn't care for this book will take a while, but it's not all a difference of political opinion. This book has a lot of lazy argumentation and I have one glaring objective example. At the beginning of the chapter on appropriation, Oluo mentions the restaurant in SeaTac airport called The Africa Lounge. I live in Seattle, so even though I've never been to the place, I was aware that the owner of the restaurant is black.

I'm not reading nor recommending any more books about anti racism because I'm just bloody tired of talking about race.
I'm tired.
SO, I'm done
This was short and effective. Everyone should read this book but especially my fellow non-educated white people. We haven’t been taught any of this is school.

I mean...I DID want to talk about race. I WAS going to write a thoughtful and fair review. But according to Ijeoma, if I’m white—I don’t get it—and therefore don’t get an opinion or place in the conversation. Awkward.

Bothered me that she said people asking to touch her hair is a racist micro aggression and the result of white supremacy. I’m white. I’ve rocked naturally curly hair for years. You don’t have claim over this America-prefers-straight-hair-and-therefore-is-racist idea.

Nope. Not ever

It’s hard to capture the magnitude of what Ijeoma Oluo has accomplished in So You Want To Talk About Race. She has managed to write a clear and concise instruction manual on how to talk about one of our country’s most difficult subjects, while neither alienating nor infantilizing the reader. This is an especially important book for the newly “woke” white person who recognizes our structural and systematic racism in the US, but is unsure (or even terrified) of how to act on this new knowledge. I finished a book!

Review to come.

I haven’t rated a book in a while but this one deserves it.

This was a complete knockout!!!!!!!!! I have to recommend this one to anyone and everyone that would like a Black perspective on Race and how
to approach + talk about it. Iljeoma is a mixed race, queer activist that discusses her privilege and Black experiences in this Non-Fiction novel. From her childhood, to her experience with her sons + husband she tackles the way race systemically affects Black America. She even dives into why Black

Absolutely invaluable. Read this book now. I learned so much, I have better steps going forward, I have better ways to reflect for myself and better ways to have conversations with other white people around me, and I have actionable ideas that I can take with me to work. This book is an investment in a better future, and I hope you take the time to read and really engage with it. I absolutely could listen all over again, and will do so soon.

This is an accessible, and at the same time, deep, book. The author helps readers understand complex topics such as intersectionality by relating lived experiences and then connecting these to theory. In many chapters she provides tips that can lead readers to action that goes beyond talk about being anti-racist. The chapter "Why Can't I Touch Your Hair?" revealed experiences that were dehumanizing, infantilizing, and degrading. The denial to Black people of control over their bodies did not go

5/5 STARS ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ I posted a lot about this author and this book recently, and after finishing this book, I can confidently say the praise I previously expressed is well deserved. This is absolutely a #mustread. The real world examples and suggestions make this book a real standout from others addressing the topic of race in America. I will be referencing this book for years to come.

So You Want to Talk About Race is a user-friendly guide on issues that affect minorities. Ms. Oluo offers the reader a chance to sit uncomfortably with some issues that they might not realize how their thoughts, words, or actions can be adding to the race issue in America.

This book offers a lot to think about and practical ways about what you can do in your circumstances.

Awful. The author comes across as an immature, narcissistic racist (against whites) who is ranting from her soapbox of self appointed victimhood. The thought systems this book conveys are extremely dysfunctional. A big disappointment.

Wow, okay. I picked up this book because I really wanted to educate myself better about the racial inequity that's happening in America. And I'm just so happy that I did because this book is also a great primer on race and systematic racism. I highly recommend!
This is so smart and honest and powerful and I want to get copies for everyone I know

As the old saying goes, I was born on third base and taught that I hit a triple.

So You Want to Talk About Race is an admirable book and I'm so glad that Ijeoma Oluo used her opportunity to speak up and write it. There are many people I'd recommend this book to, many people who need to read it to gain some perspective. It's so clearly and simply written that it can be used as a toolkit or guide book for group discussions and help everyone have more constructive conversations about race and racism.
But it is not a 'timeless masterpiece', so to speak, and I'm afraid there will

I really don’t want to write a review for this book except saying that just pick it up. It’s a very necessary and eye opening read that’ll make us question our own privilege and perspective, help us understand the futility of being defensive about it, and also make us learn better ways to be an ally to Black people and engage in good faith conversations about racism.

I have to admit I alternated between feeling pretty pissed off, and a sense of appreciation at being able to receive what reads very much like a private (although social media blurs and complicates that distinction these days) person’s experiences of her life in daily America while reading this.
